story:
Who we are & where we come from...

Hello there! My name is Dulcey Fuqua. I am the dance director of Old Dominion Performance Arts Studio in Waynesboro, VA.  Our community is small and our studio is small, but our dancers have more passion than most people I know. We all work very hard and make one big family! This past year our traveling team of dancers stood together and realized that training with passion, hard work and commitment really does pay off.

We are a studio that accepts students regardless of background or financial situations.   We believe that every youth can benefit from the positive, nurturing and accepting environment we are committed to offering to all of our dancers. The need for such an environment truly stands out when I consider the family struggles (health and financial) that so many of our dancers live with and tell us that they see dance and our studio as their outlet and place where they are always accepted. In the past 12 years, I have seen lives changed and dreams realized for several of our students that without the support of their studio family and community, may have never happened.  I have seen students reacy beyond where they ever thought they could, because they knew people believed in them. 

I am reaching out to you, with 5 dancers of ours, asking for your help. These 5 dancers have qualified for New York City Dance Alliance's (NYCDA) National competition and would have the opportunity to go to NYC this summer and take classes with some of the top dancers, instructors and choreographers in the country.  They would have the opportunity to audition for a wide variety of scholarships (from this organization that last summer awarded 2.8 million dollars in college scholarships!)! These dancers would also be able to attend workshops from falculty from Complexions Contemporary Ballet and the world famous Cirque du Soleil and finally they would get to compete for national recognition along side with so many inspiring and talented dancers from around the world.

Even though all five of these dancers are exceptional and have ambitions that include professional involvement in the dance world, Katlyn Lawhorne and Donovan Mellon were two out of three awarded Future Star Scholarships at one of the regional NYCDA events this season and Donovan was also awarded one of eight regional ballet scholarships at this event. Donvan would be attending these Nationals as a runner-up for the Teen Outstanding Dancer Award & Scholarship from the regional event, and therefore would have a opportunity to compete for the national title.  

Without the financial contributions of others, these dancers will not be able to attend this event. 

 

 

 

How you can help...

We are hoping to raise $8000 in donations & sponsors. This would cover travel expenses to and from NYC, lodging, meals, convention fees and competition fees for this group of dancers to attend.  Lodging for 10 days in NYC can be extremely expensive, so $3500 of this $8000 goal, is to cover lodging. We expect travel expenses to be around $1200.  The remainder of funds raised will cover the NYCDA required fees for participation and meals.  

If we are able to raise more than this $8000, dependant upon how much, we may be able to have these dancers go to a Broadway show or professional performance, take in additional NYC siteseeing, or even take an additional national qualifying dancer(s) from our team with us on this trip. Otherwise, should there be additional funds raised not used for this direct trip, will be put aside for our scholarship program which would help dancers on our travel team next season

If we are not able to reach this goal and are not able for these dancers to attend this event - funds will be put aside for our scholarship program which would help dancers on our travel team next season

To thank anyone donating to our cause we would like to offer the following:

For a $25 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter from the dancers and be listed as an official sponsor of our team!

For a $50 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team and receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers.

For a $75 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive a signed additional poster featuring one of the 5 dancers.

For a $100 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive two signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers.

For a $125 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive three signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

For a $150 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive four signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

For a $175 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive five signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

For a $200 or more donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official VIP sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive five signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

Our studio has also offered for any family-friendly organization or business that donates $500 or more - a 4 month business card listing on the Studio Website!



Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to make a financial donation, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.

Please help us spread the word about our campaign!! Indiegogo has share tools to help others know about our cause. Pass it on!
story_txt:
Who we are & where we come from...
Hello there! My name is Dulcey Fuqua. I am the dance director of Old Dominion Performance Arts Studio in Waynesboro, VA.  Our community is small and our studio is small, but our dancers have more passion than most people I know. We all work very hard and make one big family! This past year our traveling team of dancers stood together and realized that training with passion, hard work and commitment really does pay off.
We are a studio that accepts students regardless of background or financial situations.   We believe that every youth can benefit from the positive, nurturing and accepting environment we are committed to offering to all of our dancers. The need for such an environment truly stands out when I consider the family struggles (health and financial) that so many of our dancers live with and tell us that they see dance and our studio as their outlet and place where they are always accepted. In the past 12 years, I have seen lives changed and dreams realized for several of our students that without the support of their studio family and community, may have never happened.  I have seen students reacy beyond where they ever thought they could, because they knew people believed in them. 
I am reaching out to you, with 5 dancers of ours, asking for your help. These 5 dancers have qualified for New York City Dance Alliance's (NYCDA) National competition and would have the opportunity to go to NYC this summer and take classes with some of the top dancers, instructors and choreographers in the country.  They would have the opportunity to audition for a wide variety of scholarships (from this organization that last summer awarded 2.8 million dollars in college scholarships!)! These dancers would also be able to attend workshops from falculty from Complexions Contemporary Ballet and the world famous Cirque du Soleil and finally they would get to compete for national recognition along side with so many inspiring and talented dancers from around the world.
Even though all five of these dancers are exceptional and have ambitions that include professional involvement in the dance world, Katlyn Lawhorne and Donovan Mellon were two out of three awarded Future Star Scholarships at one of the regional NYCDA events this season and Donovan was also awarded one of eight regional ballet scholarships at this event. Donvan would be attending these Nationals as a runner-up for the Teen Outstanding Dancer Award & Scholarship from the regional event, and therefore would have a opportunity to compete for the national title.  
Without the financial contributions of others, these dancers will not be able to attend this event.

For a $25 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter from the dancers and be listed as an official sponsor of our team!
For a $50 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team and receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers.
For a $75 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive a signed additional poster featuring one of the 5 dancers.
For a $100 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive two signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers.

For a $150 donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive four signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

For a $200 or more donation - you will receive a personal thank you letter, be listed as an official VIP sponsor of our team, receive a 11"x17" poster of the dancers, and receive five signed additional posters each featuring one of the 5 dancers

story:
How I Learned to Drive by Paula Vogel is the first show from Asae Dean Productions, a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Asae Dean Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

Hello. I’m Asae Dean, a stage director dedicated to producing passionate, poetic, provocative plays that explore both the personal and political aspects of love and sexuality. The Pulitizer Prize Winning play How I Learned to Drive by Paula Vogel is just such a play, a funny, forgiving, and feminist take on a Lolitaesquestory.

How I Learned to Drive runs September 7th – 9th and 14th – 16th at Backdoor Theatre in Portland, Oregon. The show features a fantastic cast of local Portland actors including Natalie Stringer, Tommy Harrington, Melanie Moseley, David M. Brown, and Elizabeth Garrett. Local actor and producer, Patrick J. Cox, is co-producing the show and local musician, Tobias Ryan, is serving as music director. Patrick, Tobias, and I have worked together on various theatrical projects over the past four years. How I Learned to Drive is the first show that we are independently producing. And we need your help.

We need to raise $1,000 to cover a portion of our production costs including our venue rental fee, performance royalties, publicity materials, costumes, and props. Your contribution is crucial to the success of this production, so we’re asking for your help. In exchange for your support, we're offering personalized haiku, signed show posters, programs and tickets. Please help bring this important story of abuse, love, and survival to Portland audiences. Thanks!

 

Unable to contribute? There are other ways you can help. 

1) Come see the show! We would love to have you there. 

Tickets are only $12 and are available at the door and online at: https://www.artfullyhq.com/store/events/339

2) Invite friends and family to the show! We would love to have them there.

You can read about the show and see publicity photographs shot by local artist Ari Grey at: http://www.asaedirects.com/how-i-learned-to-drive.html

3) Share this campaign.

story:
The Cause 

My name is Brian Egland.  I am a Producer, Director, Playwright, and Actor out of Lafayette, LA (but I'm a native of Breaux Bridge.)  In October of 2013 my play, She Still Dreams premiered at Cite des Arts, in Lafayette, LA.

Out of 383 submissions total, She Still Dreams was selected by The DC Black Theatre Festival, and by the Atlanta Black Theatre Festival to perform.  In June and October of 2014 the cast and crew will travel to D.C. not only to perform our show, but to represent dreamers, independent artists, urban theatre, and the theatrical arts of Lafayette, of Acadiana, and of Louisiana amongst a diverse line up of plays from places like  New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia, and London, England to name a few. 

This is a huge opportunity for an independent artist from a small country town; doing plays in the local theatre, but it is also a huge expense for an independent artist from a small country town that does plays at the local theatre. 

Our focus is the D.C. festival as it takes place sooner.
 

The estimated expense to take and perform She Still Dreams in D.C. is around $10,000. 

Our goal for this fundraiser is $2,000.  We’re hoping to raise 20% of our estimated expense if not more through this indiegogo campaign. 

So to all of the dreamers, fellow artists, good Samaritans, art lovers, fellow Louisianans, people of Acadiana, family, friends, and whoever it may be that stumbles across this….PLEASE SUPPORT US.  PLEASE SUPPORT SHE STILL DREAMS GOING TO DC!


The Cost

Your contributions of support will help towards the cost of the following:

  • The Theatre Venue (estimated $1,700)
  • Our Travel: (estimated $1,500)
  • Lodging: (estimated $5,000)
  • Food: (estimated $2,000)
These estimates are based off of costs for 15 people, 6 days, and 4 performances.


The Perks

Our perks are different ways of saying THANK YOU for your support and donation. 

$5 - Facebook Shout Out

$25 - Letter of Thanks + The Previous

$45 - Have your name featured on our website for special recognition + The Previous

$50 - Have your picture featured on our website for special recognition + The Previous

$55 - Have your name featured in program for special recognition + The Previous

$60 - Have your picture featured in program for special recognition + The Previous

$65 - Have your name displayed on a sign for special recognition at the DC Performances + The Previous

$75 - Have your picture displayed on a sign for special recognition at the DC Performances + The Previous

$100 - She Still Dreams DVD + The Previous

$105 - Signed cast picture with DVD + The Previous

$125 - She Still Dreams T-Shirt + The Previous

$130 - I Support Plays By Brian Egland T-Shirt + The Previous

$150 - Sugar Peach Package (Includes recipe and ingredients to make cookies used in premiere performances) + The Previous

$250 - Special Thank You Phone Call By Cast to You from D.C. + The Previous

$500 or More - Official Certificate of Support + The Previous


The Story


She Still Dreams is the story of dreaming from a small town.  There’s the person that stayed, Savannah.  Now she’s a Louisiana woman with a very empty life; a housewife, with no kids, and a husband,Russell, that does not talk.  She tries to make the best of a bad situation, but truly she doesn’t believe that there is more for her than what she already has.  So she spends her days baking and waiting for visits from her best friend, Etta Mae.  Then there’s the person that left, Jethro, who returns upon the death of his father.  He seeks comfort and shelter with Savannah, his High school sweetheart, but is confused as to why she lives the life she lives.  So what happens when you don’t choose love?  When you’re not brave enough to follow your dreams?  What happens if you are?  And when all the dreams come true, you’ve been fulfilled, and you’ve been happy, what left is there?  Do you live in a constant world of bliss?  Or do you still dream?

The show stars ULL theatre students Missi Shepherd and M.J. Battley, BET’s Sunday’s Best finalist, Nebu Neezy, and Billboard Hip Hop Award honored recording artist Jru Starz.  


The Producer, Director, Playwright

Brian is a twenty six year old native of Breaux Bridge, LA that holds a BFA in Performing Arts from the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, graduated as The Outstanding Graduate, and was honored by the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival for Excellence in Original Playwriting.  As a Director and Playwright Brian’s works include: The Birthday Dinner, A Window in the Kitchen, Coping, and Ragin on Stage developed for ULL’s Orientation Program.  As an actor Brian’s works include: Jitney, Nyetta Meaux’s Love Can’t Be Real, Mississippi in the Face of Emmett Till, The Exonerated, The Laramie Project, How I Learned to Drive, The Mystery of Edwin Drood, and In His Grace.


The Cast


Missi B. Shepherd    Jru Starz      M.J. Battley       Nebu Nezey



The Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation you can still support us by:

  • Helping to spread the word of the She Still Dreams DC donation campaign through word of mouth, email, facebook, twitter, instagram, vine, or anyway you can.
  • Donation of craft or skill if you happen to have a useful craft or skill you can provide to us for our performance, travel, or stay in D.C.
  • Prayer and Positive thought sent our way!


For More Information Visit

www.PlaysByBrianEgland.com

story:
3 Visions 3 Voices 1 Experience

Elisa Monte, Jacqulyn Buglisi, Jennifer Muller: We are distinctly different choreographers, yet we share a sensibility of creating work that combines virtuosic movement with an expressive edge that touches the heart – work that dances “full out” yet speaks of individual experiences and shared humanity. On June 18-21, 2014, we will come together at New York Live Arts in a rare opportunity to view in one presentation the works of three female choreographers whose careers span more than four decades.

3 choreographers | 5 works | 3 world premieres |12 artistic collaborators | 35 dancers | 1 program

We are exploring what we believe is a dynamic and inclusive new model to attract not only our existing audiences, but also introduce new audiences to what each of us does.  And so we are very excited to bring to you Monte/Buglisi/ Muller Live!

Collaboration

Our collaboration - Elisa Monte Dance, Buglisi Dance Theatre and Jennifer Muller/The Works - represents a vision that we share and a passionate belief in community.  Only in live performance can we continue the human exchange between artist and audience.

Buglisi Dance Theatre Photo by Kristin Lodoen Linder

Why Come Together?

We are proud of the rich artistic legacy that each of us carries, and we have a hopeful expectation that this kind of collaboration can support new creations and at the same time preserve our existing repertoire while continuing to expand the audience reach for contemporary dance. 

The strength of our work comes from our dedication to such an exchange. Our decades-long commitment to exploration and creativity has enabled us to produce works that continue to push the boundaries of art in our field.

The economic crisis that continues to impact the arts has opened our minds up to finding a new way to produce such works by pooling our finances and sharing our resources. It is becoming increasingly challenging for dance companies to present performance seasons on stretched budgets. Once you consider rehearsal costs, production and marketing expenses, theater rentals, designers and technical crews, ticket sales do not cover costs.

Elisa Monte Dance Photo by Matthew Murphy

Is Your Collaboration Strictly a Money-Saving Effort?

No.  Jacqulyn Buglisi, Artistic Director of Buglisi Dance Theatre, published an article in Dance/USA E-Journal in 2011, titled “Growing Through Collaboration: Finding Balance in a Shifting Landscape.”  In the article, she shares, "collaboration may generate energy; ignite relationships that build trust, further knowledge and group effort that continue to infuse the creative process."  We are most interested in ideas like this – in the value that coming together as artists brings to our work and to audiences in the spirit of education and exchange. We are also encouraged by the ability to share the financial burden of performances and by the support we receive from each other to make the performances possible without losing our artistic voices or the theatrical integrity of our work.   


Jennifer Muller/The Works Photo by  Carol Rosegg

Where is My Contribution Going?

Your contribution benefits not one but THREE dance companies, enabling us all to show our work live on stage. The nucleus of our work is live performance and that core makes everything else possible from touring to community outreach and arts-in-education programs. You, too, are a participant in making that cycle happen. The energy of live performance is one of the greatest forms of inspiration. It all starts June 18 at New York Live Arts. 

Fund us Forward

Thank you to all who have supported us so far.  We are excited to see where our collaboration is going and to share it with you.  

We are committed to keeping ticket prices affordable and accessible for our audiences.  In the spirit of collaboration, we ask you to help us reach our goal. 

We are coming to you with $6,300 left to raise.  Please consider even a small contribution.  A little goes a long way when we all come together.  Join us in making our collective creativity possible and in seeing where collaboration takes us next.

We are so grateful for your support. Thank you for giving!

Please give now to take full advantage of our thank you rewards!

community outreach and arts-in-education programs. You, too, are a participant
in making that cycle happen. The energy of live performance is one of the
greatest forms of inspiration. It all starts June 18 at New York Live
Arts. Fund us ForwardThank you to all who have supported us so far.  We are excited to see where our collaboration is going and to share it with you.  We are committed to keeping ticket prices affordable and accessible for our audiences.  In the spirit of collaboration, we ask you to help us reach our goal. We are coming to you with $6,300 left to raise.  Please consider even a small contribution.  A little goes a long way when we all come together.  Join us in making our collective creativity possible and in seeing where collaboration takes us next.We are so grateful for your support. Thank you for giving!Please give now to take full advantage of our thank you rewards!

story:
Join over a hundred Bay Area writers, directors, actors, and fine artists to become a part of one of San Francisco's most exciting new theater festivals! 

Who are you?

The San Francisco Olympians Festival is an annual event that lasts for twelve nights (thirteen, if you count our opening party!) with a focus on the creation of new scripts for the theater in addition to providing a showcase for Bay Area fine artists, actors and writers.

The Festival was started in 2010 by Stuart Bousel, and featured 12 new full length plays, each one based on one of the twelve Olympian gods of Ancient Greece. In 2011 the festival returned with 32 plays, ranging from five minute shorts to full lengths, each one based upon an Ancient Greek sky god or mythical figure who had become a constellation, moon, etc. In 2012 we debuted 25 one acts, each night pitting a play about an Olympian god against a play about a Titan, the race of gods who sired the Olympian gods, and were then overthrown by them. Last year we premiered 36 new plays about the Trojan War.

This year we are excited to premiere 28 new plays by 30 local writers- 13 of whom will be contributing written work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one acts to full lengths, and each one explores a different monster. It will play 12 nights, November 5-22, at the EXIT Theatre in San Francisco, and if previous years are indicative of a trend, (every year we've broken our own records), we expect this to be the largest festival yet in terms of participants and audience!

Why do you need so much money?

Well, a bigger festival requires a bigger base of support, but we're actually tightening our budget and asking for the same amount as last year- even though the cost of creating a theater festival has, like everything else in the world, gone up. We're looking to raise $10,000- a really big number- because:

  • $3,600 of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! The rest of the money we raise is split two ways...
  • The first half goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party, and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.
  • The second half goes towards maintaining last year's lofty goal of paying everyone who works on the festival a stipend of some kind. In previous years actors and writers were paid, and we held raffles to raise some funds for the artists, but our entire production team and crew, including our box office manager and all of our directors, were volunteers. Last year we changed that by creating enough funds to offer everyone a small thank you for the hours, days and weeks they put into this project. If we meet our goal, we'll be able to do this again, and maybe even have enough left over to put some money away for next year- something we've never been able to do!

Most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low and our comp policy generous, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.

Okay, but why should I support you?

When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 30 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use, a dozen directors, and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival, and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts nationally, and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.

The San Francisco Olympians Festival has been gaining momentum since its first year, with eight plays that were first given a public reading in the festival having gone on to full productions: 2010’s Hermes (No Nude Men Productions, Dramaworks, Bread and Water Theatre), Juno En Victoria (Wily West Productions), and Salty Towers (Thunderbird Theater Company); 2011’s Cassiopeia (Eat Street Players), Chronus (Bread and Water Theatre), You’re Going To Bleed (DivaFest), and Pleiades (No Nude Men Productions); 2013's Take Me Home: a One-woman Odyssey (Lucy Tafler Presents)- soon to make its international debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival! Many others have received additional readings on local and national stages, including: 2011’s Joe Ryan (Impact Theatre), Pleiades (Atlantic Stage), Io (Eat Street Players), and Selene, or Someone Like The Moon (EXIT Theatre); 2012’s Caenis and Poseidon (Playwrights’ Center of San Francisco), and Twins (San Francisco State); 2013's Under The Gods' Golden Cleets (Dramatist Guild). 2013's Walls Of Troy was a finalist for the Stanley Drama Award and the entire festival won "Playwriting Series Most Likely to Win a Gold Medal" from the SF Guardian. Additionally, EXIT Press has released a collection of five plays from year one of the festival, Songs of Hestia, and ten plays from year two, Heavenly Bodies, now available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. So when you support our festival you're also supporting American Theater, Literature and Art, and adding to the cultural heritage of generations of artists and audience yet to come!

Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow!

Find out more about the festival at www.sfolympians.com.

story:
Presents the US Premier of...

The devastating true story of the working class of 1913 Dublin who rose up to fight their wealthy oppressors, sacrificing everything to break free from the shackles of poverty. LOCKOUT stirs with live music, Irish ballads and a percussive sound-scape.



We honor stories that engage us in an emotional and cerebral way to inspire conversation about social equality, including sex, race, religion, as well as civic duty and personal responsibility. Encompassing new works, re-imagined classics and multi-disciplinary projects incorporating music and dance we will bring to the community stories that inspire us, haunt us, demand of us, and, in some small way, change us, finding a way to humanize us all. 


We are presenting two shows at the Hollywood Fringe this year; LOCKOUT and REBORNING. The two one-acts will be performed back to back on Saturdays, June 14, 21 and 28 at 8:15 and 9:15pm. Preview on Sunday June 8 at 3:15 and 4:15pm.


Hollywood Fringe 2014 link for LOCKOUT:

 http://hollywoodfringe.org/projects/1838

 Hollywood Fringe 2014 link for REBORNING"

http://hollywoodfringe.org/projects/1839


Hollywood FRINGE 2013 

Last year at Fringe, our production, "APERTURE" garnered us three nominations for Best Production, Best Actress for Bridgette Campbell and Best Writing for Jesse Janzen, as well as multiple sold out performances.  In an effort to surpass last year's successes, we're doing a bit of fundraising to raise the production values. We are also on the path to make Curious Beast Theatre Co. a non-profit, so that all donations made will be tax-deductible, and we will then be eligible for grants and community outreach. We will keep everyone informed of that progress.


OUR GOAL AND BUDGET:

  • Fringe Entry Fee:  250
  • McCadden Theatre Rental: 800
  • Insurance: 75
  • Projector: 150
  • Marketing: 250
  • Sets: 175
  • Costumes: 225
  • Musicians: 300
  • Rights to "Lockout:" 300
  • Printing: 100
  • Getting Ms. Matthews to a studio in Dublin for an interview on KCRW: 150
  • TOTAL: 2775

We are happy to announce that The Village Idiot and Sal's Restaurant and Comedy Club, both wonderful neighborhood restaurants on Melrose Ave in West Hollywood, and The Irish Import Shop on Vine St. have all donated to our production.  Please honor them with your patronage!

 TICKETS AND PERKS

We offer you different levels of giving and honor Ireland's greatest:

Tickets at the door cost $16.  So on indie go go each level gets you a ticket/s and a different perk.

St. Brigid of Kildare: $5 We will light a candle for you.

Just the Ticket Please: $16 One ticket to LOCKOUT any night you choose.

Kenneth Branagh: $20, that'll be one ticket to LOCKOUT plus a $4 donation to LOCKOUT.

Oscar Wilde: $40, $32 for two tickets to LOCKOUT and $8 donation to LOCKOUT.

Samuel Beckett: $50, we'll throw in two free drinks at the show. That's two tickets and two drinks.

Sean O' Casey: $75 gets you two tickets to "LOCKOUT" and two tickets to "REBORNING"

James Joyce: $100 gets you two tickets to both shows, LOCKOUT and REBORNING with prime reserved seats (which is great if you're a person who runs late and always has to settle for whatever's left :-)), plus two drinks at the theatre.

W.B. Yeats: $150 gets you two tickets to both shows LOCKOUT and REBORNING with prime reserved seats, two drinks at the theatre, a Curious Beast t-shirt and a bottle of Irish whiskey or a tin box of Irish tea, depending on your tastes. 

St. Patrick: $500 all of the above plus your reward in heaven.

And you can double any of these level for FOUR tickets. 

And if you don't live in LA or can't make the show, we will send you a t-shirt for any donation $25 and up.  $100 and up gets you a bottle of Irish whiskey or Irish tea and shortbread!

The Village Idiot has generously sponsored our t-shirt costs!

Once you buy a ticket please include the night you'd like to come in your comments.


The Impact

In this time of growing animosity toward trade unions, it is all the more important to discuss and remember the hardships endured by the early trade unionist. The 1913 lockout is a critical juncture in that historical conflict, providing a compelling setting for drama, which Ms. Matthews utilizes effectively in creating an engaging theater experience. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our show and forward our campaign to anyone you think might be interested. And if it's not in your budget to donate right now, please let us know if you would like to help out during the performances.  We need volunteers for Front of House, Box office, Load In/Load Out. You can see the show for free if you volunteer!

Curious Beast Theatre Co. is also presenting REBORNING immediately following LOCKOUT at McCadden Place Theatre at 9:15.

Thanks to everyone for your support from all of us at Curious Beast; 

From Left; Christopher Wallinger, Managing Director, Jaimie Boabley, Co-Artistic Director, Spark O' Connell, Marketing Director and Bridgette Campbell, Co-Artistic Director

We can't wait to see you at Lockout and Reborning Fringe 2014!

story:
THE UGA RED HOTZ WANT TO TAKE NATIONALS BY STORM!

The UGA Red Hotz are one of the University of Georgia's best kept secrets. We are a completely student ran dance team. We get a small amount of funding from our school and the rest is up to us! This year, we want to be taken seriously. We don't want to just compete at Nationals, we want to be considered competition. In order to be competitive you need to have the funds to do so. The funds we raise will go towards our costumes, choreography, and travel expenses. 

We have something to prove; to ourselves, to our school, and to our peers. We are more than just a club sports dance team. We are athletes. We train like athletes, and want to be treated like athletes. 

We worked extremely hard this past year to go to nationals with a great routine and we succeeded. Next year we want to work even harder. We want to surprise everyone. In order to do so we have to start the year out with nationals on our mind. We have elite judges coming in to our auditions, we are taking extra classes in order to up our technique, and we are working closely with our choreographer who knows everything there is to know about nationals and the kind of dancers we need to be to succeed at nationals. 

"DO IT WITH PASSION OR NOT AT ALL"


  • http://rossmade.mynmi.net/publish_to_web/soundslider.swf

Check out this video one of our dancers made to get to know us a little better. This video was made before going to nationals this past year!

story:
MELODY NELSON

MELODY NELSON was originally developed as an intergenerational community dance piece for NextFest NW at Velocity Dance Center in Seattle, WA.  We responded to Serge Gainsbourg’s story album Historie de Melody Nelson, about an older man in love with an ill-fated teenage girl. What we developed was a psychedelic performance piece about .
MELODY is currently in development to expand the piece to 60 minutes for a show on July 12th at Velocity Dance Center. The evening will include two performances, each featuring our ensemble and an intergenerational community group.  
MELODY is built, performed, produced, designed, and documented by working artists.  We are raising funds to compensate them. We wish to determine fees for their time at a rate at least that of the state hourly minimum wage. 

THE NEED

In order to insure that the performers, designers, and documentarians are paid for their time, we need $1100. 

(Large donations may be tax deductible. Email melodynelsonperformance@gmail.com for more information)

OUR APPRECIATION

We are offering signed posters, dvd's, and tickets to our show as tokens of our appreciation.  Of course we will appreciate any donation, however small. It is our mission to create stories for you. 

OUR HOPE

By creating a community from broad locations and staggering ticket prices, we hope to diversify the audience and the performers that might normally be present at a dance-theater event.  Ideally, this would result in strategic alliances between artistic, educational and social service organizations. 

By accomplishing a complex and ridiculous task, such as is performance, we believe things may be seen differently.  

HELP US

If you can contribute at all, we would dearly appreciate it.
Please, share this with your friends as well.

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Funding our project will help us with the following: 

  • Booking affordable rehearsal space for our cast and our film crew to practice staging the production.
  • Any donation amount will help us obtain period costumes and our desired film equipment and set pieces for the performances. 
  • Helping pay our amazing designer, creators, actors and film crew personnel living wages!
  • We will thank all supporters of our production with producer credits in our Mabou Mines programs. See our amazing perks for more details. 

The Impact

  • Your support will bring a diverse set of theatremakers and filmmakers to the NYC stage. A rarity in today's age and that our team and production are desperately trying to change.
  • Supporting this work means standing with representation of marginalized peoples in the arts especially Asian-Americans. 
  • Come find us as part of the SUITE/SPACE program at Mabou Mines. Our performance space and venue is set, we just need your support to help us get there.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't contribute at this time we would still love to see you at the show! You can get tickets at the link posted directly below. 
  • https://ci.ovationtix.com/3092 

Short Summary

The Actress Who Died a Thousand Deaths utilizes ‘live cinema theater’ to both recreate and reimagine moments from actress, Anna May Wong’s films during the Hollywood Golden Age (1930s) and life; to subvert type-casted and Orientalist tropes of the original and offer a ‘re-framing’ on stage. Your support will help bring a voice that history has largely marginalized and celebrate its truth onstage and on the screen simultaneously. This production is being brought to life through the help of companies Rebel Motion and AC Productions. 

The Team

Cinthia Chen is a Taiwanese American interdisciplinary artist, working mainly in film and theater. In film she has worked extensively in production design, editing, and has been involved in projects with Five Sisters Productions and ARRI China. Chen has trained in kunqu opera under the London Jing Kun Opera Association, and Japanese noh theater through the Kyoto Arts Center with the Kanze School of Noh. She seeks to integrate traditional art forms with new mediums to explore stories pertaining to cultural memory.

Ben Haven Taylor, Video Direction

Alex Cadena, Producer

Grace Chan, Producer

story:
Deeper, Still is an interdisciplinary movement-theater work that illuminates our inner mysteries using old folk songs, mythological metaphor, and legends of the ocean. Through movement and mystical narrative, it reveals an individual’s efforts to reconcile with the self—shadow, creature, and all.

 

+++++++

 

I'm Jordan Saenz, a movement artist and choreographer based in Los Angeles. I've been dancing and making work professionally for the past few years, and this will be the first time I make something of this scale by integrating all aspects of my art-making. This project began as an obsession with aquatic life, which turned into a love affair with oceanic mythology, mysticism, and tarot. While entrenched in this material, I wrote a series of poems—essentially a myth of my own—and wondered how they might translate to the theater.

So I've teamed up with musician/composer Heather Lockie to create a physical adaptation of these poems.  We scavenged and compiled traditional folk songs about journeying and transformation. (Heather is somewhat of a life-time folk song collector, with binders full of old tunes about the sea, love, longing, and death.) The songs that called to us helped construct a map—segments that would tell the story in a collage of movement and imagery. 

We've been asked to show excerpts of the piece in the coming months as it develops, which is exciting! However, the lifespan of this work requires funding in these early stages—more than is currently available. In order to pursue opportunities to show Deeper, Still  in its entirety, preliminary showings need to represent the full scope of this work's potential. That means raising funds not only for professional-level lighting design, film documentation, rehearsal space and costuming, but also compensation for collaborators and performers.

 

++++++

 

With sufficient funding, we'll be able to get this project off the ground. 

$1,000 — Space — We will be able to pay for a rehearsal space that can accommodate our needs.  We want the dancers to work in a bigger space with sprung floors!

$2,500 — Collaborators — All collaborators and performers deserve compensation for their time in the process. They're the ones who'll be bringing this to life after all!

$500 — Video — Professional video documentation will allow us to submit this work to festivals and seek more performance opportunities.  It will also allow us to submit to an appropriate venue to show the work as an evening-length event.

$1,000 — Design — The right costuming, lighting, and set pieces make a world of difference.

 

++++++

 

With your help, the work will have longevity. It will grant us the time and resources to continue this sacred process we've been sharing. It will also allow us to share the work through more avenues, via contributor perks. 

Contributors will receive music downloads, poems, tarot card pulls, as well as inside footage and writings about the work and our process.  

The work illustrates themes of the inner shadow, integration of the feminine and masculine, water, nature, aquatic life, emotional alchemy, transformation, and spiritual awakening. Themes I believe to be prominent at this time.  Working on this project has been a truly healing and insightful experience, and we hope that resonates with you as well.

Thank you so much for your support!

 

++++++

 

***First showing: March 29-30, 2019 at Highways Performance Space, Santa Monica, CA***

 

Artists:

Heather Lockie (musician/composer)

Ariana Daub (dancer)

Nicole Nistal (dancer)

Amir Rappaport (dancer)

Alyson Van (dancer)

Brian Saia (musician)

Clay Chaplin (musician)

Laura Steenberge (musician)

story:
We are pleased to announce The Denizens Theater Company’s first production, "Savage in Limbo",  a concert play by John Patrick Shanley. We will be partnering with the design team of For The People NYC, a team of artists putting talent to work and bringing the Brooklyn artistic community together with custom, creative events. As production is underway and we begin rehearsals, we are reaching out to ask that you consider a donation to our project.

Our production will run January 5th, 6th, and 7th, 2018. The setting is a slightly seedy neighborhood bar in the Bronx, where a group of regulars (who all happen to be the same age—thirty-two) seeks relief from the disappointments and tedium of the outside world. Denise Savage, is desperate to get out of the limbo of loneliness from which she cannot seem to escape. 

 Our production cannot happen without the help of our friends; anything you might have to offer would directly lend to bringing these characters’ story to the stage. 

Your support means the world to us!

story:
What We Want

TO BE THE MOST EXCITING, MOST ADVENTUROUS FESTIVAL IN THE SOUTH.
We're almost through our growing pains. These are the goals this year:

  • PRINTING COSTS (schedule of events, posters, postcards & flyers) $2600
  • TECH EQUIPMENT (for venues that aren't full-time theatres) $600
  • VENUE MANAGER SALARY (the Fest weekend is a big job) $2400
  • SOCIAL MEDIA & WEBSITE MANAGEMENT $800
  • ORIGINAL ARTWORK $400
  • SANDWICH BOARDS (for every venue) $400
  • MISCELLANEOUS (the dreaded miscellaneous) $600

InFringe Fest is a community event as well as an artistic one. We keep it as easy-to-access for artists as we can: The (refundable) application fee is a mere $25. The shows get 60% of the door, the venue 20%, the Fest 20%. Ticket prices everywhere except the BYOVs is only $10, and a full-weekend pass (including the BYOVs) is only $100.

 

What You Get

We'll be adding beautiful or practical donor perks - or beautiful AND practical - to this campaign on a daily basis. (Also details about the shows you can expect to see.) But we know that the main reason you might be moved to contribute is because you love live performance, or New Orleans, or your friends who are involved, or all of the above. A contribution to an event like InFringe Fest is, ultimately, a matter of the heart.
We thank you for that. We love you too.

If You Just Can't Contribute? We Understand.

You know the drill. Share this online. Tell your friends. Wish us well.
COME TO A SHOW.

If We Don't Reach Our Goal? Onward!

If you have any questions, contact me directly at cloveproductions@gmail.com.

Best regards,
Michael Martin
Co-Founder
Director of Artist Relations

story:
Short Summary

We are a company founded in a pandemic with the intention of keeping live theater and classic texts available and accessible to all. For our first production, we are returning to the roots of remote theater with an episodic radio drama based on L.M. Montgomery's novel Anne of Green Gables.  With an original adaptation designed for radio, and a small but mighty cast, we aim to bring to life this timeless story of a fiery, idealistic girl and the community that she finds in Avonlea. You can listen to the trailer now on Spotify. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our main goal in fundraising is to cover labor costs. We believe that artists, like any other profession, should be paid for their work. In addition, we want to ensure good quality sound for the project, so we need funding to get our actors any necessary recording equipment, as well as cover labor for audio editing. We are still a small company, and our budget is reflected proportionally, but we are looking to grow in the future and any excess funds will be used to produce more theater that is accessible for all.

In exchange for your donation, we have a range of ways to show our gratitude:

  • For $5, receive a personalized shout out in our virtual playbill
  • For $10, we will add a video message from one of our cast members
  • For $25, you will also be sent a small themed gift to enjoy along with the performance

Risks & Challenges

We recognize that we will be tackling a monumental amount of audio editing, and compiling tracks recorded in completely different environments as our actors are all recording remotely in their own homes. However, our team is committed to taking the time and care needed to ensure a quality final product, drawing on expert help as needed.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, please help us get the word out about the project! And tune in when episodes are released. Theater isn't theater without an audience!

Also, feel free to check out our website (www.inkblottheaterco.com) for more information about our educational programming and other projects that are currently in development.

story:
WE MADE IT!!

Thank you for supporting us, and for helping us reach our goal. Please join us in the Park, at 59E59 and in Edinburgh, Scotland!

 

####################

 

Elephant Run District’s Transatlantic Summer Season

Elephant Run District is thrilled to present our Transatlantic Summer Season!

Now in our fourth year, we create theater that entertains our audience, while addressing important social issues. This summer is no different. So far, the New York Times has called our work “unexpectedly poignant”, NYTheatre.com terms us “polished, professional and entertaining… the kind of theatre I love best” and Cultural Capitol declares us “flawless.”

Elephant Run District is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. Your contribution is tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.  

This summer, we are producing: 

Brecht in the Park:

This summer, we will produce three rarely performed one acts by Bertolt Brecht: The Elephant Calf (1926), In Search of Justice (1938) and The Exception and the Rule (1929). The plays, two of which have never been produced in New York City before, will be performed for free near Central Park’s Great Hill. Using puppetry and masks, we will connect these three plays with modern day issues of Occupy Movement, Citizens United, Stop & Frisk and Stand Your Ground gun laws. It’s a public service to New York City, and we want you there.

 

American Gun Show: 

 

After a wildly-successful run at the FRIGID New York Festival (under the title Two Lovely Black Eyes), we are honored to bring American Gun Show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. This solo (sorta) comedy about gun violence offers a nuanced and human view of American gun culture. We hope to be ambassadors for a different view of American gun culture than the world often sees – one that is more complicated than gun-huggers versus peace-mongers. We hope you’ll join our vision!

 

What We Need:

We’re extremely excited to announce a “moral support” grant from the Yip Harburg Foundation! Their funds, as well as some private donations, have given us a boost, but we still have a ways to go.

Your contributions will go towards:

  • Artist Fees – Elephant Run District is committed to paying artists for their work. We always provide stipends for all actors, directors, designers and stage managers involved in our projects. It is one of our largest production costs.
  • Masks and Puppets – Brecht in the Park will include masks and puppets designed by NYIT Award-winning (and soon-to-be War Horse tour performer) Joe Osheroff.
  • Rehearsal Space – Both Brecht in the Park and American Gun Show need to rehearse somewhere! While we are frugal and smart about this, we occasionally have to plop down cash.
  • Transportation – We gotta fly Chris and Heather over to Edinburgh to make American Gun Show happen! Airlines charge an arm and a leg, so could you give us a hand?
  • Performance space in Edinburgh – Our new friends at the Gryphon Venues gave us a great performing space in the center of town. It’s a hot venue that produces winning shows, filled with young talent and the spirit of the Edinburgh Fringe. But that does come at a cost. 
  • The flat  – It will cost twice what it costs to live in New York for a month to be in Edinburgh for 25 days. 

 

The Impact:

Our season is a call to action, both in our city, our country and our world. Brecht in the Park is a public service to all New York City residents, and will rekindle discussion about Stop and Frisk, Occupy, Citizens United and Stand Your Ground laws. American Gun Show brings a human face and moderated view of American gun culture to a worldwide population. Our season spans the local to the global, and will shake up (and wake up) our audiences. Come be a part of that!

 

Other Ways You Can Help: 

PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!! Please share information about our seasons with your Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and other social media site followers! "Like" us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, subscribe to us on YouTube! #joinourherd, #brechtinthepark, #americangunshow, #edfringe

Our Companies:

Brecht in the Park 

Ethan Angelica - Ron Dizon - Mel House - Rebecca Nyahay - Mike Perrie Jr. - Jenny Tibbels-Jordan

Director: Aimee Todoroff, Assistant Director: Lacy Reily, Stage Manager: Heather Olmstead, Musical Director/Composer: Mike Perrie Jr., Mask & Additional Design: Joe Osheroff, Casting Director: Jackie Sydney, Translations: Eric Bentley

American Gun Show

Chris Harcum - Heather Olmstead

Director: Aimee Todoroff, Author: Chris Harcum, Stage Manager: Heather Olmstead

Masks and Puppets – Brecht in the Park will include masks and puppets designed by NYIT Award-winning (and soon-to-be War Horse tour performer) Joe Osheroff.

Rehearsal Space – Both Brecht in the Park and American Gun Show need to rehearse somewhere! While we are frugal and smart about this, we occasionally have to plop down cash.

Transportation – We gotta fly Chris and Heather over to Edinburgh to make American Gun Show happen! Airlines charge an arm and a leg, so could you give us a hand?

Performance space in Edinburgh – Our new friends at the Gryphon Venues gave us a great performing space in the center of town. It’s a hot venue that produces winning shows, filled with young talent and the spirit of the Edinburgh Fringe. But that does come at a cost. 

The flat  – It will cost twice what it costs to live in New York for a month to be in Edinburgh for 25 days. 
 
The Impact:

Our season is a call to action, both in our city, our country and our world. Brecht in the Park is a public service to all New York City residents, and will rekindle discussion about Stop and Frisk, Occupy, Citizens United and Stand Your Ground laws. American Gun Show brings a human face and moderated view of American gun culture to a worldwide population. Our season spans the local to the global, and will shake up (and wake up) our audiences. Come be a part of that!
 

Other Ways You Can Help: 


PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!! Please share information about our seasons with your Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and other social media site followers! "Like" us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, subscribe to us on YouTube! #joinourherd, #brechtinthepark, #americangunshow, #edfringe
Our Companies:

Brecht in the Park 

Ethan Angelica - Ron Dizon - Mel House - Rebecca Nyahay - Mike Perrie Jr. - Jenny Tibbels-Jordan
Director: Aimee Todoroff, Assistant Director: Lacy Reily, Stage Manager: Heather Olmstead, Musical Director/Composer: Mike Perrie Jr., Mask & Additional Design: Joe Osheroff, Casting Director: Jackie Sydney, Translations: Eric Bentley
American Gun Show
Chris Harcum - Heather Olmstead
Director: Aimee Todoroff, Author: Chris Harcum, Stage Manager: Heather Olmstead

story:
Our Story

Zachari Productions is thrilled to be invited back to the New York International Fringe Festival with a brand new script by Peter Zachari called the THE 3RD GENDER. 

THE 3RD GENDER is a futuristic, sci-fi allegory set in the year 2397 that finds Manten, a twenty year old “straight” amnesiac struggling to find his existence in a world now ruled by an elevated group of spiritual beings that live in the intermediate state between man and woman. This group is known as “The 3rd Gender” and the world no longer allows heteronormatives like Manten to be born. His escape from being “eliminated” forces him on a journey to rediscover his existence in an unfamiliar world that both rejects and haunts him. 

And now we have been selected to premiere our show at The New York International Fringe Festival.  (www.fringenyc.org) We are thrilled to have this fantastic opportunity to bring these characters to New York City, and now we need your help. 

We Need Your Help!

We need to mount a production of this complete with costume, sound, props, publicity, the works. Your donation to this project will help make this dream of ours a reality. By contributing money to this project, you are helping the artists associated with this project to see an original production come to fruition. We have set our goal at $4000 but if we reach that, please keep giving! Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. 

Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us. Visit our Facebook page (www.facebook.com/TheThirdGender). And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.

Peter Zachari (Playwright/Lyrics) most recent show, Fat Asses: The Musical was presented at Theater for the New City this past Spring. In 2011, his musical Parker & Dizzys Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow was presented at The New York International Fringe Festival as well as the Encores Series. Peter has also written Lighten Up!, which was produced off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!, Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, and One Love. Mr. Zacharis directing credits include Fat Asses: The Musical, Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow, Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, West Side Story, Theyre Playing Our Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo .  As an actor, his New York credits include Street Scene (The York Theatre Company), Connections (Actors Theatre of America), 1940s Radio Hour (The Emelin Theatre), The All-Male Importance of Being Earnest (New York International Fringe Festival), and Happy Hour (The Producers Club).  Regional credits include Loves Labours Lost (Huntington), The Illusion, All in the Timing, Laughter on the 23rd Floor, A Christmas Carol and 4R Planet (Hippodrome State Theatre); Big River and Young Abe Lincoln (Lincoln Amphitheatre); A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Last of the Red Hot Lovers, Mary, Mary (Summer Theatre at Salem); The Flatlanders (Dollywood) and Fiddler on the Roof and Cabaret(Center for the Performing Arts, Gainesville).  His television credits include White Collar, As the World Turns, The Life of Lizzie Borden, and Half Empty.  He received his M.F.A. from the University of Florida and his B.F.A. from Salem State College. 

About FringeNYC

The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues. FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like "Urinetown" and "Silence: The Musical." When accepted to participate, it gives untested writers/performers a chance to put their work up at some of the city's best Off-Broadway and Off-Off Broadway venues.

story:
What is "Antony & Cleopatra: Infinite Lives"?

Antony & Cleopatra: Infinite Lives is a new play by J. Michael DeAngelis & Pete Barry, incorporating original text by William Shakespeare.  It's the story of  an Egyptian expatriate who gets caught between two revolutionaries - her fiancée, an activist director who tries to upend his commissioned Shakespeare production, and her brother, a nationalist fresh from the violence of Tahrir Square.
 
Drawn from still developing current events, this original play juxtaposes today's Egypt alongside Cleopatra's Egypt as seen by Shakespeare.  It puts a spotlight on theater as historical record and questions the role of the artist in politics.
 

WAIT A MINUTE - I'M HAVING DEJA VU!

That's right.  Last year, thanks to the help of our many supporters, we produced Infinite Lives at the Penn Museum as part of the 2012 Philly Fringe.  Now, we have been selected from hundreds of appliciants to do it all again...at the New York International Fringe Festival.

We have an amazing cast and an icredible performing space at the Lynn Redgrave Theater.

 
Our show times are as follows:
Saturday 8/10 @ 9pm
Sunday 8/11 @ 2pm
Friday 8/16 @ 9:30pm
Sunday 8/18 @ 4:45pm
Sunday 8/25 @ 12noon
 
 
The play is being produced as part of the 2013 FringeNYC by The Porch Room, an award-winning independent theater company.  Authors J. Michael DeAngelis and Pete Barry are multi-award winning playwrights, whose works have been published by Samuel French and Vintage Press.  This is their third original production for the Philly Fringe, having previously presented sold-out runs of X/Yand Signs from God, which recently concluded an encore production in New York City.  Director John Dowgin is a co-founder of The Porch Room and as helmed such productions as Othello and A Few Good Men.
 

As in the original production, costume design is by Olivia Rutigliano and the show features several pieces of original music by Rebecca Kotcher, including a haunting and beautiful adapatation of Shakespeare's Sonnet #27.
 

Why We're Asking For Your Help

Producing a show on this scale presents new challenges The Porch Room.

We've set a goal of $3,000. That will ensure that all of our cast and crew's salaries can be gaurenteed without having to wait for box office results.  It also means that we can put the cash we already have on hand to good use designing and marketing this show.

Ever wanted to have a play written just for you? WE CAN MAKE THAT HAPPEN! Support us at the highest level and the boys from The Porch Room will crank out an original one-act play!

Want to know more about ancient Egypt? WE CAN MAKE THAT HAPPEN TOO! Donors at the top level can get a guided tour of the Metropolitian Museum of Art's Egyptian exhibit, lead by our archaelogy consultant, Professor Katharine Davis.

How You'll Be Helping

Your donation goes a long way towards making our show shine.  Here are just a few examples of how you'll be helping:

  • $10-$20 is a prop! Anything from a Roman sword to a clipboard to an asp!
  • $50 covers one night of rehearsal in a professional studio space.
  • $100 pays an actor's salary!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Come see the show! Purchasing a ticket not only helps financially, it's why we're here!  Let us entertain you!
  • Talk up the show to your friends and family!
  • Tweet it, Facebook it, start a debate on Reddit about it...get some word of mouth going!

story:
THE PROJECT

More often than not when we visit websites and we're asked to agree to some terms and conditions statement.  We simply check a box and click a button without thinking about it. We are allowing somebody permission to know everything about us and to use that information in whatever way they choose.  This has made me really think about the notion of privacy and how I let other people see me or what I want them to know about me.  In this day and age with so much information already being online I don't really have a choice anymore.  I can spend all day going through security settings and reading privacy statements, but if I don't agree to the terms that someone else's already laid out than likely I'm not going to be able to use those goods or services. 

Terms and conditions takes all of these ideas and puts it on the physical level. We're exploring permission, vulnerability, exposure, intimacy and invasion.  I’m not setting out to make a political work that tells us technology is bad.  I'm trying to find the essence of how these experiences make us feel and put that into a dance.  When you're done watching this performance you may feel that maybe your privacy has been invaded a little bit, maybe you'll feel really bad for somebody on stage, or maybe you'll laugh a little bit because of how extreme some of these measures are.  Hopefully you'll just think a little bit about the decisions you're making every day and how you interact with this technology that is a part of almost all of our activities.  


I'm so proud to be working with a phenomenal group of artists for this project.  There are six beautiful dancers that have been working hard for almost seven months now to put this thing together.  I'm also collaborating with lighting designer Julie Ballard and video designer Laura Wiley who are going to bring incredibly original visual elements to the show.  

The fantastic team of collaborators include:

CHOREOGRAPHER and DIRECTOR: Philip Elson 

PERFORMERS: Katie Graves, Omar Hernandez, Kameron Johnson, Matthew McMunn, James Nemecek, Gretchen Soechting 

LIGHTING DESIGNER and STAGE MANAGER: Julie Ballard

VIDEO DESIGNER and ASST STAGE MANAGER: Laura Wiley 


WHAT WE NEED 

Your contribution to terms and conditions will make all of this happen and more. It will ensure that we have a fantastic show and that we can continue this kind of work that makes a difference in how we see the world around us.  There are some fantastic rewards available for your contribution here not to mention anything that you donate towards this project is tax-deductible to the extent of the law. 

Your contributions to this work will help cover the following expenses: 

-Rehearsal Studio Rentals 

-Performance Venue Rental

-Lighting and Projection Equipment Rental 

-Costumes 

-Artist Compensation  


WHAT YOU GET 

$25 or more 

A big THANK YOU on Philip Elson Dance’s Facebook page and website and a mention in the program notes as a supporter of the project. 

$50 or more 

All of the above and a special video made just for you by Philip and the dancers. 

$75 or more 

All of the above and photo from the show signed by all the artists. 

$100 or more 

All of the above and two free tickets to see Terms and Conditions the evening of your choice. 

$150 or more 

All of the above and a DVD of the production including bonus features such as interviews with the artists. 

$300 or more 

All of the above and a dinner date with Philip and the dancers in your honor.

|||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||||

Thanks again for visiting today and I hope we’ll see you at the premiere of Terms and Conditions March 14-16 at Links Hall in Chicago. 

Visit www.philipelson.com for more information and to get tickets today!

story:
Produced by The Sally Collective and straight from Arena Theatres, Inside 130 Residency comes 

'Scapegoat.

Brand new and that's what makes us important.

Amidst the kid to adult threshold lies the half fantastical, not-quite-reality that is the mind of the twenty something year old. 

'Scapegoat drills at the here and now of Melbourne in a warehouse world where Neverland meets Footscray grit.
You meet us in this big fuck off space where Mum, Dad, Ginsberg, Saint Joan, Peter, Wendy, Alice and Montaigne become nothing more than you and me on a life sized, home built  game of Mousetrap.
Pretty simple really....

It is though! Because we are dedicated to being true-honest about what it is that's actually up. No bullshit.....Except maybe Kale. 

This is Melbourne's new generation of theatre. A fresh collective of transdisciplinary artists who have been drawn together like seedy, dirt broke but talented moths to a flame of roaring drive, ambition, danger and authenticity. Our bloods bubbling, our butterflies are chucking 360's, we are at full charge.

This is our call for your help in keeping Melbourne Theatre's respiratory system breathing in new air. To do that we have to keep supporting its new voices.
Help us show you what Melbourne's new generation of theatre is.
Between holding the supportive, clammy hands of veteran Melbourne artists that have wisdom to burn and itching to mess up massively, comes the risk of what supporting us will be.

But what's theatre without that risk? IT'S BORING and you've seen it already. 

Here's your chance to play a part in telling a new story of now, with all it's passion and bits of lovely.

And to question if Peter Pan really has left without you.


Purchase tix @ http://www.trybooking.com/Booking/BookingEventS...

Here's how you help!

Donating to us makes the show possible by contributing to the space hire. Nothing in our budget contradicts the concession-healthcare-card budget we and the characters in the piece are on. In fact, we think budgets tend to stunt innovation.

But then there was space hire. And that's something we struggle to find in a tip or borrow off a mate. This is the one thing we need help with. 

We just need to concore The Grange Space!

Other than the space we have it covered with our hospitality/ market research/ all too glamorous day jobs. Not to mention our elite level of resourcefulness.

The Space hire is a aproximately 80% of our $7,800  budget. The total space costs equates to $6,200 we need your help to raise $4,000 of that. The rest of our costs are spent on Lighting, Tech fee, Insurance, Printing and any costume/set we can't source from the Tip or Aunty Jane's back yard. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We appreciate your support in anyway possible.

    • Please share this campaign with people you know through Facebook, Twitter or any other funky internet devices you have at your service
    • Come along. We want everyone to see our production! Tickets available from www.sallycollective.com/productions/ or http://www.trybooking.com/Booking/BookingEventSummary.aspx?eid=109702

story:
Bloodbound is about the freedom to love.

In 1972—after three years immersed at Chicago’s Goodman School of Drama in stringent classes that included Speech and Voice, Fencing and Scene Study, Theater History and Musical Theater—I came to Los Angeles and was cast in the West Coast premiere of Tom Eyen’s The Dirtiest Show In Town in which I appeared in orgiastic scenes (in the nude) and scenes protesting the Vietnam war and pollution (with clothes on). After performing in that show, I perceived something that I never learned in all those years at Goodman; in all those hours upon hours devoted to the indefatigable study of the theater, I learned—simply but surely—that the theater is about the freedom to love.

Contribute to Bloodbound and you'll find out why.

It's the same team of players who brought Bang Bang to life In 2015 -- director Bringelson, Highways Performance Space, Moon Mile Run (partner Ryland Shelton) nurturing the playwright's new work. After a stunning career that encompasses acting, directing, producing, teaching and various entrepreneurial assignments in the theater (including his current Artistic Associate position at Skylight Theatre, Artistic Director of QueerWise, Founder and one of the Michael Kearns & Other Outies, and Artist-in-Residence at Housing Works, it is playwrighting that seems to have captured the artist-activist's impassioned mode of expression.

What The Critics' Said About 2017's Bang Bang

“This is a play whose writing explores the idea of the outlaw…Playwright Michael Kearns’ latest opus is like a dark funhouse ride, in which kaleidoscopic fragments of themes shift and coalesce into entirely different ideas from scene to scene…  with ferocious power. Kearns has written many plays full of character portraits, but here the characters are often left intentionally incomplete, with motivations that are subject to interpretation. This artistic choice is solid, and the haunting quality engendered by the work stays with us long after the show’s over.” 

L.A. Raw

“The collisions of sex and death, of eroticism and grief, have propelled Kearns' stage works for about 40 years, and ‘Bang Bang’, a new play at Santa Monica's Highways, provides no exception to that pattern, which is really an artistic calling. Sex is on his brain, and on his stages, while he is lamenting the loss of friends from the kinds of predilections he's striving to better comprehend.”

L.A. Weekly

“The world premiere of playwright Michael Kearns' Bang Bang will leave you stunned and loss for words. Heartrending tales of tragedy weaved together by the common denominator of a gun (hence, ‘Bang Bang’) will rip your heartstrings and possibly cause a flow of tears… Bravo to Kearns for a beautiful and meaningful script full of realistic dialogue from real, three-dimensional people.”

Broadway World

Awarded For More Than Four Decades of Trailblazing

In June of 2017, Kearns was awarded in a ceremony at ceremony at Los Angeles City Hall that kicked off the City’s seventh annual Heritage Month. Mayor Eric Garcetti, along with Councilmember Mitch O’Farrell, were among the city officials who cited Kearns, along with Alexandra Billings, Sara Ramirez and Alexei Romanoff with Trailblazer Awards. Kearns was specifically acknowledged for more than four decades of combining art and activism in a number of theatrical presentations he was attached to and a number of organizations he founded.

Kearns' trailblazing reputation included many firsts: He came out in the mid-Seventies, officially making him "Hollywood's first openly gay actor" with one foot in the mainstream industry and one foot in the alternative art world. In 1991, he revealed his HIV-positive status on Entertainment Tonight and  a few years later, he was the first HIV-positive, single, gay man to adopt. His Black daughter, he says, is "the most important force" in his life.

At the ceremony, Kearns concluded his speech with the following words:

"I don’t care if you call it “Resist” or “Pride”—it’s time to channel your inner anarchist—uh, SORRY, I mean archaeologist. Each of us needs to find a trail to blaze. Find the light within and aim it into some neighborhoods you’ve never been to; shine your light on paths untraveled and neglected. (Dare to ruin a pair of shoes, okay?)

I take this acknowledgment very seriously. Thank you, Mayor Garcetti, and Councilmember O’Farrell. I consider today’s acknowledgment a map, a blueprint for future expeditions.

This award serves as my marching papers."

The freedom to love is threatened and it's the responsibility of those of us with a voice to use it. Help amplify my voice.

Kearns’ new full length play tracks the lives of two misfit brothers who are destined to love in spite of the gnarled realities they cannot avoid sharing. By remembering their past—in some cases, reliving critical, contradictory, and conflicting moments—perhaps the horrific fear of their mutual deaths (whether in a shitty hospital bed or a sweaty prison cell) will lessen as they approach the final curtain. Just maybe, just perhaps, the brothers—or, wait, maybe you, you in the audience—maybe you will be absolved of your burdens enough (not perfectly but enough), absolved of your burdens enough, to abound into whatever the freedom of love means to you.

Please contribute whatever you can but also spread the word. We all know the power of social media in getting the message out. I appreciate your belief in me and the work I am able to churn out. It is the jolt of art and its unpredictable permutations that lead us to the freedom of love. Mk
story_txt: Bloodbound is about the freedom to love.In 1972—after three years immersed at Chicago’s Goodman School of Drama in stringent classes that included Speech and Voice, Fencing and Scene Study, Theater History and Musical Theater—I came to Los Angeles and was cast in the West Coast premiere of Tom Eyen’s The Dirtiest Show In Town in which I appeared in orgiastic scenes (in the nude) and scenes protesting the Vietnam war and pollution (with clothes on). After performing in that show, I perceived something that I never learned in all those years at Goodman; in all those hours upon hours devoted to the indefatigable study of the theater, I learned—simply but surely—that the theater is about the freedom to love.Contribute to Bloodbound and you'll find out why.It's the same team of players who brought Bang Bang to life In 2015 -- director Bringelson, Highways Performance Space, Moon Mile Run (partner Ryland Shelton) nurturing the playwright's new work. After a stunning career that encompasses acting, directing, producing, teaching and various entrepreneurial assignments in the theater (including his current Artistic Associate position at Skylight Theatre, Artistic Director of QueerWise, Founder and one of the Michael Kearns & Other Outies, and Artist-in-Residence at Housing Works, it is playwrighting that seems to have captured the artist-activist's impassioned mode of expression.What The Critics' Said About 2017's Bang Bang“This is a play whose writing explores the idea of the outlaw…Playwright Michael Kearns’ latest opus is like a dark funhouse ride, in which kaleidoscopic fragments of themes shift and coalesce into entirely different ideas from scene to scene…  with ferocious power. Kearns has written many plays full of character portraits, but here the characters are often left intentionally incomplete, with motivations that are subject to interpretation. This artistic choice is solid, and the haunting quality engendered by the work stays with us long after the show’s over.” L.A.
