story:
About Us 

Paper Balloon are Alex Kanefsky (writer/performer) Darren Clark (music/lyrics) Dorie Kinnear (deviser/performer).

We make original theatre for young audiences and their families. 

Since 2012 we have toured to theatres across the South East, the UK and Moscow. We make work with artists from around the world including the US, Russia and Australia. 

We believe passionately in telling new and exciting stories to children in the most interesting and accessible ways. Our work is a mashup of live music, puppetry, storytelling and physical theatre. 

Our Campaign

On the furthest edge of a wind-battered rock there sits a small fishing town. Sometimes it feels like the town is on the edge of the world. 

That’s mainly because it is.

Dylan lives with his grandma, forbidden from venturing beyond the shore. But the terrifying tales told of horrors in the deep only whet his appetite - he stares at the ocean and dreams. 

Can one unlikely friendship save the Town On The Sea from catastrophe?

Our new production The Boy and the Mermaid is our third touring piece for families. Inspired by the humanitarian refugee crisis on Europe’s shores, this new play uses the sea shanty tradition to explore how communities and relationships are affected by 'Otherness', through a childhood friendship against the odds. 

Our production received funding from Arts Council England for Research and Development in February 2016. We are now awaiting further funding to support a tour to South East England. 

This campaign is to allow us to spend one further week exploring the piece's theatrical world; and to run a drama workshop with young refugees & asylum seekers, engaging with the themes at its heart.

Before we get into the nuts and bolts of rehearsal, we want to spend a week clarifying our theatrical languages, perfecting our puppetry and exploring the story with young people. 

By contributing to this campaign, you will help  

  • reach vulnerable young people with a specially devised drama workshop in a safe and supportive environment 
  • allow us to make new theatrical discoveries that enrich the final production before it reaches families across the South East
  • support a new production for young people engaging with difficult issues in a fun, accessible and innovative way

- 

What We Need & What You Get

Paper Balloon are asking for £2500 to support 1 week of Research and Development (R&D) in January 2017; and workshops with young refugees and asylum seekers in the South East. 

The R&D 

  • 4 artists (paid at industry standard rates) will explore music, movement and puppetry within the piece 
  • The Unicorn Theatre (the UK's flagship theatre for children) has kindly offered to donate one week's rehearsal space for our use on the project 
  • This creative work will then influence the script, songs and design that will feature in rehearsals for our tour later that year

The workshops

  • We will work with young refugees and asylum seekers in Oxford 
  • In a safe and supportive environment, we will explore issues such as friendship through difference and overcoming linguistic and cultural barriers 
  • What we discover in these workshops will affect and influence our production; something that has always proved key to our shows 

In Return

Be a part of our expanding network! Paper Balloon rely on the support of ordinary people in order to keep going. Art is often the first to get the chop in tough times, so your support is vital in providing a voice. 

In return for contributing to our campaign we can offer the following fun perks, including signed cast photos, signed copies of the script used in rehearsal, special invitations to work-in-progress performances, and musical production soundtracks

The Impact

It takes a lot of work to create a project like this. Arts Council England have been a massive help, as have the many theatres who have supported our work. Paper Balloon artists often work for free in order to get the project off the ground, but we can only offer so much time.  

Any funding towards our goal will help pay for our time to come, enriching the project and allowing us to devote all our energies towards it. 

We have found that the extra time of one week of R&D makes all the difference to the quality of our work; by paying artists properly, allowing us to travel to workshops and covering the costs of materials, we are able to greatly improve the finished product. 

Why this and why now? 

If you pick up a paper or switch on the news, it's hard to avoid difficult and uncomfortable conversations about people escaping war, the building of walls and who "should be here" in the UK. We believe it's important for children to access these complex issues. 

Our story provides a human face to difficult statistics and distant shores. It lets children empathise with different characters and people, and it allows them to laugh at difficult things. And crucially, it allows families to enjoy a shared experience together, with catchy music to hum to each other on the journey home. 

This is our third production, and our most challenging yet. With your help we can turn it into our biggest success. 

For a flavour of our work so far, please visit our website

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course not everyone can afford to donate money. But perhaps you can help our campaign:

  • Spread the word! Let people know about the project through social media, tell them about it, show them how they can help 
  • Contact us if there are other things you can offer: marketing support, a handy van, unused lighting equipment! 

And don't forget to share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter and your social media platforms

story:
Hay personas que nacen para bailar. 

Nosotrxs nacimos para bailar.  Bailar en nuestra tierra o al otro lado del mar.  Cada experiencia provoca nuevas formas de relacionarnos con nuestros cuerpos y crecer como artistas.  De eso se trata este proyecto.  De bailar en la matria/patria que es Puerto Rico y compartir con la gente del corazón lo aprendido en tres años de estudios en Barcelona.  De una puertorriqueña que viene acompañada de sus bailes y de un bailarín que viene a conocer desde el movimiento compartido una tierra que no es suya, pero que ya conoce desde la distancia.

Cuando se nace para bailar, sólo se piensa en dar nuevos sentidos a cada movimiento y experiencia.

Podríamos hablar de la experiencia que proponemos con un lenguaje técnico, y lo haremos en un rato, pero primero queremos contarles lo que significa llegar en este momento del año a Puerto Rico y tener la oportunidad de compartir un escenario con otras y otros creadores de danza. 

Hace un año que Isadora no pone un pie bailarín en su matria/patria.  La añora.  La sueña.  La vive desde la distancia.  Sigue los movimientos de otras bailarinas y bailarines que quiere y que admira.  Sueña con verles.  También sueña con el mar, el sol, las montañas y los abrazos de su familia.  Y para una trabajadora de la danza, toda esa emoción y experiencia como mejor se traduce es con el baile.  Ese baile que se comparte como si fuera una buena fiesta navideña en tiempos de solsticio, de aguinaldos y de la mejor comida del año.

Bailar es una necesidad. 

Cos Parlant es un grupo compuesto por bailarinxs y artistas de distintos estilos y disciplinas que se encuentran en un punto común: la necesidad de llevar el lenguaje del cuerpo a espacios de exposición que transformen el movimiento en un discurso corpóreo capaz de expresar infinidades. Nace de la iniciativa de Isadora López Pagán, bailarina de danza contemporánea formada en el Institut del Teatre en Barcelona quien con ayuda de artistas de otras corrientes decide tomar rienda en un proyecto que tendrá como finalidad reunir a jóvenes bailarinxs, que como ella, comienzan a investigar en el mundo de la creación artística y necesitan espacios donde exponer sus nuevas ideas en proceso de creación.

Foto por Judit Rodríguez

¿Qué proponemos? Un diálogo creativo.

El grupo Cos Parlant se enfoca principalmente en la danza y las miles de formas de exponerla, compartirla y comprenderla. De ahí surge la idea de un Junte de Jóvenes Creadorxs que busca reunir a artistas que dan comienzo a su carrera como coreógrafxs y darles la oportunidad de presentar sus creaciones en un espacio escénico común. El programa constará de tres o cuatro creadorxs, entre ellxs Cos Parlant, quienes en una duración entre media hora y una hora presentarán piezas de corta duración.

El tema será libre para lxs creadorxs y trabajarán por su cuenta hasta la semana de la programación donde antes de hacer la puesta en escena tendrán un espacio de intercambio de propuestas. La idea está en ir más allá del resultado coreográfico y la diversidad escénica que se pueda unir en un mismo espacio. El propósito principal de este JUNTE es llegar al diálogo y al intercambio de procesos creativos que cada creador/a ha utilizado para concluir el trabajo que presentará.

¿Cómo dialogaremos?

Hoy en día la danza contemporánea se nutre de su propio proceso. Los creadores y creadoras que deciden crear a través de este estilo de danza se sumergen en investigaciones tanto académicas como físicas. El movimiento ya no es visto como un paso normativo sino como un mundo de sensaciones, sentimientos y conocimientos que provocan que el cuerpo se mueva y armonice en lo que llamamos baile. Con los años lxs nuevxs creadorxs que van ganando nombre han establecido que la prioridad no está en el resultado sino en el proceso para llegar a una finalidad. Lxs bailrinxs de danza contemporánea no solo tienen como labor seguir las órdenes del coreógrafo sino que a nivel personal tienen que ser personas plenas, capaces de abrir su cuerpo y alma a temas que no necesariamente están relacionados a la danza.

 El cuerpo es capaz de absorber y transformar el entorno que le rodea pero para eso se necesita comenzar a crear un discurso propio donde el cuerpo trabajado y amoldado pueda llenar el espacio con sus interrogantes y opiniones. Cos Parlant cada día trabaja en la búsqueda de este discurso no verbal y es por eso que propone un espacio para llevar a cabo este intercambio entre creadorxs jóvenes como ellxs.

Con dos días de intercambio y dos funciones abiertas al público, lxs creadorxs compartirán entre ellxs y luego con el público. Los primeros dos días serán de intercambio donde Isadora López y Cristian Ortega tendrán a cargo la fluidez en el intercambio de conocimientos. Comenzando con clases multidireccionales donde pondrán en práctica sus técnicas de entrenamiento para comenzar a aprender de lxs otrxs bailarinxs. Seguido a esto cada creadorx hará una exposicion de su pieza para lxs demás creadorxs. Presentará la pieza finalizada pero también hablará del proceso en el que se ha sumergido a lo largo de la creación. La idea de este espacio es generar un conversatorio entre creadorxs y aprender de los otros procesos para enriquecer el propio.

Los días de presentaciones a público abierto las piezas de las creadoras y creadores serán el menú para lxs espectadorxs. Como conclusión a los días anteriores, Cos Parlant busca que la finalidad sea exponer a las nuevas creaciones y abrir un espacio de diálogo entre artistas y amantes del arte de la danza que buscan renovar el lenguaje corporal en la isla de Puerto Rico.

 Para esta primera ocasión el intercambio se dará entre bailarinxs que desarrollan su trabajo artístico dentro de la isla y Cos Parlant que trabaja en Barcelona compuesto por Isadora López Pagán bailarina puertorriqueña que lleva 3 años formándose en España y Cristian Ortega Ruedas quien también recibe formación en Barcelona pero ha viajado a instruirse a Ámsterdam, Francia, entre otros.  Este JUNTE es una puerta de comunicación entre la nueva generación de coreógrafos y coreógrafas locales e internacionales.

 Las creadoras y creadores invitados a participar del JUNTE autogestionarán sus procesos de creación. El tiempo, los espacios de ensayo, entreno físico, investigación y elección del tema queda en manos de lxs creadorxs. No habrá ningún tipo de restricción en cuanto a los medios. La única cosa que se les solicitará a lxs participantes es que documenten todo el proceso, desde la elección del tema, gestión del tiempo de ensayos y los recursos físico de investigación. La forma en que sea recogido el proceso puede variar. Como por ejemplo: partituras de la coreografía, notas de conceptos físicos, espaciales y metales, vídeos de ensayos y/o cosas relacionadas a la creación, fotos, etcétera.

Todx bailarín o bailarina que busca realizarse en el mundo de la creación entiende que este aprendizaje está en la práctica y que los primeros años hay que tomárselos como una asignatura artística en la vida de cada creadorx. Cada unx recurre a los métodos de otrxs creadorxs y los asimila a una zona propia para conseguir un buen resultado de su trabajo. Es ahí donde Isadora López propone el JUNTE como un camino para ampliar el vínculo de comunicación entre lxs jóvenes coreógrafxs reuniéndose en un lugar común donde se pueda conversar y compartir plenamente el proceso para así aprender y mejorar desde la experiencia de lxs demás. Para crecer hay que observar los aciertos y errores de otrxs.  Hay que reconocer los aciertos y errores propios.

Puerto Rico necesita más espacios de aciertos y errores en los que lxs bailarinxs puedan trabajar en piel propia la creación del lenguaje del cuerpo.  Pero, más que nada, necesitan un espacio donde puedan compartir sus preocupaciones y que haya otrxs que también quieran solucionar y encontrar  sentido a la paradoja del discurso hecho carne.

¿Para qué queremos el dinero?

Para esta producción necesitaremos cubrir gastos de producción y de transportación. Ofreceremos dos funciones libres de costo los días 7 y 8 de enero en el Tablao de Paulette en Ballajá en Viejo San Juan. A las 8pm. ¿Vendrás a vernos?

transformen el movimiento en un discurso corpóreo capaz de expresar
infinidades. Nace de la iniciativa de Isadora López Pagán, bailarina de danza
contemporánea formada en el Institut del Teatre en Barcelona quien con ayuda de
artistas de otras corrientes decide tomar rienda en un proyecto que tendrá como
finalidad reunir a jóvenes bailarinxs, que como ella, comienzan a investigar en
el mundo de la creación artística y necesitan espacios donde exponer sus nuevas
ideas en proceso de creación.


Foto por Judit Rodríguez
¿Qué proponemos? Un diálogo creativo. 


El grupo Cos Parlant se enfoca
principalmente en la danza y las miles de formas de exponerla, compartirla y
comprenderla. De ahí surge la idea de un Junte de Jóvenes Creadorxs que busca
reunir a artistas que dan comienzo a su carrera como coreógrafxs y darles la
oportunidad de presentar sus creaciones en un espacio escénico común. El
programa constará de tres o cuatro creadorxs, entre ellxs Cos Parlant, quienes
en una duración entre media hora y una hora presentarán piezas de corta
duración.
El
tema será libre para lxs creadorxs y trabajarán por su cuenta hasta la semana
de la programación donde antes de hacer la puesta en escena tendrán un espacio
de intercambio de propuestas. La idea está en ir más allá del resultado
coreográfico y la diversidad escénica que se pueda unir en un mismo espacio. El
propósito principal de este JUNTE es llegar al diálogo y al intercambio de
procesos creativos que cada creador/a ha utilizado para concluir el trabajo que
presentará.
¿Cómo dialogaremos?




Hoy en día la danza contemporánea se
nutre de su propio proceso. Los creadores y creadoras que deciden crear a
través de este estilo de danza se sumergen en investigaciones tanto académicas
como físicas. El movimiento ya no es visto como un paso normativo sino como un
mundo de sensaciones, sentimientos y conocimientos que provocan que el cuerpo
se mueva y armonice en lo que llamamos baile. Con los años lxs nuevxs creadorxs
que van ganando nombre han establecido que la prioridad no está en el resultado
sino en el proceso para llegar a una finalidad. Lxs bailrinxs de danza
contemporánea no solo tienen como labor seguir las órdenes del coreógrafo sino
que a nivel personal tienen que ser personas plenas, capaces de abrir su cuerpo
y alma a temas que no necesariamente están relacionados a la danza.
 El
cuerpo es capaz de absorber y transformar el entorno que le rodea pero para eso
se necesita comenzar a crear un discurso propio donde el cuerpo trabajado y
amoldado pueda llenar el espacio con sus interrogantes y opiniones. Cos Parlant
cada día trabaja en la búsqueda de este discurso no verbal y es por eso que
propone un espacio para llevar a cabo este intercambio entre creadorxs jóvenes
como ellxs.
Con
dos días de intercambio y dos funciones abiertas al público, lxs creadorxs
compartirán entre ellxs y luego con el público. Los primeros dos días serán de
intercambio donde Isadora López y Cristian Ortega tendrán a cargo la fluidez en
el intercambio de conocimientos. Comenzando con clases multidireccionales donde
pondrán en práctica sus técnicas de entrenamiento para comenzar a aprender de
lxs otrxs bailarinxs. Seguido a esto cada creadorx hará una exposicion de su
pieza para lxs demás creadorxs. Presentará la pieza finalizada pero también
hablará del proceso en el que se ha sumergido a lo largo de la creación. La
idea de este espacio es generar un conversatorio entre creadorxs y aprender de
los otros procesos para enriquecer el propio.
Los
días de presentaciones a público abierto las piezas de las creadoras y
creadores serán el menú para lxs espectadorxs. Como conclusión a los días
anteriores, Cos Parlant busca que la finalidad sea exponer a las nuevas
creaciones y abrir un espacio de diálogo entre artistas y amantes del arte de
la danza que buscan renovar el lenguaje corporal en la isla de Puerto Rico.
 Para
esta primera ocasión el intercambio se dará entre bailarinxs que desarrollan su
trabajo artístico dentro de la isla y Cos Parlant que trabaja en Barcelona
compuesto por Isadora López Pagán bailarina puertorriqueña que lleva 3 años
formándose en España y Cristian Ortega Ruedas quien también recibe formación en
Barcelona pero ha viajado a instruirse a Ámsterdam, Francia, entre otros.  Este JUNTE es una puerta de comunicación
entre la nueva generación de coreógrafos y coreógrafas locales e
internacionales.
 Las
creadoras y creadores invitados a participar del JUNTE autogestionarán sus
procesos de creación. El tiempo, los espacios de ensayo, entreno físico,
investigación y elección del tema queda en manos de lxs creadorxs. No habrá
ningún tipo de restricción en cuanto a los medios. La única cosa que se les
solicitará a lxs participantes es que documenten todo el proceso, desde la
elección del tema, gestión del tiempo de ensayos y los recursos físico de
investigación. La forma en que sea recogido el proceso puede variar. Como por
ejemplo: partituras de la coreografía, notas de conceptos físicos, espaciales y
metales, vídeos de ensayos y/o cosas relacionadas a la creación, fotos,
etcétera.
Todx
bailarín o bailarina que busca realizarse en el mundo de la creación entiende
que este aprendizaje está en la práctica y que los primeros años hay que
tomárselos como una asignatura artística en la vida de cada creadorx. Cada unx
recurre a los métodos de otrxs creadorxs y los asimila a una zona propia para
conseguir un buen resultado de su trabajo. Es ahí donde Isadora López propone
el JUNTE como un camino para ampliar el vínculo de comunicación entre lxs
jóvenes coreógrafxs reuniéndose en un lugar común donde se pueda conversar y
compartir plenamente el proceso para así aprender y mejorar desde la
experiencia de lxs demás. Para crecer hay que observar los aciertos y errores
de otrxs.  Hay que reconocer los aciertos
y errores propios. 
Puerto Rico necesita más espacios de aciertos y errores en
los que lxs bailarinxs puedan trabajar en piel propia la creación del lenguaje
del cuerpo.  Pero, más que nada,
necesitan un espacio donde puedan compartir sus preocupaciones y que haya otrxs
que también quieran solucionar y encontrar 
sentido a la paradoja del discurso hecho carne.
¿Para qué queremos el dinero?
Para esta producción necesitaremos cubrir gastos de producción y de transportación. Ofreceremos dos funciones libres de costo los días 7 y 8 de enero en el Tablao de Paulette en Ballajá en Viejo San Juan. A las 8pm. ¿Vendrás a vernos?

story:
About Eagle Project


Eagle Project is an inter-tribal and multicultural performing arts company, fiscally sponsored by New York Live Arts, that behaves as an artistic laboratory by utilizing theater, music, dance, spoken word, and film to dissect the American identity, while using the Native American experience, both past and present, as the primary means for which to conduct its exploration. This mission is carried out through the development and staging of the works of Native American playwrights, educational outreach on Native American culture, and the production of the works of other American voices that are not frequently heard. It is the goal of Eagle Project to produce theatrical work that gives us as Americans a true recollection of our past, a better understanding of our present, for a just and more inclusive vision for our future.  Supporting our 21st Century writers is critical to the work that we do. Hatch is Eagle Project’s program of readings, staged readings, and workshops to support the playwright in their work, and thus the time table and format of the presentation is based on where the writer is in their process. Sometimes the work goes all the way to full production, as did our first production, Wood Bones by William S. Yellow Robe, Jr., our second production, Broken Heart Land by Vicki Lynn Mooney, and our third production (in partnership with Rebel Theater Company), Trail of Tears by Thomas J. Soto. Over the past four years, Eagle Project has had the privilege of collaborating and/or being hosted by the Public Theater, The Lark Play Development Center, Primary Stages, Nuyorican Poets Café, as well as the United Nations. In addition, our programming consists of our America Unveiled Series, an annual event that brings talented poets and comedians together to riff on one of the hottest topics of the time. We are also pleased to announce the launch of our new Education Department, scheduled to start in early 2017.


LOST VOICES - Synopsis

The two one-act plays that will make up Lost Voices will explore two different ethnic groups who were greatly affected by Hurricane Katrina, and who, because of their economic status in our society, have been almost lost in our consciousness.  Vanishing Point is a new work written by Lakota playwright, Larissa FastHorse.  Inspired by the Biloxi-Chitimacha-Choctaw tribe, America’s first official climate refugees, Vanishing Point follows two characters who fight to stay above water in Louisiana. If they can just weather the storm, they will survive. But what if the storm never ends and the water never retreats? Will saving themselves mean the loss of their entire tribe? Vanishing Point is the first play Eagle Project ever commissioned.

The second play, Wide Blossoms by Elise Marenson, deals with a young white lawyer in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. Having escaped from New Orleans after the storm, the lawyer is in a bar drinking his sorrows away after work late one night. A young African American woman enters the bar disheveled, and throughout the play, she drops phrases, songs, and poems that haunt the lawyer. She almost seems like a ghost or our conscience picking away at something that we’re trying to cover up. Once the dramatic truth is revealed, we are once again reminded that in the end, we are all connected to one another.


Our Production
LOST VOICES: The Vision & The Performance

Everything, from the set to the music to the lighting, will be utilized to immerse the audience in these Louisiana communities. Many of the design elements will be used to emphasize simplicity in order to highlight some of the universal themes that both these stories share. Music will include an eclectic mix of Native American/ indigenous sounds along with jazz and elements of Creole culture. This is in order to explore the fusion of these heritages, how they relate, how they differ, and their common root in the American experience.


The cast and creative team will consist of some of the most talented, diverse, and unique theater artists in New York City. This whole production is designed to give those who hardly ever have a voice in American Theater a platform. This goes for the people involved in executing the production, in addition to the characters in the stories themselves.


Why this project?

The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina was one of the worst atrocities in American history. While this storm was certainly a force of nature, the impact was greatly compounded by the racial and class divisions that still permeate contemporary American society. Many of these divisions run deep because of policies that were put into effect centuries ago, but have yet to be changed. Lost Voices brings to the surface the American secrets and realities Katrina uncovered, and the uncomfortable truths left in the residue.


The Impact

Lost Voices directly dramatizes the consequences of not adhering to what Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. phrased as, “The fierce urgency of now.”  Vanishing Point  parallels the loss of the tribe’s culture with the physical disappearance of their land due to climate change and greed. This, combined with the current bureaucracy of the federal recognition system, puts many state recognized tribes, such as the Biloxi-Chitimacha-Choctaw, at a great disadvantage. By helping to bring their story to light, we will not only hope to bring awareness to their plight, but plant a seed in our viewers’ minds that it’s still not too late to alter the tide of history.

Wide Blossoms broadens the scope of the evening to remind us that no matter who we are, where we come from, and how much money we have, nothing can insulate us from what we collectively do to one another.  One of the central characters in the piece tries everything, both cultural and physical, to separate himself from the truth, but it follows him wherever he goes.  Yet the catharsis that only comes from acceptance, allows him to finally be free.

Whether one lives in Louisiana, Florida, California, Manhattan Island, or any of the areas in between, Lost Voices drives home the reality that how we treat one another and our planet are interconnected, and that we only have a certain amount of time to change course.


Larissa FastHorse - Writer
Vanishing Point

Larissa FastHorse is an award winning playwright, director, and choreographer based in Santa Monica. She was awarded the NEA Distinguished New Play Development Grant, Joe Dowling Annamaghkerrig Fellowship, AATE Distinguished Play Award, Inge Residency, Sundance/Ford Foundation Fellowship, Aurand Harris Fellowship, and numerous Ford and NEA Grants. Larissa's produced plays include Urban Rez, Landless, Average Family, Teaching Disco Squaredancing to Our Elders: a Class Presentation, and Cherokee Family Reunion. She has written commissions for Cornerstone Theatre Company, Children’s Theatre Company of Minneapolis, AlterTheater, Kennedy Center TYA, Native Voices at the Autry, Artist’s Rep and Mountainside Theatre. She developed plays with Kansas City Rep, Artist’s Rep in Portland, Arizona Theater Company, the Center Theatre Group Writer’s Workshop and Berkeley Rep’s Ground Floor. She is a current member of the Playwright’s Union, Director’s Lab West 2015, Theatre Communications Group board of directors and is an enrolled member of the Rosebud Sioux Tribe, Lakota Nation. (Photo Credit: Conor Horgan) 


Elise Marenson - Writer
Wide Blossoms

Elise Marenson appeared in more than thirty stage productions before choosing writing over acting. In 2015, her play Real Estate of Emergency was produced at the Metropolitan Playhouse in New York. Her play Learn To Drive was voted Best Drama at the First Stage Los Angeles Playwrights Festival in 2014. A production of her play Colony was featured in the 2014 Midtown International Theatre Festival. Also in 2014, her comedy Head Trauma played at the Roy Arias Theatre directed by Marcus Yi. In 2011, she wrote and directed Straight From The Rib gleaned from her life experience, with twenty-seven monologues performed by a cast of nine women of all ages. She directed productions at the Abingdon Theatre, WorkShop Theater Company, Samuel French OOB Festival, New Center Stages, Strawberry Theatre Festival, Sounding Theater, Atlantic Theater School, Westbeth Theatre, The Triad, as well as numerous readings.

Ms. Marenson’s feature length screenplays Jeremy, Malcolm, and Bess, Spacious Skies, Chorus Girl, and Picked Out, were finalists in Ace Fest, FilmMakers International, Scriptapalooza, and Chesterfield Writers Film Project competitions. Two scripts have been optioned. She wrote and directed Joanie and Amalia which earned jury mention at the International Short Film Festival at Clermont-Ferrand. She is a script consultant and has taught acting, using what she learned from her teacher Uta Hagen. You can read her theater reviews at thefrontrowcenter.com. She is a member of SAG-AFTRA, AEA, and NY Women in Film & Television. Elise is currently developing two full length stage plays, American Flamingos and Comfort Zones.


Other Ways You Can Help

Besides donating necessary funds, people can spread the word about Eagle Project and LOST VOICES. Visit our Eagle Project website and join our e-mail list, like us on Facebook, and follow us on Twitter. There are also volunteer opportunities. If interested, please e-mail eagleprojectarts@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

Romeo and Juliet: A tale of tragic accidents. But how accidental was it, really? Set in a night club and told from the perspective of Rosaline, Romeo's first love; Valentine, Mercutio's brother; and Queen Mab, who might personify more than just a dream. Dance your way through the other side of history's most famous love story.

On the stroke of Midnight on September 12, 2014 we will open Mad Blood & Other Beauties at The Playground @ The Adrienne as part of the Philadelphia Live Arts/Fringe Festival. It is a play inspired by the unspoken characters of Romeo and Juliet. We will be recreating the famous Capulet Masquerade where Romeo and Juliet meet. We will be modernizing the story thereby making it more accessible to a 2014 audience. 

Jason Rosenberg wrote a play where poetry, Shakespeare's text, and contemporary language meet and juxtapose one another. Through his beautiful text we will be creating a theatrical piece that uses contemporary music and designs inspired by steam punk/ Modern Elizabethan Bondage / and club fashion. We want our audience to feel immersed by our recreation of the Capulet Masquerade. Maybe you will meet your star-crossed lover at our show... 

We are inspired to make theater that speaks to our generation. Instead of watching Netflix in bed on a Friday night, we want to make work that draws people to a theatrical event. We hope you come see Mad Blood & Other Beauties and donate! 

The Impact

All of us are current or recent graduates of The University of the Arts, which was just a step away from the epicenter of the Philadelphia theatre scene. As we make our path way through the Philly community as young theatre artists; we hope to make Mad Blood & Other Beauties an example of the kind of riveting theatrical work that we hope to contribute for the Philadelphia theatre community. In return, we hope this show will be a launching pad for future work with the company members and new collaborators! Please help support Philly Emerging Artists make great art! Thank you.

  • What We Need

To have a production recreating the Capulet Masquerade

We are asking for $3250! Your contribution will include:

$1200: Our space rental for The Playground @ The Adrienne Theatre and our rehearsal/ audition rental. 

$1200: Production expenses including costumes, scenic design, lighting, sound composition, and props. We will be using design elements such as masks, modern Elizabethan Bondage fashion, weapons for fight scenes , and lighting figurations/set made of found materials. ( You'll have to see our show to see the brilliance of what our designers will create!) 

$500: Fringe Fees for the festival and insurance for our show. 

$350: Marketing and Poster Printing. Our goal is to draw current theater goers as well as draw new audiences to the theater. We want 350 so we can print posters/postcards all over the city and have a strong presence on Social Media. 


* This campaign of $3250 will not compensate the Creators of this project*

Jason Rosenberg is a Philadelphia based playwright and actor, entering his senior year at UArts , where he is currently dramaturging Matt Pfeiffer's production of We Are Proud to Present A Presentation this upcoming fall. He is the co-founder, co-curator, and resident playwright Cursed Church Theater Company, a theater based art-collective, through which Jason has produced his plays Nothing But Light and [sleep] holds them.

Jessica Schwartz is a Philadelphia based Director and Producer. Favorite directing credits include Modern Playground (Philly Fringe), Crumble (Lay Me Down, Justin Timberlake), The Vagina Monologues (A Fundraiser for Women Against Abuse), SubUrbia, and Pantie$. She has worked with companies including: Atlantic Theater Company, Azuka Theatre, Philly Young Playwrights, InterAct, and Simpatico Theatre Project. www.jessicaschwartzdirector.com 

David Hutchison is a Philadelphia based Actor. Recent credits: Auctioning the Ainsley's (Bristol Riverside), The Importance of Being Earnest, Shakespeare's R + J (Mauckingbird Theatre Co). David is a graduate of The University of the Arts and The British American Drama Academy. www.davidrhutchison.com

Tess McChesney Kunik is a Colorado native and graduate of the University of the Arts where she earned her BFA in acting. She is a Philadelphia based actor and visual artist. Recent credits include Delaware Mudtub and the Mighty Wampum (Plays and Players), A Midsummer Night's Dream (Tudor Theatrical Productions,), Three Sisters (Masha *understudy* at the Arden Theatre Company)

Arlen Hancock is a recent graduate from The University of the Arts. Recent roles include Mr. Wheeler (Play Penn), Modern Playground (Philly Fringe), and Dear Diary, Bye (Plays and Players).

Merri Rashoyan is a Philadelphia based actor, and a recent graduate of the University of the Arts. She is beyond thrilled that Mad Blood is a reality! Previous credits include Young Voices Monologue Festival(PYP/InterAct) Cockfight(PlayPenn) Comedy of Errors(Scranton Shakespeare Festival) among others.

Through his beautiful text we will be creating a theatrical piece that uses contemporary music and designs inspired by steam punk/ Modern Elizabethan Bondage / and club fashion. We want our audience to feel immersed by our recreation of the Capulet Masquerade. Maybe you will meet your star-crossed lover at our show... We are inspired to make theater that speaks to our generation. Instead of watching Netflix in bed on a Friday night, we want to make work that draws people to a theatrical event. We hope you come see Mad Blood & Other Beauties and donate! The ImpactAll of us are current or recent graduates of The University of the Arts, which was just a step away from the epicenter of the Philadelphia theatre scene. As we make our path way through the Philly community as young theatre artists; we hope to make Mad Blood & Other Beauties an example of the kind of riveting theatrical work that we hope to contribute for the Philadelphia theatre community. In return, we hope this show will be a launching pad for future work with the company members and new collaborators! Please help support Philly Emerging Artists make great art! Thank you.What We NeedTo have a production recreating the Capulet MasqueradeWe are asking for $3250! Your contribution will include:$1200: Our space rental for The Playground @ The Adrienne Theatre and our rehearsal/ audition rental. $1200: Production expenses including costumes, scenic design, lighting, sound composition, and props. We will be using design elements such as masks, modern Elizabethan Bondage fashion, weapons for fight scenes , and lighting figurations/set made of found materials. ( You'll have to see our show to see the brilliance of what our designers will create!) $500: Fringe Fees for the festival and insurance for our show. $350: Marketing and Poster Printing. Our goal is to draw current theater goers as well as draw new audiences to the theater. We want 350 so we can print posters/postcards all over the city and have a strong presence on Social Media. * This campaign of $3250 will not compensate the Creators of this project*Jason Rosenberg is a Philadelphia based playwright and actor, entering his senior year at UArts , where he is currently dramaturging Matt Pfeiffer's production of We Are Proud to Present A Presentation this upcoming fall. He is the co-founder, co-curator, and resident playwright Cursed Church Theater Company, a theater based art-collective, through which Jason has produced his plays Nothing But Light and [sleep] holds them.Jessica Schwartz is a Philadelphia based Director and Producer. Favorite directing credits include Modern Playground (Philly Fringe), Crumble (Lay Me Down, Justin Timberlake), The Vagina Monologues (A Fundraiser for Women Against Abuse), SubUrbia, and Pantie$. She has worked with companies including: Atlantic Theater Company, Azuka Theatre, Philly Young Playwrights, InterAct, and Simpatico Theatre Project. www.jessicaschwartzdirector.com David Hutchison is a Philadelphia based Actor. Recent credits: Auctioning the Ainsley's (Bristol Riverside), The Importance of Being Earnest, Shakespeare's R + J (Mauckingbird Theatre Co). David is a graduate of The University of the Arts and The British American Drama Academy. www.davidrhutchison.comTess McChesney Kunik is a Colorado native and graduate of the University of the Arts where she earned her BFA in acting. She is a Philadelphia based actor and visual artist. Recent credits include Delaware Mudtub and the Mighty Wampum (Plays and Players), A Midsummer Night's Dream (Tudor Theatrical Productions,), Three Sisters (Masha *understudy* at the Arden Theatre Company)Arlen Hancock is a recent graduate from The University of the Arts. Recent roles include Mr. Wheeler (Play Penn), Modern Playground (Philly Fringe), and Dear Diary, Bye (Plays and Players).Merri Rashoyan is a Philadelphia based actor, and a recent graduate of the University of the Arts. She is beyond thrilled that Mad Blood is a reality! Previous credits include Young Voices Monologue Festival(PYP/InterAct) Cockfight(PlayPenn) Comedy of Errors(Scranton Shakespeare Festival) among others.

story:
DISTRICTLAND is about a city full of transplant activists who cannot name DC’s mayor.  It’s about slam poetry, your iPhone, your internship, your Mall kickball team, Law School, Rhodes Scholars, World Bankers, Peace Corps, first generation baggage, the lone DC native and how a cabbie from Kabul’s life is so much more interesting than yours.

A satire, DISTRICTLAND is a loving tribute to youth and ambition and a plea for all of us to slow down, open a bottle of wine and just talk to the people we live with. Spoiler Alert: you are not your LinkedIn profile!

 DISTRICTLAND needs your help!

We are asking you, our friends and fans, to help us create this unique theatrical experience at Capital Fringe this summer in DC!

Please help us reach our goal of $6000 by the end of our run. Your donation with defray the costs of:

•                     Paying our artists for their time and effort

•                     Fringe festival fees

•                     Set acquisition –  e.g. a faux DC taxi cab ....

•                     Costumes and props – this is a detail-oriented show!

•                     Lights and Sound – both are crucial to Dellaporta’s vision

•                     Insurance – Just in case

•                     Marketing materials and publicity – canvassing the town

Every little bit helps! Please share this campaign with your friends. And even if you cannot help financially, it’s a big help to get the DISTRICTLAND word out! Thank you. Long live the District.

Here are the show details:

DISTRICTLAND

By Cristina Bejan

Directed by John Dellaporta

This production is presented as a part of the 2014 Capital Fringe Festival, a program of the Washington, DC non-profit Capital Fringe. #capfringe14

Performances:

Friday, July 11, 10:30 pm
Sunday, July 13, 8 pm
Wednesday, July 16, 6:30 pm
Saturday, July 19, 2:15 pm
Wednesday, July 23, 9 pm
Sunday, July 27, 6:15 pm

Venue:

Fort Fringe's REDRUM theatre
612 L Street NW, Washington, DC, 20001

 Team:

Assistant Director: Hope Villaneuva 
Stage Manager: Bethanie Herman 
Light/Sound Design: Elliot Lanes 
Backstage guru: Mary Anne Limoncelli 
Fundraising: Renu Alhuwalia 
PR: Andra Belknap 
Program: Joan Cummins

Cast: Andrew Quilpa, Ruthie Rado, Johnny Day, Aaren Keith, Andra Belknap, Peter Orvetti, Mary-Alice Farina, Vick Krishna, Robin Freeman, Kathleen Mason and Carson Elizabeth Gregory.

Bucharest Inside the Beltway is DC’s new culture and arts collective dedicated to all artforms, every culture and all languages. BiB’s distinguished board included artists from DC, Romania, Canada and India. BiB is led by directors Cristina Bejan (DC) and Rucsandra Pop (Bucharest). www.bucharestinsidethebeltway.com

Risks and Challenges

Bejan has produced theatrical productions and events in the US, UK, Romania and Vanuatu but this is her first time doing so at DC’s Fringe! This is also the first project of Bucharest Inside the Beltway. The DISTRICTLAND team has professional experience across the board and we are dedicated to providing an entertaining, dynamic and high-quality show at the festival this summer.

FAQ 

If any of this information doesn’t answer your questions, please get in touch with us directly at DISTRICTLAND2014@gmail.com

Special thanks to Manish Alimchandani and Sean Yetter for making our awesome trailer! And a big thanks to Bar Pilar for hosting the film.

story:
WHO AM I?

My name is Marcos and I am a New York City choreographer. I direct Marcos Duran Performance Group, and have been making dances professionally since 2004. I began improvising with movement at the age of 15, and studied at the University of California–Santa Barbara, graduating in 2006 with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance with distinction and honors in choreography. My movement work has been presented throughout California, and in Philadelphia and New York City. I have danced on international stages, in site specific work, and on film. I have worked nationally for choreographers such as Daniel Charon, Faye Driscoll, Risa Jaroslow, Keith Johnson, Jerry Pearson, and Bill Young, and I have extensive experience as member of a variety of creative teams. www.marcosduranmoves.com

WHAT I'M CREATING & WHY IT'S IMPORTANT

"Around The Fortress"  is my first full length 45 minute group dance. It confronts the psyche as a confine and labyrinth, and expresses my interest in self actualization as an ongoing mission. It will premier in full at Greenspace, New York City, on February 20 and 21 as part of Take Root. I was delighted to share the first 20 minute draft of the work in October 2014 at Dixon Place's Underexposed . 
"Fortress" also marks my first collaboration with a composer. My cross-country work with Seattle-based Adam Lahm has been a groundbreaking step forward in my art making.  Adam is a brilliant force who empathetically lends his conceptual mind and original music to this vision. We aim to reveal a life without walls or fortresses, and inspire a wider perspective on ourselves and others.  
Furthermore, this project culminates my first decade of directing. My vision of dance theatre is not just about imposing my own ideas on performers, but to provide an opportunity for collaborators to explore their own states, their own psyche and histories, and their own movement potential. I could not be more excited to share this with you!
Performing alongside myself in the work will be Desira Barnes, Ariane Bernier, Randy Burd, Joanna Nobbe, Emily Vetsch, and Mei Yamanaka. BIOS

WHY FUNDRAISE?

I am fundraising for basic expenses that come along with dance making. This includes rehearsal space and compensation for all collaborators involved. I have decided to pay Desira, Randy, Ariane, Joanna, Emily, Mei, and Adam upon the final performances at Greenspace in the form of a stipend. This stipend will retroactively compensate these hardworking individuals for the passion and dedication that they have brought to "Fortress". 

72 percent of funds raised will go directly to all collaborators involved for their efforts, 24 percent will go towards our work spaces, and 4 percent will go towards administrative fees. I realize that my proposed budget proves to be a modest amount considering our endless hours of work over a 9 month rehearsal period and perhaps in an ideal world we are entitled to quadruple this amount, but I believe this is a good start! 

Yet, as I do not have the resources to do this on my own, this is where you come in. 

WHY DONATE?

Your support for "Around The Fortress" is pivotal.  Ultimately, this work is about CONNECTION. I choreograph in order to connect my imagination to the world outside of myself, and that includes you. What excites me most about running this campaign is that I get to explore my vision with a new wave of individuals. Nothing fulfills me more than sharing my work with people like you!

I am so excited to bring you in on this journey!

THE RISK: If this goal is not met, nearly 10% of proceeds will be lost! YOU ARE CERTAINLY NEEDED

THE IMPACT

This project marks Marcos Duran Performance Group's second Indiegogo campaign. We are dedicating our highly trained bodies and voices to this project, and sharing our abilities with you. You are an integral part of our communities, families and friends. Your contribution has a tremendous impact and literally provides us with the space to make this work. Furthermore, it reinforces that art is worth investing in and making; it justifies our hundreds of hours of enthusiasm, investigation and collaboration! 

Marcos Duran Performance Group has previously fundraised for New York City performances at 92nd St Y, Triskelion Arts, and Center for Performance Research in Winter 2013. In 36 days, the campaign gained support from 106 funders, and MDPG raised over its $5000 goal! This was a resounding success and made a huge difference in the quality of Marcos' work. We continue to thank all of you who got involved and turned our individual contributions into community action!

We look forward to a 2nd successful campaign! 

OTHER WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE

Support does not only come in the form of money! We highly value your potential as a collaborator with "Around The Fortress" and the future of Marcos Duran Performance Group. Skills we could utilize and would appreciate in this process would be photography, videography, marketing/PR strategies, dramaturgy, design, costume, and any participation in spreading the word. Perhaps you'd like to come to rehearsal one day and donate a class or workshop to the company! Share. The. Love.

Also – PLEASE COME TO THE SHOW on Feb 20th and 21st at Greenspace!  Thank you tremendously in advance and always.

We look forward to a 2nd successful campaign!    
OTHER WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE

story:
Short Summary

Hi folks! We are Kacie and Karen Devaney, a mother daughter team who wrote an original full length play entitled The Great Forgotten that was accepted into The New York City Fringe Festival 2015. The Great Forgotten goes up at the highly respected, Robert Moss Theater in Manhattan, August, 22nd, 27th, 28th, 29th, and 30th. Performance times and more details can be found directly on The Fringe website in the coming weeks here,  http://www.fringenyc.org/.

Karen Devaney is a writer, actor, teacher, and was once a nurse who lives in Sacramento, California. Kacie Devaney is a playwright, actor, dancer, choreographer, singer/song writer, and Pilates instructor currently living in New York City.

The Great Forgotten is set during WWI  and the Roaring Twenties. Two sisters, Elizabeth and Celia, work as American nurses in France during the Great War. When they return the roaring twenties is in full swing. While both sisters eventually become flappers, performing together at a local speakeasy in Manhattan, one struggles to forget the war and everyone she lost, while the other finds solace in her new life and  seeks fame and fortune as a dancer.

We are beyond excited to have been accepted into the NYC Fringe Festival! The Great Forgotten was one of 200 plays chosen out of over 1,000 submissions! The New York Fringe Festival gets over 80,000 spectators each year many of whom are industry professionals! As women playwrights and actors, we strove to write a piece with strong female characters. We also wanted to tell the story of the nurses, the unsung heroes, who served during The Great War. This play is not only a historical account of what nurses endured during WWI, but a tribute to all women whose contributions have been chronically overlooked. The Great Forgotten sheds light on women who have had the courage to pursue their passions despite the struggles of sexism and oppression.

What we need now is your help in bringing The Great Forgotten to life! What does this mean? Well, as struggling artist, it means helping us raise funds by donating or spreading the word about our campaign on all of your social media sites. This is a full scale production and we need as much help as we can get. We will need funding for; Rehearsal space, a stage manager and crew, a lighting crew, directors, actors we can pay, props, costumes, sound engineer, video engineer, insurance and more.

We realize that putting up a play is challenging and that creating the authenticity we hope for on stage will be tough. On the other hand, we are hard workers and dedicated to getting The Great Forgotten out there. This is not just art for art’s sake, this is a story that needs to be told and must be heard! Women especially, let's band together and give this female dominated play the chance it deserves!

Thank you all so much for reading and considering The Great Forgotten. Remember too, every bit counts. If you can't donate, please spread the word on your social media sites by liking our page and talking us up here-- https://www.facebook.com/Thegreatforgotten.

THANK YOU ALL!!!!


Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Performance Lab is a scratch night with a difference. It's aimed at any genre of live performance where the participants are developing new ways of working. The show on 8th February at The Bread and Roses, Clapham includes improvisation, cross art form based on tango and performance poetry. 

What We Need & What You Get

The aim is two fold first to pay expenses of participants - it's about developing as artists without adding to or creating personal debt. We also need to pay for a technician, some marketing and create the beginning of a small production fund for a full scale show by one of the participants. 

5 performers from Brighton @ £20 each = £100                                                                   10 performers from London @ £10 each = £100                                                                   Technician's fee                                             = £ 30                                                                    Marketing flyers/posters                            = £ 30                                                                    Future Production fund                                = £240

Total £500

                                                                                    

The perks are first a thank you by email then a thank you from The Stage on the night for the audience to cheer. Then a personally improvised poem in an email, then a personally dedicated mp3 recording of the poem. Finally a two man impro show in your own home (London and Brighton and Hove only).

If we don't make the full amount the first call on funds is technician's fee and performers' expenses

The Impact

I have been producing and directing theatre for many years and always seek to do something new. This includes Shakespeare played in private houses and an interactive, site specific and immersive show in a cafe. The Shakespeare sold out - the cafe show got a five star review.

My work has often used new actors and some have also gone onto direct and create their own work. Small scale innovation like this can eventually build to shows which delight the audience and employ creative people enriching the lives of both audience and performer. In these austere times it is essential to us all but funds are tight.

Other Ways You Can Help

I have noticed many crowd funding campaigns include advance tickets and I feel that this lacks imagination and engagement with pledgers, If all you can afford is to buy a ticket for the show (£5) then that's great. Here's a link to ticket sales http://www.breadandrosestheatre.co.uk/performan...
story_txt:

story:
In true KIN fashion, we're expanding our familial reach,
but we need our current network of supporters - our KIN -
to help us get there! 


   

Teamwork makes the dream work!

Robert Moses' KIN is widening our reach in our two, all-time favorite ways: teaching and performing!

RMK plans to travel to Montreal, Canada to expand our programming to youth regionally, nationally and worldwide. Showcasing at the annual International Presenters of Arts for Youth conference is a huge opportunity to make this possible!

The company has also been invited to the Republic of Congo for an international arts showcase called The Festival International de Theater, Dance et Cirque. Performing at this event in the Congo is a chance to bring our work to the continent of Africa for the first time in our 20 year history. Are you ready? WE ARE! But we can't do it without you.


What We Need

Your valiance! 

                       

                                                                      You!

  • Half of the 10k will go towards travel costs for the company to attend The Festival International de Theater, Dance et Cirque in the Congo (visas, plane tickets, per diem, etc.)
  • The other half will support the company's travel to and lodging in Canada for the International Presenters of Arts for Youth conference


The Impact

Robert Moses has always been committed to bringing people together. He and the company are committed to helping us humans, one show and one audience at a time, to break down old school doors and barriers that often keep us apart. 

                     Robert ---> 

Getting Robert Moses' KIN to the International Presenter's of Arts for Youth Conference in Canada will open countless doors to youth for the company and make it possible for us to share Robert's work farther and wider, with young and older audiences alike. 

Who knows what audience members, choreographers or young dancers will have their lives changed and dreams brought to life by seeing such a gifted and relatable company as Robert Moses' KIN live?

                                    


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may not be able to contribute $$$, and that's ok!

  • Please help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign (the Indiegogo share tools below are a great way to do this!)
  • Inquire with your company about them contributing a matching donation - you might not even know that they do this - it can't hurt to ask! Email info@robertmoseskin.org if you're interested but unsure how to go about this step.

story:
Help support queer performance art!

"A Queer Time and Place" is an evening of queer dance and performance, showcasing original work by choreographers Maggie Cee, Grant Jacoby, and J Michael Winward. The three artists draw inspiration from sources including pop culture, history, and queer theory. Audiences will be moved, provoked and entertained by the unique blend of contemporary and modern dance, physical theater, and original monologues. Guest artists include power//PLAY and Pampi. With a variety of perspectives represented, A Queer Time and Place celebrates the theater as a space of inclusion.

But we can't do it alone! We need your help to raise the funds to help cover production costs so we can focus on donating half of our proceeds from ticket sales to Youth on Fire (YOF), a drop-in center for homeless and street-involved youth, located in Harvard Square, Cambridge.

 

Where your support goes

We need your help raising $3000 to cover the following:

  • 2 nights of theater rental
  • Lighting designer/technician 
  • Stage manager
  • Videographer
  • Photographer
  • Marketing (Posters, programs, etc)

 

Every penny counts!  If we do not make our entire goal, all of the money will still go to covering production costs.

 

Other ways you can help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Spread the word! If you know anyone else who would be interested in our mission and willing to donate, or just to come to the show...let them know! We always want to reach new audiences.
  • Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media outlets.
  • Come to our performance! Even if you can't donate now, we would love to see you in the audience at one of our two performances.

 

Thank you so much for checking out our campaign! We can't thank you enough for your support.

- Maggie, Grant, & Michael

story:
Who’s In The Tub?

WHAT IS CROWDED TUB COLLECTIVE?

We are a newly formed collective that is focused on inciting a reconstruction of our human selves by delving into the lifeblood of great stories, one project at a time.  By maintaining a single focus, we can put all of our energy towards challenging our boundaries, concepts, and perceptions of the world in which we live, with Shakespeare's rich text as our primary tool. As storytellers, we believe that a solid investment in these explorations is fundamental. Granted, this territory has been traversed in the past, but now it’s being charted by rookies in a new and exciting way.

 

Meet the Tubbers

Matt Schwader: Director / Artistic Director

ShaRhonda Knott Dawson: Producer

Brent T. Barnes: Stage Manager

Alecia Annacchino: Juliet

Chad Bay: Tybalt

Jacqueline Davies: Capulet

Taylor Glowac: Romeo

Luce Metrius: Mercutio

BrittneyLove Smith: Nurse

Carlos Trevino: Friar

 

Our first production: Shakespeare's Romeo & Juliet

 

 

 On Tap in the Tub

WHAT IS UNIQUE ABOUT OUR APPROACH?

The story of Romeo & Juliet reveals a bright glimpse of something worth longing for: a purity in love - a passion that ignites just as rapidly as it is extinguished.  This glimpse challenges our ideas of worth and of the value of a happy ending.  To see evidence of our greatest desires made manifest is a wish for anyone with a beating heart, but it raises hard questions: is a happy ending possible in a world that is often so cruel?  Are stars really crossed, or is Fate in our own hands?  

 

Everyone knows the story of Romeo & Juliet; but when we see a great production of it we want so badly for these two characters to live and love that we can't help but cheer for them to survive, even when we know the tragic ending from the start. We want to give our audience their most passionate experience of an epic journey that constantly ricochets between absolute joy and utter desperation.

 

The process that we are developing to embody the story will challenge us to confront and reconstruct how we experience language. For eight weeks we will study the text in a rigorous investigation to uncover the power of the poetry, in what we are calling Shakespeare "Labs". These Labs consist of breaking down the structures of the language in order to master the rhetoric inherent in the play. What will we discover when we stop and really dissect a word? Can we find new meanings/inspirations in words we hear on a daily basis? How do the sounds and rhythms of our language influence meaning? What is the most effective way to reach one’s core using language?  

 

The Lab process will flow into a more traditional rehearsal format in March.  We'll use what we uncovered in our Labs to create the final piece, which will culminate in three weekends of high-paced, heartfelt and sharp-witted performances.  

 

This is not just another staging of Romeo & Juliet.  We're pushing ourselves beyond our comfort zones to rediscover our connections to speech and humanity, in an environment where we welcome even failure: after all, the biggest "mistakes" can lead to fantastic breakthroughs! Our greatest wish is to not only discover our connections to Romeo & Juliet, but to inspire a transformation of our audience's relationship to the play, and give them a story to remember!

 

 

 

Don’t Miss Our Performances!

Romeo & Juliet will be performed the last three weeks of April!

April 11th - 27th:  Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays at 8:00pm

The Bughouse Theatre

2054 W. Irving Park Rd., Chicago, IL

(Just 3 Blocks West from the CTA Brown Line)

 

Why Donate to our Tub?

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR MONEY?

We're excited to continue our discovery process with Romeo & Juliet.  While we all come from different backgrounds in theatre, we are united in our passion to explore meaning and reason in new and challenging ways. We're bursting with curiosity and eager to share our findings with you.

 

First, we need your help!

 

Not only will our production team benefit from this experiment, so will you! With your donations and attendance, you’ll have the chance to get gifts and rewards from the production team, help us spread the word about  Crowded Tub, and come with us on our journey through Shakespeare’s text.

 

OUR GOAL IS TO RAISE $3,000 IN 30 DAYS

Take a look at our budget breakdown:

The Bughouse Theatre rental

$1150

Rehearsal space

$320

Marketing and printing

$380

Crew compensation

$200

Designer budgets (Costumes, Lights, Sound, Set, Props)

$350

Wardrobe during show run (Laundry and repairs)

$200

Travel expenses

$400

Fees and incidentals

$225


We're also hoping to travel to other cities, including Milwaukee and Kenosha, to perform this piece.

 

Help Us Fill Our Tub!

HERE’S HOW YOU CAN HELP MAKE OUR PROJECT HAPPEN!

We are currently raising funds for the first few stages of our development.  There are several convenient modes for donating to our campaign, and they all start by clicking “Contribute Now”.  Just follow the easy steps for filling out contact information and choose a desired donation amount.  As a gigantic “THANK YOU!” for your support, we're offering a number of perks for almost all donation levels.  The best part is that you will be helping support live independent theatre in Chicagoland!  Please feel free to leave us comments for our campaign, too, as we love to hear from our supporters!

 

Every contribution, from $1 to $1,000, counts!  No donation is too small or too large!

 

Can't Donate? — You Can Still Help!

Whether or not you are able to contribute to this campaign, you are in a position to help us reach (or surpass!) our goal. Please spread the word about our show and campaign using whatever social media and other tools you have available.

Every dollar you help raise through your friends, family, followers and contacts is as if you had donated it yourself.

 

Follow our journey as we post updates and photos! 

SEE HOW YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS HAVE HELPED!

 

VISIT our Web page!

TRANSFORM with us on our Blog!

LIKE our Facebook page!

FOLLOW us on Twitter! 

EMAIL US

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Our Story:

Pipeline Theatre Company is a downtown Manhattan-based non-profit theater company, comprised of 25 emerging actors, directors, writers and designers. The work Pipeline produces–both new and established–hopes to be a testament to the power of theater to entertain, inspire, and enlighten.

We are currently fundraising for our upcoming show, The Caucasian Chalk Circle, by Bertolt Brecht. Our goal is to mount a production of the highest quality, that challenges both our audiences and ourselves. We believe that if we can get people excited about Brecht, we have done our job.

What We Need:

We have been fundraising for this project since August, and have almost reached our goal. But we're not there yet. As the production draws near, we are reaching out to our community for any donations of any size to help us cover final costs.

Other Ways You Can Help:

BUY TICKETS! Come see this epic production when it opens March 5th. You can purchase tickets from Smarttix or by calling 212-868-4444.

story:
Our Story

Our story is the story of many artists and people who come to a point in life where they need to move on and pursue another career. Dancers like athletes have a short lived career and at some point need to be prepared to make a living doing something else. At a time when most are looking for promotions or a climb up the ladder. Dancers are starting over, some continuing education, training, and figuring out who they are and where they want to be.  

We have enlisted an amazing group of former Broadway, film and tv dancers, choreographers, educators, agents and students who are willingly giving of their time and energy to share their stories of triumph during and after their career in dance as well as reflecting on the future generation of dancers and what preparations they need to be mindful of .


The Impact

Dance is at the height of popular culture. We see it in our lives everyday in movies, videos, and television shows. Dancers spend their lives training and perfecting their craft to be able to compete in a highly saturated field and hope they are able to secure employment to sustain their lives.  What most don't consider is what happens after dancers move on, either from injury, lack of desire or age, that propels them to explore the world outside of dance.  This documentary touches on a very taboo subject in the dance community. I feel this will not only shed light on the inevitable conversations dancer's must have,but also a feeling of community in knowing that there are others that share in this unique experience and can offer resources, guidance and inspiration.


What We Need & What You Get

Other Ways You Can Help

With very little resources we have been able to shoot the promo you see here. We are now ready to move forward and shoot the rest of the amazing talent that has agreed to participate. We want this to be the best it can be and have a long life. That being said the money raised will go to all equipment needed to shoot in HD, mics, lighting and crew to run said equipment as well as all our post production needs.


You can be apart of not only my transition story but all the other dancers and career changers that feel lost and unsure about the future.  In addition to financial contributions please share with your friends, family, colleagues, post us up on your Facebook, twitter, or mention us a business meeting.  


Your support will go a long way in providing a platform for a much needed conversation that speaks to a multitude of people. Not only will it shed light on this important topic but you can bear witness to the transformation taking place in someone's life!


To everyone that takes the time to donate, share, read about and support this project I say thank you and 

Peace and blessings!

What We Need & What You Get
Other Ways You Can Help
With very little resources we have been able to shoot the promo you see here. We are now ready to move forward and shoot the rest of the amazing talent that has agreed to participate. We want this to be the best it can be and have a long life. That being said the money raised will go to all equipment needed to shoot in HD, mics, lighting and crew to run said equipment as well as all our post production needs.

You can be apart of not only my transition story but all the other dancers and career changers that feel lost and unsure about the future.  In addition to financial contributions please share with your friends, family, colleagues, post us up on your Facebook, twitter, or mention us a business meeting.  

Your support will go a long way in providing a platform for a much needed conversation that speaks to a multitude of people. Not only will it shed light on this important topic but you can bear witness to the transformation taking place in someone's life!

To everyone that takes the time to donate, share, read about and support this project I say thank you and 
Peace and blessings!

story:
“To turn aspiring professionals into working professionals…”

The Senior Performance students at TheatreVCU, in conjunction with our department’s faculty, staff, generous patrons, and other donors are harnessing our creativity, talent, and devotion to the performing arts in order to raise the funds necessary to pursue our professional destinies. The money raised will go directly toward enhancing the legitimate, professional opportunities that will be available to us as actors, singers, directors, producers, and aspiring playwrights leading up to and following graduation. 

 The money raised will help fund two trips: New York and Los Angeles. These business trips will give our students the opportunity to audition for, be introduced to, and work closely with influential industry professionals. Additionally, the students will perform a Showcase in New York City where they will have their best scenes and songs reviewed by casting directors, agents, etc. These funds will also allow TheatreVCU Seniors to participate in numerous workshops on both coasts as well as attend Actor’s Connection: the ultimate job fair for actors breaking into the professional world. 

 Most importantly, long before travel plans become a priority, the money we raise will help bring experts and industry professionals to TheatreVCU. The preparation, advice, and encouragement we receive from our guest artists will become an invaluable part of our training. By learning the nature of the business first-hand, from experienced professionals, our students are becoming better equipped and better prepared for the world of professional performance art. The purpose of this project, as an extension of the senior class, is to help raise awareness of our pursuit as well as give the outside world an up-close and personal insight into TheatreVCU’s Senior class. 

We definitely have some heavy financial demands up against us and we are doing all we can to help support ourselves and our peers. Our goal as a class is $50,000 TOTAL to fund everyone and we're doing several fundraisers to reach our goal including:
----a weekly senior challenge at our Friday Night Live Variety Show,
----bake sales as far as the eye can see
----Our Holiday Showcase, The Jingle Ball, put on entirely by the Senior Class, not to mention sending countless letters of support to gain sponsors. We've indulged in many fun activities that have brought us together in our quest to raise money, but it isn't easy. We are determined to make it. After all, the showcase must go on!

Who we are: 

We are TheatreVCU's Senior Class of 2013, full of actors, singers, dancers, comedians, writers, directors, and most importantly dreamers. We are inspired by those who came before us, those who believe in our dreams, and those who are willing to help us on our journey to success.  We are fresh, active, and driven young people and we LOVE what we do!

story:
Sundown Collaborative Theatre needs your help!

We are excited to present paper backs, a beautiful new play from a long-time Sundown collaborator, Brittany Willis. This show, the first of our 6th season, explores the story of an artist and a scholar as they navigate their way through a relationship that continuously cycles back to the beginning. 

Our $1200 Indiegogo goal is based on space/venue costs- not even factoring in our production costs as well. We appreciate any help you can provide!

About Sundown

We are proud to be rooted in Denton, which has been home to a flourishing art scene for many years. We are committed to showing that great art can be represented and supported in the DFW theatre community. In fact, we love our city so much that we’ll be offering a myriad of discounts throughout out season for audience members who support other local businesses. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, here are other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about our show! Bring friends and family to see it when it goes up!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote this campaign. Every little bit helps!

story:
Short Summary

A few months ago, we (Denise and Rod Bigner) were thinking about how much we would love to operate a place were people could come together and experience the magic of movies as a community.  We didn’t have much money but we sold our home in Orange County, California, put a down payment on a single-screen theater the heart of Historic Downtown Albany, Oregon and moved our family of four a thousand miles away.

  

With a welcoming atmosphere and a dedication to affordable pricing, we believe the Pix is an important part of the neighborhood and we hope it will play a prominent role in the continued resurgence of the downtown. Over the past few months we have come to love our new home and are happy that we went “all in”.  

Now we turn to our friends and community for the next step.  As many of you probably know, the motion picture business has changed, and the Pix must acquire a digital projector if we are going to continue to serve the community of Albany and surrounding areas.  We could really use your help so that the Pix can remain the place that many have come to love.

What We Need & What You Get

We shopped around and the the best deal we have found for a new DCI compliant projector is $36,000.  We are hoping that our friends and community will come together to help us achieve the goal.  In return for your contribution, we are offering some cool rewards.  With a range between $5 and $1,000 we believe there’s a price that will fit any budget. 

We really love the T-shirts that we’ve designed with our Pix designer the famous Scott Elliott and our stylish new friends at No Dinx, and wearing it saves you money as well. (Make sure you include a note about male or female cut and what size!)  There’s cups, tubs, stickers, private parties and more.  Even some stuff for your business.  But mostly, if we succeed, you help us continue to provide a locally-owned, friendly, neighborhood alternative to the corporate multiplex, where you can do more than just “see a movie”, you can have an experience!  

If we surpass our goal, we will use the money to purchase some additional stuff that will enhance the Pix experience, such as a silver screen (giving us the option for 3D) a caramel corn machine (yum), and perhaps even a lighted marquee so that you’ll be able to see what fantastic movies are coming your way!  

Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond donating, you can also help by getting the word out about the Pix and our campaign.  Indiegogo has some terrific share tools built right in.  We’re hoping that we can all join in and do this thing together! 

So what do you say?  Ready to help the Pix project into the future?

story:
About Us

The CAST Program (Collaborative Artists' Summer Training) has emerged in the Calgary theatre scene to fill a niche that previously required young artists (ages 15-24) to travel to Toronto, New York, or Oklahoma for similar programs. We are here to provide both a stepping stone to such endeavours as well as an option for those who want to study locally. 

The Impact

Our goal as a professional training program is to offer an experience like none other including a theatre production that is a cut above. Tuition and ticket sales cover most of our production costs, we just need some help with venue rental costs. 

We operate under the banner of the Youth Singers of Calgary (YSC) and use their facility which means if we don't meet our funding goal there is some room for forgiveness. However, YSC is a not-for-profit and relies on revenue from venue rental and as such we want to do right by them. 

Not only that, we want to go a step further and invest in the venue by raising funds to paint one of their studios black, creating a black box space for future groups to use for rehearsal, recital and theatre purposes.

What We Need & What You Get

Why are we asking for $8000? Well, the costs we're faced with split that amount right down the middle. There are actually some decimals in there but let's keep this simple.

  • rehearsal and performance venue ($4000)
  • painting the studio black ($4000)

Not only do you get the great feeling of helping young artists get on stage and have a place to perform, you can know that your investment is a long lasting investment in the arts. 

We also have some perks for you! One of the most popular in our previous fundraising project was the $100 level which got you priority seating at our shows!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially to our program may we suggest that you:

  • Come see the show! July 25 - Aug 2. Tickets only $15  http://milliecast.bpt.me
  • Volunteer with us (email us at thecastprogram@gmail.com)
  • Share this campaign with others.

Thank you, thank you, thank you. Any and all support is appreciated.
