story:
Be A Part of the Arts Live Theatre Magic!

Watch scenes from the ALT production of 'Shrek' - just one of our terrific productions!

Arts Live Theatre makes a significant difference in the lives of its children, youth and their families through its classes, workshops and Broadway-style productions. 

Arts Live Theatre, located in Fayetteville Arkansas, is producing 'Annie, Jr: The Musical' in April, 2016, and we invite you to be a part of the magic.

The goal is to raise $5,000 to help pay for production costs, as our outstanding musicals average $12,000 to produce.

When you contribute to Arts Live Theatre you are supporting the organization's exceptional programming and providing an opportunity for all children and youth, including the under served community. 

Your contribution makes an impact!

story:
THE SHOW

Weed lube, throuple therapy, & one life-altering text message. With an open mind, heart, and vagina, KEEPING MY KIDNEYS challenges the romantic comedy narrative and the roles we play in it. Writer and performer Mindy Raf demystifies love, loss, and sexuality and engages her vulnerable, razor-sharp storytelling style to face the complexities of modern love and leave us asking, “could I ever do that?”

KEEPING MY KIDNEYS  had a great debut in NYC this past year with SOLD OUT shows at the PIT Loft and stellar reviews and features by: GO Magazine, Time Out New York, Theatre Is Easy, Effort Lez, Cynical Magazine, and Hy Reviews. Now we want to share this story with international audiences, and we need your help!

WHY?

This show is deeply personal and so important to me. The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world and a wonderful opportunity to create an international conversation through comedy and storytelling about how we're taught to define love and ourselves through our relationships. 

How will an international  audience respond to: stories about weed lube and identity, learning about new relationship structures, and hearing my vagina sing ? I have absolutely no idea. 

But I'm really excited to find out in August.

 

BETTER REPRESENTION

A major newspaper recently published a cover story on open relationships that was narrow in scope and failed to accurately represent ethical non-monogamy. It also didn't represent lesbian, bisexual, pansexual, queer, or trans identities. When we represent and tell our own stories we can break the barriers that stand in the way of normalizing the unconventional. Taking this story to Edinburgh will create a platform for this representation and hopefully stir up this important conversation.

 

WHAT DO WE NEED?

Our initial fundraising goal is $8000. We do not stand to make a profit on the Edinburgh run, only cover costs.  Anything raised beyond our initial goal will go toward paying people for their time, energy, and talents during the life of the show.

Here’s a breakdown of how the money raised will be utilized:

 

 

Transportation & Housing
Will need to purchase flight from NYC to Edinburgh and rent a room to stay for the full month of August. The population more than doubles during the fringe and housing is at peak prices.
Publicity & Marketing
Our goal is to share this story with as many people as possible. As there are over 3,000 shows across 300+ venues, publicity and marketing (outreach, poster / flyer design and printing) is key. 
Venue & Festival Fees
There are many fees that add up when taking a show to a festival of this scale such as registration, festival program, and insurance.
Production Team
I’m lucky to be working with Edinburgh-based live arts production company, Civil Disobedience as well as director Tara Elliott who was instrumental in developing the show and during its residency at the PIT Loft. In the demanding, exciting world of the Fringe, it's important to have support on the ground as well as work with a director in preparation to acclimate the show to a new space.

HOW ELSE CAN I HELP?

In addition to a donation, you can help by sharing the show and this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter.  #KeepingMyKidneys  

And if you've already had a chance to see the show, please talk about it. A lot. Be that person that makes your friends go, "Enough already about KEEPING MY KIDNEYS, but yes it does sound like a fantastic show."  

If you've seen the show and are feeling it, you can post or send Mindy along a testimonial :

And come out to see a show!

NYC: JULY 19 8:30PM & 22- 23 2:30 PM at 59E59

Tickets 

Edinburgh: AUGUST 2 - 28 at the Gilded Balloon.

story:
HI!

My name is Derrian Tolden. In 2007, I won the title of Miss Gay Louisiana America under my female impersonation stage name, Chelsea DeLorean Divine. That year I placed 6th (1 point from top 5) at Miss Gay America out of 50+ contestants.  It has now been 7 years since that wonderful experience. Competing at Miss Gay Southern Elegance America has now qualified me to strive for the title of Miss Gay America 2015!

 From my first experience watching former Miss Gay Louisiana Americas and Miss Gay Americas I knew I wanted to join the ranks of such a prestigious  history and world-class entertainment. Pageants can be an expensive but rewarding endeavor. With your help we can bring Chelsea Divine Across America as the national "Symbol of Excellence". 

Your Contribution

Helps with:

  • Travel (round-trip airfare Los Angeles-->Nashville)
  • Hotel ( 5 nights)
  • Hair Care (Presentation,Evening Gown, Talent, Solo Talent)
  • Costume Care (Presentation, Evening Gown, Talent, Solo Talent, Male Interview)
  • Marketing (MGA program ad, Business/postcards, Miss Photogenic)

    THANK YOU!

    Your contribution is greatly welcomed and appreciated. This campaign does have a goal but if I it is not met your contribution will still go towards National Excellence. I just have to pay a higher fee. So help me make this destiny apart of yours!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Share this with anyone you know that loves the art of female impersonation, LGBT rights, and/or just plain ENTERTAINMENT!

story:
Austin Shakespeare and Red Then Productions are bringing Robert Faires' Solo Version of Shakespeare's "Henry V" to the Long Center's Rollins Theater Sept. 5-14.

  • Austin Shakespeare has been producing plays for more than 30 years.  Robert Faires won "The Mt. Everest Award" from the Austin Critics Table in his first production of this show.
  • We feel deeply that young audiences will be inspired and moved by this production.  Your contribution will help make student tickets more affordable.
  • In a time when classic live theater often seems distant, we know that the high school and college students have been captivated by this production's story and its message.

We need your support and we'd love to give you some perks!

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • If you help us reach our $2,500 goal we can underwrite 100 student tickets. If we  go over our goal we can reach even more students!
  • Check out  your unique perks!

  • $25 – your name in our program

    $50 – you get a signed program

    $100 – you receive a signed poster of Henry V

    $150 – you get a T-shirt with Henry V logo!

    $200 – you get a signed script by Robert Faires!

    Please know that Even if don't reach our goal, whatever you contribute will underwrite as many student tickets as possible!

The Impact

We know that young people want to see this innovative production.   If you value Shakespeare's superb language, his insight into every person's journey through life, and the power of live theater to transform us through imagination, you will be making a contribution to support your values.

You can trust Austin Shakespeare and Red Then productions, we have both produced successful plays and gotten the most out of every dollar raised!

Fundraising is always a challenge

  • We know there are many worthy causes.
  • We believe that our friends and colleagues believe in this work enough to help this specific campaign.

Even if you can't contribute

Help us get the word out!

  • Talk abt us  on Facebook, Tweet about us!  Use Indiegogo Share Tools!
  • Come and See the Show.

Wherever you are in the world your contribution will help keep this show alive.  We hope to bring it around the country and perhaps… around the world to your world!

the Austin Critics Table in his first production of this show. We feel deeply that young audiences will be inspired and moved by this production.  Your contribution will help make student tickets more affordable. In a time when classic live theater often seems distant, we know that the high school and college students have been captivated by this production's story and its message.

  We need your support and we'd love to give you some perks! Break it down for folks in more detail: 
If you help us reach our $2,500 goal we can underwrite 100 student tickets. If we  go over our goal we can reach even more students!
Check out  your unique perks!

$25 – your name in our program
$50 – you get a signed program
$100 – you receive a signed poster of Henry V
$150 – you get a T-shirt with Henry V logo!
$200 – you get a signed script by Robert Faires!
Please know that Even if don't reach our goal, whatever you contribute will underwrite as many student tickets as possible!
 
  The Impact 

We know that young people want to see this innovative production.   If you value Shakespeare's superb language, his insight into every person's journey through life, and the power of live theater to transform us through imagination, you will be making a contribution to support your values.
You can trust Austin Shakespeare and Red Then productions, we have both produced successful plays and gotten the most out of every dollar raised!
  Fundraising is always a challenge 
We know there are many worthy causes. We believe that our friends and colleagues believe in this work enough to help this specific campaign. 
  Even if you can't contribute Help us get the word out! 
Talk abt us  on Facebook, Tweet about us!  Use Indiegogo Share Tools! Come and See the Show. 
 Wherever you are in the world your contribution will help keep this show alive.  We hope to bring it around the country and perhaps… around the world to your world!

story:
Stage 1: Pollination 

Petals is the story of one girl's journey to the night of a lifetime. Written entirely in verse, Petals takes a vibrant look at what it means to be a sexually awakened in a city where school nuns shame, school boys leer, where less is more and no means yes and  the beer-soaked nightclub is sanctuary. 

Roadkill Productions is a new company that finds beauty in the obscene -  we aim to tell stories with beating hearts, teeth and claws, and a wicked sense of humour.

Following on from the success of Goodnight, Rabbit at The Collaborations Festival in February, Roadkill Productions is delighted to present Petals as the final show at Theatre Upstairs for 2014!

As we are a brand spanking new company, Roadkill Productions and the work we produce is entirely unfunded, so to get this show on the road, we're gonna need a little help from our friends...

New work is nothing without the support of the public, and any support you can give - from €5 to €500, from a kind word to a share on a Facebook page, is priceless to us and to our show.

Stage 2: Fertilisation 

The story of Petals is one of unexpected beginnings: originally a scrawl on the back of a Winnie-the-Pooh notebook, Petals gradually became a twenty minute radio play named Meat and Blue WKD, performed on Midlands Radio as part of the Scripts Festival. The graphic content of the piece courted some controversy and sparked an on-air debate about female sexuality and consent. Spurred on by the its ability to get people talking, writer Gillian Greer delved deeper into the story, in the hopes of creating a play that pushed boundaries both stylistically and thematically. In the meantime, Meat and Blue WKD picked up Silver at the National PPI Radio Awards.

In Petals, we hope to have gone one step further and created something that is both hard hitting, powerful and astonishingly beautiful. It is also Roadkill's first full production and tells a story that is close to our hearts and to the hearts of many women around the country and indeed, around the world.

Stage 3: Seed Formation

Roadkill Productions are blessed in that we have gathered a truly remarkable team to bring this production from the page to the stage, including:

Cast / Kate Gilmore

Director / Karl Shiels

Set Design / Laura Honan

Lighting Design / Eoin Stapleton

Sound Design + Composition / Derek Conaghy 

Assistant Director / Clodagh Mooney Duggan

Visual Design / Ste Murray 

With a stellar script by Gillian Greer and co-produced by the writer and Mark'O Brien in association with Theatre Upstairs.

This team of incredibly talented and hard working theatre makers have dedicated themselves to creating a spectacular show that will not disappoint.

Stage 4: Seed Dispersal 

The big question: Where is the money going? 

The money we are asking for is going towards building our set, creating our costume and make-up design, producing our publicity materials and all of those unexpected costs which crop up with a new production.

Again, the support you give is vital to seeing this production realised - we cannot stress our appreciation enough.

Stage 5: Germination 

Our aim in this show is to tell a story worth the telling, one that will send shivers down your spine and leave your heart in your throat. With an exciting script, monstrously talented cast and crew and a great, big determined vision we believe that Petals can deliver this and so much more - but now we need your help. Your generosity will not go unrewarded as we have cobbled together a number of tokens of our appreciation as rewards for our donators, but nothing can outshine our deep and unending gratitude for each and every contribution!

We are over the moon to have the chance to bring this story to life - we hope you'll join us for the ride!!

story:
We are the Charleston Performing Arts Center, a new 501(c)(3) non-profit arts organization, whose mission is to inspire, invigorate and educated through artistic excellence in the performing arts.

Our vision is to provide world-class conservatory education focused on pre-professional musical theatre technique. This training includes a full curriculum for teens and adults in acting, voice and dance developed by, and under the supervision of, renowned masters. Our scholarship program will ensure that arts education is available to those who are typically unable to afford it.

The Conservatory will also be host to a year-round Master Class Series and two intensive programs in Charleston and New York City. Students will be inspired and coached by Broadway performers, directors, choreographers, and technicians who will enhance the education and skill of the students. Broadway Faculty includes (left to right): Stephanie Samaras, MaryAnn Lamb, Patrick DeGennaro, Caitlin Carter, Lyn Philistine, Christopher Sutton, (photo not included) Cherie Bower, Mary Carpenter, Kurt Domoney.


The Charleston Performing Arts Center will also be a performance venue to provide opportunities for Conservatory students to perform alongside Broadway guest artists. This venue will also enable us to open our doors to local emerging artists who struggle to find affordable venues to showcase their talent.

In June of 2014 we offered a week-long musical theatre intensive in New York City for a group of 20 locals ranging from 13 to 40, all who shared a common desire: to better themselves and improve their technique in musical theatre. They all share an intense passion and dream of performing on Broadway. We nurtured that passion and gave them a glimpse of what it is like for a professional studying/working in NYC. 

Kirk Sprinkles (C-PAC Artistic Director) organized the intensive, from hotel and flight accommodations; to hiring each instructor, finding rehearsal space, and coordinating a rigorous schedule to include seven master classes, three Broadway shows, and a la carte classes at Broadway Dance Center and STEPS on Broadway. They also had time to enjoy the city and its sites! This work was nothing new to Sprinkles who has coordinated these intensives for the past seven years.

 “As a child who grew up in a small Southern town, I knew firsthand how it feels to want something so bad and not have the local resources to help guide me towards the direction of my dream. At the early age of 16, I knew what I wanted to do and achieve, to perform on Broadway and later return to the South to open a center that would provide the level of training, mentoring and experience that would help others like myself,” says Sprinkles.

“Since then, I have been fortunate enough to achieve just that. I moved to NYC and performed on Broadway in Tap Dogs, Radio City’s Christmas Spectacular and have performed around the world in touring shows.”

“For the past 15 years I have focused on training and mentoring others with their pursuit of performing on the Great White Way and it has been one of the most rewarding things of my life! I have former students who have performed on Broadway, National tours, cruise lines, theme parks, and dance companies. I want to continue inspiring and preparing others like-minded individuals for careers in musical theatre.”

“To be able to do something you enjoy is a gift but to be able to do what you love is a blessing.” “I can’t help but feel that if more people were given the proper tools, they too might follow their dreams and experience great success.”

 

(photo courtesy of BroadwayWorld.com: C-PAC Artistic Director hosting Broadway event at Sardi's Restaurant with Tony Award-winning directors Kathleen Marshall, Jerry Mitchell, and Broadway celebrities Charlotte d'Amboise, Joshua Bergasse, and Krisha Marcano.)


A vision and mission is one thing, but making it manifest is another. It takes more than just passion and desire: it requires a space, equipment, and a great deal of funding!

We are actively looking at several locations to house both our conservatory and theatre venue. We feel confident that we will have a lease signed in the month. Your contributions will help us refurbish the exterior and interior of the space we assume and make this vision a reality. The conservatory space requires a sprung floor, mirrors, and barres; the performance venue needs an elevated stage, a dressing area, and all the technical equipment that goes along with it (lights, sound, curtains, etc.).


A LITTLE MORE ABOUT US 

Like most great companies, we started in a garage! (photo: cast of 2013 holiday show)

For the past year we have produced and rehearsed original full-scale musicals, conducted performing arts classes including ballet, voice, jazz and tap classes, and musical theatre intensives, all in a 20 x 20 garage. Most recently we produced an original musical conceived and written by our executive team Scott Pfeiffer and Kirk Sprinkles. The dance musical "The Charleston" was accepted into the 2014 Piccolo Spoleto Festival and performed seven sold out performances! We have also performed corporate events for nearly a dozen community and civic events in the area, including: The North Charleston Pops!, Charleston CVB, Charleston Hotelier's Association, Dragon Boat Annual Fundraiser, as well as teaching theatre arts in the Charleston and Berkley County Schools through Engaging Creative Minds.

(photo courtesy of Engaging Creative Minds: C-PAC Artistic Director teaches kids tap)

Your support is needed and the time is NOW! Our target to open our doors to the public is October 6th, 2014. We have a short amount of time to accomplish this enormous undertaking but I have faith that we will find the support through those who love the arts and perhaps had a similar dream as a young adult.  


WHAT HAPPENS IF YOU DO NOT RAISE THE FULL $25,000?

No matter what, we will open our doors. We may not be able to complete all of the cosmetics, but we intend to continue to raise funds until our performing arts center is fully functional. The conservatory is first on our list of priorities. 


WHAT IF I CANNOT AFFORD TO CONTRIBUTE?

First, we accept all gift amounts. Remember, every cent counts! Another way you can contribute is by donating materials, equipment, or even something as simple as spreading the word of our cause to others. If you are interested in donating materials or equipment and would like to peruse our WISH LIST, visit our website www.CharlestonPerformingArts.org/wishlist 


HOW WILL YOUR DONATION IMPACT OTHERS?

Your donation will directly benefit the conservatory's mission and services. In another words, your gift will help others receive the training and opportunities to further them in their career development and put them one step one step closer to reaching their dream!


WHAT OBSTACLES MAY WE FACE AND HOW WILL WE OVERCOME THEM?

Our biggest concern at this point is the construction and modifications that will affect the City's zoning codes and permits. We will first open our doors as a conservatory and, as funds permit, we will make the required modifications to open as a theatre and conservatory. 


DO YOU HAVE ANY EXPERIENCE IN STARTING A BUSINESS SUCH AS THIS?

Yes. Our Artistic Director has successfully owned and operated a similar dance and performing arts studio. He and his father built the entire interior, including floating floors, and a black box theatre. Mr. Sprinkles also served as the managing director for a professional ballet company in NYC and as general manager for a professional dinner theatre for nearly four years. He also currently serves as the Honorary Chairman for the Program Development Committee for the national non-profit organization Career Transition For Dancers in NYC. 


CAN I SIGN UP AS A VOLUNTEER?

Absolutely! In fact, if you have the time to help with the cosmetic construction of our building, we will be working around the clock until its complete. Bring your tools and we will gladly put you to work! For more information on becoming a volunteer, contact our executive director scott.pfeiffer@charlestonperformingarts.org.

story: We are putting on the show Beyond Therapy by Christopher Durang on January 10th, 11th, and 12th. We are completely committed to this hilarious comedy, but do not have incredibly powerful, rich, billionaire, or even millionaire, investors and are hoping on our lovely friends, family members, and random investors that made it on to this page to invest in our fun-filled production. We are aiming to put on more shows in the future and eventually become a theater company. Please help us reach our dreams and help us to create, laugh, and grow by donating a little bit. Each dollar you add actually will help to create something, including: insurance, the theater, the costumes, and the playbills. Please donate to our show.

story:
We are so close to our target and the campaign ends tonight! To everyone who has donated, shared or spread the word in some way thank you so much. We really appreciate your support and are overwhelmed by your generosity! We are unbelievably excited about taking such a good step forward towards our goal, especially with only 3 days left! Please continue to share and spread the word.

Just six months after coming together, Spectra Theatre Company has been chosen for not one but three festivals this summer. And we need your help! Our debut production, 'After Penelope', after a sell-out run at the White Bear in Kennington in November 2014, has been selected for the Rome International Fringe Festival and the RADA Festival here in London. Then, in August, we’re creating a new piece, Harry’s Girls, for the Camden Fringe Festival.


Wait, who are we?

For those of you who don’t know us; Spectra was formed in 2014 by six international graduates from East 15 Acting School. Our aim is to tell compelling stories from a female perspective. RADA graduate Colleen Prendergast joined us as director/co-writer for our first show, 'After Penelope', which means we are an all-female group committed to bringing striking, arresting theatre to the widest audience possible. 

So why are we raising money?

As a new company, we know how important it is to get our work out there and establish our presence. We plan to achieve all of this on an insanely shoestring budget, but we do need some funds to cover plane tickets, rehearsal space, marketing, props and costume etc.

We need to raise £2372 to cover the cost of our summer season for our seven company members. If, by some miracle, we raise more than our goal, the difference will go towards developing further work and setting up our next show.

We know £2372 sounds like a lot, but here is a breakdown to explain:

Rome International Festival

Flights: £60/total: £420
Bags: £34/total: £238
Transport: £17/total: £119
Food: £30/total: £210
Marketing: £60/total: £60
TOTAL for ROME: £1047

RADA Festival

Technical support: £30
Poster/flyer printing: £30
TOTAL: £60

Camden Fringe Festival 

RADA studios bar (3rd-4th August 2015)
Space rental: £87.50/total: £175
Technical rehearsal fee: £50
Poster/flyer printing: £30
Camden Fringe Festival listing fee: £150
TOTAL: £405
Upstairs at the Gatehouse theatre, Highgate (18th-20th August 2015)
Space rental: £50/total: £150
Poster/flyer printing: £30
Technical support: £50
Camden Fringe Festival listing fee: £150
TOTAL: £380
ADDITIONAL EXTRAS
Rehearsal space: £10/hour at Theatre Delicatessen/total: £280
Props and costume: £200
TOTAL EXTRAS: £480
TOTAL FOR CAMDEN FRINGE: £1265

Spectra's summer season total: £2372


ANYTHING you can give will enable us to firmly establish this fledgling company on the international scene, create new female-centric work, and in time, allow us to extend opportunities to other female theatre practitioners. 

Some of the perks available to you in exchange for your donation: 

- Signed flyers 

- Signed posters 

- Signed copy of the script 

- Personalised video thank you

- A mention in our programme as a sponsor/donor


Anything you can contribute will be very gratefully received, but you can help in other ways too! Please share this campaign across social media - Twitter, Facebook etc - you can use Indiegogo’s share tool to make it easier. 

Thank you once again, and we’d love to meet you if you come to see one (or both) of our shows! Get in touch via Twitter or our website - let us know when you’ll be in so we can thank you in person. Hope to see you soon!

Anything you can contribute will be very gratefully received, but you can help in other ways too! Please share this campaign across social media - Twitter, Facebook etc - you can use Indiegogo’s share tool to make it easier. 


Thank you once again, and we’d love to meet you if you come to see one (or both) of our shows! Get in touch via Twitter or our website - let us know when you’ll be in so we can thank you in person.

Hope to see you soon!

story:
Easy Street Productions and The Ottawa Children’s Theatre are collaborating to produce Up to Low, based on the book by Brian Doyle and adapted for the stage by Janet Irwin. 

Up to Low is a story of the Ottawa Valley in the 1950s, and one boy's story of loss, love and courage is its centre. A play filled with music and heart, Up to Low runs May 21 – June 6 at the Arts Court Studio Theatre in Ottawa.

This is a show for family audiences. It's set in a tavern, with humour so sly that all ages will have fun. And there’s music! Intrigued?

What We Need

Your generous support helps fund:

  • Talent! We’ve got some of the best of the best! You'll help support performers (8 actors and 3 musicians), designers (Set, Costumes, Lights, Sound), as well as our award-winning Musical Composer Ian Tamblyn and award-winning Director Janet Irwin.

You'll also help us to build the world we need to recreate:

  • Sets – an Ottawa Valley tavern, Hwy 5 north to Low, the Gatineau River
  • Costumes – Ottawa/Gatineau Valley, 1950
  • Props – the objects carried by the performers: Aunt Dottie’s spray gun, Frank’s stew pot, a rowboat, a coffin
  • Lights/Sound – the theatrical effects that create moonlight on the Gatineau, a hailstorm on a hot day, the sound of the electrical generators of the dam in Low, Quebec
  • Venue rental - Arts Court Library for rehearsals, Arts Court Studio for performances

& What You Get

  • Your selection of perks, including dress rehearsal tickets, a signed copy of Up to Low (the novel),  a copy of the poster, tax receipts
  • The satisfaction of supporting a great local initiative celebrating an Ottawa Valley story, written by an Ottawa Valley writer, with a local cast and crew

The Impact

Your support is hugely important.  Your donation inspires others to donate. When you forward this campaign to friends and family, you help us reach our goal quicker and more surely.

In a period when support to the arts is diminishing, the awareness of art’s essential contribution to human growth and development is becoming more and more understood. You are helping to enrich your community!

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a professional show is tough, let alone one with 8 actors and three musicians! But we are two independent producers, risking it all, to put on this show because we know you'll love it!

We've spent two years in pre-production (not to mention 10 years developing the script) and are ready to bring Up to Low  to the stage. We've been working hard and have government and foundation support, great corporate sponsors and many people, just like you, who are providing funds to help make Up to Low  a reality. It's a huge undertaking for a grass roots organization, and we are almost there.

With your support we can transform a former court room into a down-home Valley pub and take you on a memorable journey from Lowertown, Ottawa, to Low, Quebec.

Other Ways You Can Help

We known not everyone can donate large amounts, but believe us when we say we appreciate anything you can do! There are easy and fun ways to help:

  • Share this information through whatever media you can. We need a network and would like to start with you!
  • Come to see the show!
  • Read some Brian Doyle to yourself and the young people in your life.
  • Volunteer to work Front of House or at the bar.
  • Spread the word!

story:
In Celebration of Our Ninth Year of Amazing Contemporary Dance, Hart Pulse Dance Company is Taking Our Show on the Road!

Hart Pulse Dance Company is celebrating our ninth year as one of LA's most prominent dance companies by taking the show on the road for our first California tour!  

After wrapping our eighth and most successful season, we are realizing that now is the perfect time to tour and share our hard work with other cities who also love dance.  Our board of directors and dancers have chosen the best of the best, most audience-loved works to take to San Francisco, San Diego, Santa Barbara, Visalia and finally back home to Santa Monica for our final wrap-up performance.  

Each of these cities holds its own, individual excitement for us!  San Diego and Santa Barbara both boast dance communities we hold close to our hearts that have not only welcomed us to participate in their own festivals and showcases, but have also been longtime participants in Hart Pulse Dance Company's annual MixMatch Dance Festival.  San Francisco is known for its rich artistic dance community and is the farthest city we will be reaching on our tour.  Our dancers are so excited to perform in this beautiful city and contact so many different dance supporters.  

As the home town of director, Amanda Hart, Visalia holds a very special place in our tour lineup.  The small farm towns of the Central Valley have a warm community of dance enthusiasts who have been requesting Hart Pulse Dance Company performances for many years now.  We are thrilled to finally be able to bring Miss Hart back to her home town and present her company in the place in which her dance journey began.  

At the end of August Hart Pulse Dance Company will present our Ninth Annual MixMatch Dance Festival at our home stage, the Miles Playhouse in Santa Monica.  In 2014 we were thrilled when MixMatch was listed by the New York Times in its "things to do and see this week” feature as one of the eight best things to do around the world for the weekend!   Next year MixMatch will not only set the stage for over 60 dance companies from across the United States, but will wrap up our California tour with Hart Pulse Dance Company’s final 2015 performance.  

After tickets sales and silent auction proceeds, we still need your help with production costs, including costumes, theater rentals, travel expenses, liability insurance, dancer pay, videographers and photographers, crew & union pay, advertising and promotion.  

Our biggest expenses this year will be dancer compensation, travel expenses and promotion.  Our dancers will be dancing more than they've ever danced before and are so excited to be on so many stages!  This is our first year working with travel expenses and promoting shows from far away.  We are an LA community-based company and rely on local connections and footwork to promote our performances.  Because we will be venturing outward from Los Angeles for the first time, 2015 will require a lot of print advertising to assist in getting the word out about Hart Pulse Dance Company’s visits to these amazing cities.  Newspapers, online ads, posters, thousands of postcards, outreach promotions and so much more will be a vital to our tour’s exposure and success.  

Consistency in performances, quality and presence are essential to helping Hart Pulse Dance Company become a company ultimately recognized as a vital part of the cultural life of Los Angeles, California and the United States.  We want Hart Pulse Dance Company to be a household name; a dance company that audiences look to for solid, beautiful performance that will be around for years to come.  

Your financial support fuels our mission: Providing affordable, professional, great dance to our community and beyond.  Your physical support, seeing you at our shows, is what we work so hard for.  The verbal encouragement we hear from our audiences fuels us to return year after year.   

By supporting Hart Pulse’s 2015 season, you go above and beyond in assisting the growth of Hart Pulse Dance Company and dance in California.  You are promoting the creation of a solid contemporary dance company in Los Angeles, allowing stronger roots to be planted in an effort to launch Hart Pulse Dance Company further into the realm of sustainability.  You are, truly, patrons of the arts.

We've put together some fun "thank you" gifts for contributing and assisting our first tour!  We hope you can feel our passion for what we do.  And we hope that you also feel empowered and passionate about dance and Hart Pulse Dance Company.  Thank you so much for contributing!  We hope to see you throughout our current season at one of our shows.  We know you will love what you see and leave wanting more! 

Please share our campaign with your friends and family.  Follow us on Facebook (hart-pulse dance-company) and stay up to speed on when and where we're performing next!

story:
This is Eurydice

 

In September of 2011, we shared Eurydice in Market East with audiences for the first time at the Philly Fringe festival. While we felt that the art we were creating was strong, we were still surprised by how much it affected those who got to see it. People talked about the piece. People discovered things about their own society through the piece. Some people even came back to see it again.

 

We want to continue the talking.

 

Eurydice in Market East is powerful because it is a found text piece. Here, trapped in her own subway station of an underworld, Eurydice finds a voice to call her own. But as someone who is always spoken about, not someone who speaks - someone who exists entirely as a figure in the story of another - the only language she has at her disposal is that of the world around her. In short, she does not have recourse to self-generate language. She can only piece together bits of language and phrases she has stumbled on to express herself.

 

Found text. Eurydice tries to explore the big issues with only the language she has found, from poetry to teen magazines. What happens when you try to describe life, heartbreak, art, and existence itself with the language of Shakespeare to car advertisements to the sound of an escalator? As Eurydice struggles to understand her story, we begin to see how our own world understands love, music, death, all those big questions. We see how our culture interprets - even packages - those ideas.

 

And that is why the inability to generate one's own language leads to so much talking.

 

A New Station

 

We want to take this conversation to New York - to interact with a new audience, to listen to more people. We want to be able to share what we found and become part of the discussion that develops. Eurydice will hit the stages of New York City in mid-June of 2012 to continue to spark conversation about culture and language and what it means to live and love and maybe even die. We want to grow with our audience through asking each other the big questions. We want this art to grow into new pieces that can engage our communities.

 

 

Why We Need Your Help

 

We suspect that all artists wish that their work could be separated from the constraints of money. That art could be financially accessible to larger audiences because there were fewer debts to pay up the chain. That no one ever had to choose between integrity of vision and cost. But because this is not the case, we need your help.

 

Here are a list of things of things we need money for:

  • Our largest cost will be renting the space. Though we have found an artist-centric space that tries to keep its rents as low as possible, we still need around $1000 for a 3 or 4 day run.
  • Transportation to and from NYC. We should be able to travel as a group there once - before tech - and return once, but it still ads up, even on discount buses.
  • Marketing. It is more important than we like to admit, and more costly. But it is necessary if we want the conversation to happen. Theatre is about bringing people together, which can only happen if people know when and where to go.
  • Insurance is pricy, and we always hope we won't have claim any of it. But it is important. Spaces require proof of insurance before they will rent to you, and with good reason.

 

We will need to pay for these as part of producing this show and any future shows. Whatever you contribute will go directly into funding these types of costs.

 

As a Thank You

Everyone who contributes will get a personal shout-out through our Facebook page. We will also list you as one of our supporters on our blog (QWERTY contributor). Everyone who donates above the "Sound Sequence" or "Syllable Sequence" levels will also receive the same chance to ask a question as listed in those contributor level perks.

 

Please see the list for full descriptions and additional perks. Also, watch for possible additions to the list!

 

More Ways You Can Help - The Talk on this Platform

We need help spreading the word about this campaign. By sharing this site with your friends, you give us two things: (1) you introduces us to more people who might contribute, and (2) you broaden our audience. While the first is the reason for this campaign, the second is the reason for the art. The more people who know about and thus can participate in the artistic conversation, the more we can all learn from each other.

 

So how can you spread the word?

 

Please, share this with everyone you know, even if you cannot contribute funds at this time. Use all those networking sites like Facebook and Twitter. There are even buttons on this page to make it easier! Email this to your parents.  Post this to your cousins through your blog.

 

Drop in on our Facebook page and convince your friends to subscribe to our WordPress blog. Commenting on this very contribution page will in itself increase our visibility on this website.

 

Thank you for your support. We want to share with you and hear what you have to say. We cannot wait to continue this conversation.

 

 

More Art at the End of the Tunnel

Even if we reach our funding goals to make Eurydice in Grand Central a reality, we are not going to stop finding ways to keep our costs low. And any money that we raise beyond the costs of the show will be directed towards future projects. Consider it a 2+ for 1 special - donations will go towards this project and, with a little luck and a lot of generosity, the art that these experiences and conversations leads to next.

 

Image Credits:

Photos from the September 2011 production of Eurydice in Market East

Photographer: Valerie Giacobbe

Lighting Designer: Ashley W. Mills

Pictured Performers: Carolina Millard, Nina Giacobbe, Samantha Rose Swab, Ashely Alter

story:
*** GOOD NEWS! A generous supporter has pledged to match all donations made by the deadline, up to a total of $750! So that means we are already more than half way to our goal! Can you help us reach the goal TODAY??


Who We Are & What We Do

We are the artist collective behind “Dare to Dance,” a professional-quality showcase for original dances created and performed by dance enthusiasts of all ages and skill levels. Since its inception in 2010, we have independently produced four successful shows involving over 100 performers, spanning the spectrum from professional dancers to total newbies. Their ages ranged from 7 to 60+; their “day jobs” included professions like postman, teacher, scientist, nurse, and social worker. As a celebration of passion and creativity, the show is loved by both the dancers and the audience.

"We loved it! So much creativity and joy expressed. It was infectious." (Audience quote)

We just performed "Dare to Dance 4: It's Time" on Apr 25-26 at Broadway Performance Hall and it was fantastic!! We had a sizable audience and they had a great time. Even so, not all production expenses were covered by box office income, and a large chunk fell onto the shoulders of our choreographers and volunteer staff, many of whom already carried expenses for "Dare to Dance 3" last year. As much as we love what we do, this is not a sustainable financial model.

What We Need & What You Get

An additional funding of $2,000 will allow us to reimburse our choreographers and staff for basic production expenses like rehearsal rental, set building, hired technicians, posters and programs, etc. Furthermore, we will use the remaining funds to formally establish "Dare to Dance" the non-profit organization, covering costs like license fees, D&O insurance, website hosting, etc. The non-profit organization will continue to grow the Dare to Dance movement with annual shows, classes and workshops, experimental performances, and other fun, unique events.

Consider this: Being an official non-profit will enable us to attract more funding, donations, staff, and volunteers. So your funding will not only cover us for "Dare to Dance 4," it will also secure the future of "Dare to Dance"!

In return, we are offering you great perks from "Dare to Dance," all the way up to a lifetime VIP status! Check the perks list for details.

Why Support Us?

While there are many other dance and art organizations doing great work, we believe "Dare to Dance" brings something unique to the table. On the performer side, it's a rare opportunity for non-professional dancers and choreographers to bring their artistic expressions to a wider audience in a professional venue. Some dancers are enthusiasts who have always dreamed of performing on stage; some are developing artists eager to refine their craft. Many of our choreographers, including several teenagers, had never created their own dance numbers before our shows. On the audience side, the show's accessible nature and wide range of dance styles provide a diversely entertaining experience for the audience, and attract many people who don’t typically attend dance shows. In doing so, “Dare to Dance” bridges the traditional gap between the professional dance community and the broader community of dance enthusiasts and dance fans. Finally, "Dare to Dance" also encourages innovation through group collaborations and fusion with other art forms (such as live singing and video media).

"I loved the passion, the realness of it all… Congratulations on putting together an ambitious, evocative and completely enjoyable performance. I will look forward to future productions!" (Audience quote)

Other Ways to Help

If you are not in a position to donate, you can still help us by spreading the word about our campaign! The more people hear about us, the more we can make a splash. We are also always open to volunteers both short-term and long-term.

Check out our website! http://daretodanceseattle.org

Some videos from past shows: http://youtube.com/daretodanceseattle

Check the perks list for details.Why Support Us?While there are many other dance and art organizations doing great work, we believe "Dare to Dance" brings something unique to the table. On the performer side, it's a rare opportunity for non-professional dancers and choreographers to bring their artistic expressions to a wider audience in a professional venue. Some dancers are enthusiasts who have always dreamed of performing on stage; some are developing artists eager to refine their craft. Many of our choreographers, including several teenagers, had never created their own dance numbers before our shows. On the audience side, the show's accessible nature and wide range of dance styles provide a diversely entertaining experience for the audience, and attract many people who don’t typically attend dance shows. In doing so, “Dare to Dance” bridges the traditional gap between the professional dance community and the broader community of dance enthusiasts and dance fans. Finally, "Dare to Dance" also encourages innovation through group collaborations and fusion with other art forms (such as live singing and video media)."I loved the passion, the realness of it all… Congratulations on putting together an ambitious, evocative and completely enjoyable performance. I will look forward to future productions!" (Audience quote)Other Ways to HelpIf you are not in a position to donate, you can still help us by spreading the word about our campaign! The more people hear about us, the more we can make a splash. We are also always open to volunteers both short-term and long-term.Check out our website! http://daretodanceseattle.orgSome videos from past shows: http://youtube.com/daretodanceseattle

story:
"We need your financial support to be able to purchase new music and dance equipment for our new dance studio!"

Hi there!

Thanks for watching our video! We are so excited for TU Dance Center Studio 2 to open late June. The new space will be great for the expanding youth program we are a part of and which offers youth of all different backgrounds access to a world class professional dance program. 

TU Dance has raised enough funding to build Studio 2 from very generous foundations, but we need to raise money for much needed equipment, such as:

  • piano & drums
    		•
  • sound system
    		•
  • instructional media/TV cart
    		•
  • sprung dance floor & surface
    		•
  • portable barres
    		•
  • mirrors
    		•
Please donate so that we can bring the studio to life! 

So, what is TU Dance Center? 

It's a unique space where young dancers like us get to learn, practice, perform, and work.  And it's the home of the TU Dance, so we work alongside professional dancers and musicians who will be joining us in Studio 2. TU Dance has opened up so many opportunities for us. It's not every day that young dancers get the chance to travel and dance in cities like San Francisco and New York, and it's all thanks to the training we get at TU Dance Center.



How you can help

Please donate as much you can because any amount helps!

In return for your generous support, you'll receive a lot of shoutouts from us--check out the perks area to see what you get. More than anything, though, we'll be very thankful to you for helping us to bring the new TU Dance Center Studio 2 to life! And if you can't give, we would be delighted if you shared our campaign. Email it. Share it on Facebook. Tweet it! However you like, it doesn't matter to us as long as it's getting there with your help.

Thank you so much for considering, and thank you for bringing TU Dance Center Studio 2 to life!
Sincerely,




About TU Dance and Studio 2

TU Dance is a non-profit contemporary dance company and school founded in St. Paul, MN in 2004 by Toni Pierce-Sands and Uri Sands, life partners and veterans of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. The 12-member professional company creates and performs choreography that celebrates a diversity of styles and dance traditions—work which has won critical acclaim and national recognition, including Dance Magazine’s 25 to watch, the 2010 Star-Tribune Artists of the Year, and the Princess Grace Award in choreography.

In 2011, TU Dance substantially expanded its programs with the opening of TU Dance Center, a hub for dance education, training and practice that has quickly become a vibrant arts anchor in St. Paul. Located along the Green Line near University and Vandalia in St. Paul, TU Dance Center serves the families of more than 150 youth, many of color and/or significantly underserved by other arts programming. Training programs for young children, teen and pre-professional artists are driven by a spirit of generosity and inclusiveness informed by the experiences of its artistic leaders. 

Dance creates a shared experience—an undeniable space where a diverse community of audience and artists connect to a common power. We founded TU Dance to create access and opportunity—a platform for performers, students and audiences to engage the remarkable art form that shaped our lives."

— Toni Pierce-Sands and Uri Sands, Artistic Directors

With enrollment expanding quickly, TU Dance Center has outgrown its original capacity. A 2,000 square foot expansion project began upstairs this spring at TU Dance Center and it will be opening late June. Studio 2 will include a new dance studio, additional restroom facilities, and offices. And since construction and related costs are covered with generous support of foundations, every dollar of this campaign goes directly to the purchase of musical instruments and dance equipment. 

Studio 2 construction costs are supported by grants from The McKnight Foundation, Mardag Foundation, F.R. Bigelow Foundation, the City of St. Paul Cultural STAR program, and the Central Corridor Funders Collaborative;  and with project support from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, and Local Initiative Support Corporation (LISC).

story:
The Petworth Dance Project is currently a non-funded outdoor festival, in the heart of NorthWest DC. 

The newly formed Petworth Dance Project launches its first Summer series in Washington, DC, with performances on the 2nd Saturday during the months of May through September. The outdoor dance series is free to the public and features an eclectic set of performances on the lawn of the Petworth Recreation Center located at the corner of 8th and Taylor Street NW. The Petworth Dance Project Summer series features eleven DC area dance companies with styles ranging from Modern, West African, Ballet Folklorico, Contemporary, and more. The Project's goal is to bring the art and joy of Dance to our neighborhood by introducing the community to a wide range of artists, while creating a new space for thriving DC dance companies to perform.

All proceeds raised through the Indiegogo campaign will help towards compensation of artists, having sufficient sound, marketing, and conducting master classes with performing companies, in an effort to provide you, our audience, the best experience possible for this FREE outdoor dance series.

story:
So, we're in the midst of rehearsals for our one and only play "Life is overrated" and would greatly appreciate a little support.


First of all...

Life is overrated is produced by THE SHADES OF GRAY - a multi arts organization with the goal of exploring and honoring the "in between" of the common human experience. (www.theshadesofgray.org)

This is a very special spring for The Shades of Gray: We are very proud to launch our first Artist Exchange Program!


So here we are:

Rayka Kobiella: A German director, and playwright, with an original work in her pocket.

Zoe Hutmacher: A German actress, dragged directly to New York from the Berlin stages and back again.

Miriam Ibrahim: A German actress, who arrived in New York a couple of years ago and is now the heart of Shades of Gray.

Julian Juaquin: An American actor and the rooster in the henhouse.

Vanessa FitzGerald: An American actress who jumped on board at the very last minute.

Then there is the creative team:

Jonas Gerberding: A German stage technician who enlightens our stage.

James Wagner: A German-American translator who decoded our endless German sentences.

Leonie Ettinger: A German expat who is assistant directing and bringing some German order into the production.


What is it about?

LIFE IS OVERRATED is a story about the search for a purpose in life and how it feels to lose one's ambition to pursue it. On the quest of trying to make life meaningful and while seeking to retain independence of our own thoughts, we are faced with a myriad of good and bad advice from friends. There are decisions we are proud of and the ones we regret. Our inner voice is seperated into many small voices; the angels, the devils and the inbetweens. When colliding they could drive us crazy...

 

"I’m forever screwing things up. I barely start to feel comfortable with myself, and then it’s over. I talk too loud, I wear something garish, I belch at the dinner table, spill something, blush, fall in love, get engaged, I’m lost, I stick out, I try to fit in, I eat too much, I don’t eat enough, I forget people’s names. I’m no good at anything. These human networks. No good. I can’t do it. I’m not only not good at it, I’m fucking terrible at it.

 


So what now?

In many ways this is our first time – Shades of Gray's first artist-exchange program, the first German-American collaboration for all of us, and our first attempt on Indiegogo...scary, right?

 


So this is what we need:

We're not asking for much – ideally $1000 but every little penny will help us cover our bases. We hope to be able to raise enough to pay for the rent of our beautiful theatre space, the funky rehearsal room, our tech equip, stage design, costumes and, of course, our metro cards! And what we would really love: starting our next project without debts!

 


And this is what you'll get for it!!!

 

You'll love our perks!

 

$1 - A “Thank You” in the program and a "Love you – email".

 

$10 – A“Thank You” in the program and a postcard with all our signatures - you can choose between NYC and Berlin.

 

$20 – A “Thank You” in the program and an autographed photo from the entire cast!

 

$50 - A “Thank You” in the program, an autographed photo from the entire cast and a DVD of the play.

$100 - you can keep the "Life is overrated”- sign from our trailer in addition to the DVD of the play, a “Thank You” in the program and the autographed photo from the entire cast!


What else?

Come and see our performance!!!!

LIFE IS OVERRATED runs May 30 - June 2, Wed. - Sat. 8:00pm. Space on White is located at 81 White Street between Lafayette and Broadway. Tickets are $12-15, available on https://www.artfullyhq.com/store/events/170 or
www.theshadesofgray.org

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH VISITING OUR CAMPAIGN AND HOPEFULLY LEAVING US SOME DUCATS :-*

story:
Sadie the Goat: A legendary character from Herbert Asbury's book Gangs of New York. A product of the impoverished "bloody" Fourth Ward of Manhattan, Sadie Farrell earned the nickname Sadie the Goat for her habit of butting her head into men's chests to incapacitate them before robbing them.

According to legend, Sadie the Goat lost an ear in a bar fight with a 6-foot tall female bouncer named Gallus Mag, who kept it as a trophy in a pickle jar. Retiring from the Fourth Ward in disgrace, Sadie put together a crew of river pirates and stole a boat. She raised the pirate flag and set out, up and down the Hudson and Harlem Rivers, raiding hamlets in upstate New York and holding farmers hostage. If the ransom didn't come, Sadie made them walk the plank.

This story is now a play told in song and poems, written in the rough slang and doggerel of the crime-filled slums of Victorian New York. The piece is a collaboration between playwright Max Sparber, author of the extensively produced play "Minstrel Show, or The Lynching of William Brown," and Jill Anderson, one of Omaha's most beloved stage actors and a musician who has specialized in Celtic music for two decades.

Dreamland Ballroom Irish Theater is a professional theater company in Omaha, Nebraska, that produces the best contemporary plays reflecting the Irish and Irish-American experience.

story:
Cohesion Theatre Company is already one show into the inaugural season, and we’re loving it! We received four glowing reviews for Coriolanus, from the Baltimore Sun, City Paper, Theatre Bloom, and the Bad Oracle. We have been welcomed by the Highlandtown community, even scoring our first awards as a company: The Innovative Arts Award from the Highlandtown Business Council, and The Most Intriguing Stage Award from The Bad Oracle. We’re doing what we love, and we couldn’t have done it without support from our followers and community.

As we go into our second ever show, we need to draw upon that same support to help lift the burden of our up-front costs. All of the costs of our production, excluding artist stipends, must be paid before the show even opens. They break down as follows:

Rent & utilities

$2,500

Costumes

$500

Set & lights

$500

Rights & photography                

$975

Total

$4,475

All of these costs must be addressed before opening night – after all, we can’t open without a space, a set, costumes, or a script. These expenses create the world we can play in and invite you into, and they keep us in the Highlandtown community that we love.

A major part of Cohesion’s mission, as we’ll tell anyone who asks us, is to pay our artists as much as we can. That means that these up-front expenses are in addition to another $4,150 in artist fees, which we plan to pay for from ticket sales. We are committed to keeping artist stipends at their current level, because we believe in the value of our artists’ work and their need for pesky things like gas, food, and clothing. In order to that, we need your help with technical expenses and overhead.

We are aiming to raise the full $4,475 from this Indiegogo campaign. We have wonderful perks that we hope you’ll take advantage of – and we can’t wait to see you at the show!

Sincerely,

Brad Norris and Alicia Stanley

Founding Artistic Producers

Details About the Show

A Baltimore premiere production, Thirteen Dead Husbands tells the fanciful story of Dee-Dee, “the most beautiful woman in the world”, and the men who come from far and wide to woo and wed her, only to end up dead under mysterious circumstances. As friends Marcel and Jean Pierre compete for her hand, they ask if one of them should marry her, will they live to enjoy it? Told with charming humor and a surreal and fantastic design, Husbands champions the simplicity of love, and the joy of possibility.

We are thrilled about the creative team we have put together for this production! 

The design team:

Director

Brad Norris

Assistant Director

Caitlin Carbone

Stage Manager

Heather Johnston

Lighting Designer                                      

Lana Riggins

Costume Designer

Stephanie Fisher

Scenic Designer

Sebastian Sears

Music Director

Nick Delaney

The cast:

Jean-Pierre                                                 

Bobby Henneberg

Marcel

Matthew Payne

Dee-Dee

Casey Dutt

Hubert Hubble

Thom Sinn

Captain Alexander Coachella

Sean James

Jack Russell

Nick Delaney

Milo

Phil Vannoorbeeck

Froedrick Leopold

Malcolm Anomnachi

Dr. Seamus Delaney

Dominic Gladden

Detective Shetland Houndstooth

Tommy Peter

Café Musician

Alicia Stanley

Many scenes in the play take place in a small café in France – and we are creating an immersive café experience for our audience (that’s you!), with café tables and everything. Live music will begin 45 minutes before curtain every performance, led by our incredibly talented Music Director, Nick Delaney.

We will also be hosting special Sunday events the first two weekends of the show. Opening weekend, on Sunday, March 15, we will be holding the First Annual Ides of March Celebration. Join us at 6 pm for a 75-minute staged reading of Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar on the day of his death, adapted and directed by Cohesion’s Alicia Stanley, who recently directed Coriolanus. On Sunday, March 22, we are thrilled to be collaborating with Baltimore Improv Group to bring a special night of improv after our regular performance! Both Sundays, we will have live music from The Arden Bards in between the events.

We can’t wait to share the show with you – and the more we raise through this campaign, the more resources we have to make it great!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't spare a few dollars for us to make this amazing show happen, please spread the word to your social media circle, friends, and family. Plus, you can contact us and sign up to volunteer to help paint, sew, and build - we need it around tech week!

Group to bring a special night of improv after our regular performance! Both
Sundays, we will have live music from The Arden Bards in between the events.
We can’t wait to share the show with you – and the more we
raise through this campaign, the more resources we have to make it great!Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't spare a few dollars for us to make this amazing show happen, please spread the word to your social media circle, friends, and family. Plus, you can contact us and sign up to volunteer to help paint, sew, and build - we need it around tech week!

story:
WHO WE ARE

Seta Morton, Tony Carlson, Renk Kocturk, Albert Delgado, and Sasha Wolfe

We, the senior class of the Eugene Lang college dance program, are thrilled to be producing works for what will be our capstone projects/performances this spring, a culmination of the research, dance experiences, and choreographic interests that we have cultivated over the past 4 years here in New York City. The dates are fast approaching; we are in the final stretch of our fundraising efforts and we need YOUR help to make the whole thing possible!


WHAT WE DO

Over the past years, we have had the privilege of working with the incredible faculty of the New School, as well as learning from and holding generative dialogue with dance and performance artists living and working in New York City today. Using dance as a framework, we have worked to intersect our choreographic endeavors with our scholarly interests in the liberal arts, like performance studies, queer and feminist theory, psychology, creative arts therapy, theater, environmental studies, critical race theory, and art history.


THE HELP WE NEED

Our individual interests and processes are diverse, and we are all investigating something different in our approach to the framework of these projects, which include both performance works and workshop facilitation. The expenses of doing so are fairly significant, and we are asking for your help so that we may be able to secure costumes, production elements, lighting, promotional materials, instrumentalists, as well as the means to pay the crew and designers a fair fee for their efforts in making the show possible. We have already raised over half of what we need through other means, but are asking for $1500 to cover the last of our expenses.

From the bottom of our hearts, we would so so appreciate anything you’re willing to give, and can assure you that all proceeds will go to help make our thesis visions possible. PLEASE come join us in April if you can, and check out the fun rewards we are able to offer in exchange for your donations, including tickets to see the show with your name on them!

Check back for updates as we get closer to the show date and, again, THANK YOU!

THE SHOW/WORKSHOP

WHEN: Performances: Friday, April 17th and Saturday April 18th at 7:30pm

               Wellness Workshop w/Renk Kocturk: Saturday, April 18th 4:00-5:30pm

WHERE: Tishman Auditorium @ the New School University Center                                   65 5th Ave, New York, NY 10003 (between 13th and 14th streets)

WITH: Tony Carlson, Renk Kocturk, Sasha Wolfe, Seta Morton, and Albert Delgado

Lighting Designer: Megan Byrne

Stage Manager: Ashley Beeler

General Admission tickets are a suggested donation of $10

FREE for New School students, faculty, and alumni!


PHOTOS BY JOSÉ VIRGILIO

story:
5 of the country's top female writers
Remix 5 classical plays by women
No Holds Barred

Botoxed hipsters, invented savages, missing nuns, loves treason and Harriet Tubman--this year’s Alcyone Festival puts a new spin on overlooked classics. We asked five contemporary women to rework/adapt/sample/remix plays written by classical women, celebrating over a thousand years of writing by women.

On average only twenty percent of plays produced each year are written by women. In Chicago in 2009, only 19% were. The percentage of women produced on broadway last year was virtually unchanged from 100 years ago. Because female playwrights are horribly represented on stages across America, we created the Alcyone Festival to combat this directly, by celebrating the depth and breadth of women writers.

It's pretty common to rework the dead men of the cannon. No one is really re-imagining Maria de Zaya y Sotomayor or Anna Cora Mowatt. (At least not that we're aware of.) Looking at works using/adapting/sampling plays written by women from Hrosvitha (c. 935 to c. 1002) through 1870, our hope is to celebrate both new and (really) old writers and see how the lineage of female playwrights over the past thousand years can inspire and inform contemporary audiences and artists.

Instead of picking scripts that have already been written, we picked some of our favorite writers and took off the brakes. While we couldn't afford to commission, we could commit to producing. And that's what we did. Amongst all the talk of development hell, etc, we're putting some of our favorite writers in the driver’s seat, and seeing what happens. The only rules the writers had were: it has to be based in some way off a work by a female playwright written before 1870 and it had to be ready to go into rehearsal in April. No holds barred.

How You can Help

Currently the single biggest obstacle is space. Rehearsal spaces and performance space for fully mounting a five show festival are about $10,000 which is our goal. Other funding will take care of paying people, sets, costumes, lights etc. However helping to create a safe space for these extraordinary women to soar is the biggest way you can help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell people about it! Facebook, Twitter, email, in-person help us spread the word.

Feel free to contact us at info@halcyontheatre.org if you have any questions.

story:
What's the Big Idea?

Tree Project started with a wink and a parade. Mandy, an acrobat, and Patrick, a musician, got together to jam in a tree during a spring festival back in '09 -- and that's when we realized how amazing trees are. How they invite you to think about the big questions and the little ones, have fun, make art, and connect with other people.

So we started inviting our friends -- more artists, more climbers, more musicians, to come by and stage structured-improvisational aerial performances in community settings, in trees -- Tree Project.

Last summer we went to York, PA and worked with RAW art collective, who invited their friends, artists and non-artists, to make an amazing day of collaborative, intiguing, spontaneous art (visual, musical, edible, danceable) with a Tree Dance in the middle -- a Jamboree.

Now we've been inspired to make more Jamborees happen, and we need your help to do it. We're hitting the road from July 10th to August 15th this year, travelling the southeast, and staging tree dances all along the way.

So far, we have local collaborators in Pittsburgh, Atlanta, Chatanooga, New Orleans, and Austin, TX. If you can help us get there, we'll hold events in each city, record our impressions, and scrapbook our experiences for all to see!

And we will have expanded the network of connections among artists and each other, artists and lay-folk, and artists and thier environments in a way that's full of summertime fun!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need fuel in our tanks and in our bellies. To get from NYC to the southeast and back agian takes roughly $700 in gas and tolls, and to feed all four us for the month we'll be on the road takes about twice that.

The rest we intend to use for safety equipment (ropes, gloves, etc.), lights, and other day-to-day incidentals. If we don't happen to get full funding, your support will go toward the same things -- we'll just shorten the trip.

We'd be so excited to have you as a friend! And to show you how happy we are to have you behind us, we have so many tokens of gratitude -- from friendship bracelets, to specially made songs, to dessert parties, to a full-on jamboree just for you!
 
 

The Impact

 . . .is huge. Because it's about connection and spontaneity, this is the kind of project that works best in-person. Your contribution translates directly into how far we can go. The more help we get, the farther we can travel, the more people we can meet, and the more jamborees we can have.

More jamborees =  a ton of people (including us) energized and reaching out to each other and playing outside and sharing their passions. What could be better?

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are so grateful to have your support, financial or otherwise.

Tell Your Friends: Come and see us when we get to your town! Tell your friends so they can help us make it to your town!

Collaborate with Us: Do you paint/draw/play/film/dance/create? Tell us what you do and where you are, and we'll structure you in to the relevant jamboree session. This is what it's all about, folks.

Offer a Space: If you have a space in any of the cities mentioned or along the way, with climbable trees, be in touch! We're happy to climb more!

Offer a Meal: Since the bulk of our funding is going to food, this is a great way to help!

story:
"There’s something epic and special here in the making.” (Fringe Review)

“Strange and beautiful, touching and magical.” (ThreeWeeks, ****)

(Praise for Howling Moon, Fringe Review Recommended Show)

 

Last year, Flyaway Theatre made a splash at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe with sell-out play Howling Moon. This year, we’re going up again with acclaimed playwright Heather Wilmot’s new play, The Rabbit and the Rose.

With The Rabbit and the Rose we’re aiming to create something really different and moving without losing a sense of fun. It’s a story of friends working together on what they love best, squabbling, and telling their stories. It’s a story about love, loss and friendship... with an alcoholic painting, talking statues, a gang of highway squirrels, hydras and a very terrible flower.

Flyaway Theatre is committed to making theatre as visually interesting as it is fun, though, so we need your help to raise funds to help us buy costumes, makeup and socks. So many socks!

Because this is the debut of The Rabbit and the Rose, we can’t show you any of the show yet (but watch this space!). But here’s the trailer for the original production of Howling Moon, way back in 2010. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wbQSsvG3CV0

If you can’t help fund us, please tell your friends or, if you’ll be in Edinburgh this August, come and see the show!

The Rabbit and the Rose will be performed at International 3 at Sweet (venue #18) from 12th-17th and the 19th of August and is suitable for people of 7 and up. It starts at 15:55 and runs for 50 minutes.

Flyaway Theatre can be found at http://www.flyawaytheatre.co.uk/

Email us at shona@flyawaytheatre.co.uk or alice@flyawaytheatre.co.uk.

Tickets available from Sweet Grassmarket Box Office (Active 1st Aug)

Tel: 0131 243 3596

story:
Help Theatre Y get to New York!
We are a small non-profit theatre company based in Chicago with a huge heart and a lot to prove. We have been in existence since 2005 and during that time we have shared our work with audiences all over the world and around the U.S. in over one hundred locations including Israel, Palestine, Romania, Hungary and many others. Right now we are raising funds to take our celebrated show I Killed My Mother to the famed La Mama Experimental Theater in New York City.  We have been invited to be part of La Mamaâ€™s 50th anniversary season, this is a huge honor us. For the past fifty years La Mama has been a breeding ground for many great theater artists.  It is a company with a proud tradition of bringing unique and disparate theater practitioners together to share their work with a broad audience.   


Our play, I Killed My Mother is not, as you might first think, a murder mystery. Rather it is a haunting and soulful play by acclaimed Romanian playwright and Theatre Y collaborator Andras Visky, directed by Karin Coonrod well known in NYC for her exceptional work with The Public Theater and many others. The play explores ideas of identity and redemption and is inspired by Romania's "lost children," a generation of orphans who grew up in government-run institutions under the brutal Ceauscescu regime . The play is based on the true story of one of those children, Bernadette, who learns to transcend the harsh realities of her brutal existence in order to fully realize her own powerful self.

 I Killed My Mother has already had a big impact on Chicago audiences and critics alike.  Now we're ready to share this beautiful piece of work with a larger audience, and we need your help.  

â€œPlaywright-poet Viskyâ€™s expressionist response to parentless hardship does things no docudrama could. Couching Bernadetteâ€™s spiritual progress as an ongoing dialogue with (her soul mate) Clip first as mentor/playmate/protector then internalized voiceâ€”the play explodes into a full-on dramatic poem, unfolding one epiphany after another.â€â€”Time Out Chicago   

Bringing a professional production to New York is expensive!  La MaMa has
made a commitment to present "I Killed My Mother," and Theatre Y has already raised almost two-thirds of the total cost of the New York production. Now we need your help to make it the rest of the way.  Help us make this show a success! We are currently raising money that will pay for travel expenses for the actors, promotional expenses necessary to market the show in New York, and a living wage for the artists involved in the production, something that we feel very passionate about.    

This is a rare opportunity to perform at one of the most important off-Broadway theatres in New York. Will you consider being a part of this project by making a tax deductible contribution of $100, $50 or even $25 to help make this project a success


Theatre Y is made up of a small but dedicated company of artists and caring board members which means we have minimal overhead, and our energy and resources go directly towards making the best, most truthful theatre we can. However, it also means that we don't have a team of professional fundraisers at our disposal. We rely on the generosity and passion of our audience and a wide array of donors to make up more than 50% of our budget.  That means that you are just as important in this process as we are.  Please make a gift in any amount to help us bring this amazing play to New
York in February 2012.  

If youâ€™re not in a position to make a gift right now donâ€™t worry you can still help a ton.  Just share this project with everyone you know using facebook, twitter or old fashioned talking.  Help us make some noise and get the word out!

   
Thank you, from all of us at Theatre Y!

Please visit us at theatre-y.com
