story:
“In the end I think theatre has only one subject: justice.”

 

The Edward Bond Festival

http://edwardbondfestival.wordpress.com

 

Hi, my name is Alan Dilworth. I am a theatre director and co-Artistic Director of Sheep No Wool, an award winning indie-theatre company based out of Toronto, Canada. This June, Sheep No Wool is bringing world-renowned master playwright Edward Bond to Toronto for a festival celebrating his 50th anniversary as a playwright.  We are a small indie company with no infrastructure creating a one-time festival for one of the world’s most acclaimed independent artistic spirits.  

 

This is a passion project.   

 

The festival takes place in Toronto and other locations across Southern Ontario from June 12-20th. The festival consists of eleven encounters featuring over fifty Canadian theatre artists and twelve theatre companies in ten days. In the spirit of Bond’s work we are keeping ticket prices affordable to ensure the participation of youth, and to make engagement for individuals at multiple events, possible.

 

We need your help to pull this off.     

 

Your contribution can help make possible this extraordinary opportunity for Canadian audiences and artists to engage in a meeting of minds with one of world's greatest living theatre artists. Your contribution will ensure that all eleven encounters we are programming can be carried out as planned: six workshop readings of Bond's works, a workshop presentation of Bond's play Have I None with the collaboration of Bond himself before a live audience, a Symposium featuring Edward Bond and UK director Chris Cooper, and an acclaimed Ryerson Theatre School remount production of Bond's epic play The Bundle, with a festival finale political theatre cabaret The Wrecking Ball.  

 

“I want to set light to people's souls.”

 

Edward Bond is one of the most important and prolific post-war playwrights. The Royal Court Theatre staged Bond's Saved in 1965. The play created a national scandal, which was instrumental in the abolition of censorship of the English stage, and established Bond as a major British playwright. He has written more than 50 plays, including Lear, The Sea, Bingo, The Woman, Restoration, The War Plays and The Paris Pentad. Many of his plays have attained the status of radical classics. Bond's influence on young writers is prodigious. The Abbey Theatre (Dublin) described him as one of the most influential English dramatists of all time. This season there were four acclaimed productions of Bond's plays in major British theatres. 

 

Bond's work challenges us to consider the nature of our humanity and the dangerous social consequences of injustice - which now become increasingly urgent. In an age of illusion, rampant consumerism, and addiction to diversion and spectacle, his plays command us to look at how we are blindly corroborating in the destruction of our environment, our society, and our humanity. Bond’s prophetic works and dramatic theories provide a blueprint for the re-vitalization of drama and it's place in society. His work restores drama's central role as a voice that cries for justice in a world where the abuses of authority are becoming increasingly elusive and unchecked.

 

“I think there is no world without theatre.”

 

We need to raise $10,000 to make our programming possible. Our goal is to raise $5,000 with this indiegogo campaign. Our fantastic partners have already made  generous in kind donations, but a number of expenses remain which require cash flow. The $5,000 raised here would go towards:

Honorarium for participating artists

Accommodation for Mr. Bond

Venue Insurance

Theatre rental/crew costs for the Symposium

Local transportation for Mr. Bond in Toronto

 

Not everyone is in a position to donate money but can use the indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about our indiegogo campaign. Please  check out our facebook page (http://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Edward-Bond-Festival/286373698112262) and our website at: http://edwardbondfestival.wordpress.com.
story_txt:
“In the end I think theatre has only one subject: justice.”
 
The Edward Bond Festival
http://edwardbondfestival.wordpress.com
 
Hi, my name is Alan Dilworth. I am a theatre director and co-Artistic Director of Sheep No Wool, an award winning indie-theatre company based out of Toronto, Canada. This June, Sheep No Wool is bringing world-renowned master playwright Edward Bond to Toronto for a festival celebrating his 50th anniversary as a playwright.  We are a small indie company with no infrastructure creating a one-time festival for one of the world’s most acclaimed independent artistic spirits.  
 
This is a passion project.   
 
The festival takes place in Toronto and other locations across Southern Ontario from June 12-20th. The festival consists of eleven encounters featuring over fifty Canadian theatre artists and twelve theatre companies in ten days. In the spirit of Bond’s work we are keeping ticket prices affordable to ensure the participation of youth, and to make engagement for individuals at multiple events, possible.
 
We need your help to pull this off.     
 
Your contribution can help make possible this extraordinary opportunity for Canadian audiences and artists to engage in a meeting of minds with one of world's greatest living theatre artists. Your contribution will ensure that all eleven encounters we are programming can be carried out as planned: six workshop readings of Bond's works, a workshop presentation of Bond's play Have I None with the collaboration of Bond himself before a live audience, a Symposium featuring Edward Bond and UK director Chris Cooper, and an acclaimed Ryerson Theatre School remount production of Bond's epic play The Bundle, with a festival finale political theatre cabaret The Wrecking Ball.  
 
“I want to set light to people's souls.”
 
Edward Bond is one of the most important and prolific post-war playwrights. The Royal Court Theatre staged Bond's Saved in 1965. The play created a national scandal, which was instrumental in the abolition of censorship of the English stage, and established Bond as a major British playwright. He has written more than 50 plays, including Lear, The Sea, Bingo, The Woman, Restoration, The War Plays and The Paris Pentad. Many of his plays have attained the status of radical classics. Bond's influence on young writers is prodigious. The Abbey Theatre (Dublin) described him as one of the most influential English dramatists of all time. This season there were four acclaimed productions of Bond's plays in major British theatres. 
 
Bond's work challenges us to consider the nature of our humanity and the dangerous social consequences of injustice - which now become increasingly urgent. In an age of illusion, rampant consumerism, and addiction to diversion and spectacle, his plays command us to look at how we are blindly corroborating in the destruction of our environment, our society, and our humanity. Bond’s prophetic works and dramatic theories provide a blueprint for the re-vitalization of drama and it's place in society. His work restores drama's central role as a voice that cries for justice in a world where the abuses of authority are becoming increasingly elusive and unchecked.
 
“I think there is no world without theatre.”
 
We need to raise $10,000 to make our programming possible. Our goal is to raise $5,000 with this indiegogo campaign. Our fantastic partners have already made  generous in kind donations, but a number of expenses remain which require cash flow. The $5,000 raised here would go towards:
Honorarium for participating artists
Accommodation for Mr. Bond
Venue Insurance
Theatre rental/crew costs for the Symposium
Local transportation for Mr. Bond in Toronto
 
Not everyone is in a position to donate money but can use the indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about our indiegogo campaign. Please  check out our facebook page (http://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Edward-Bond-Festival/286373698112262) and our website at: http://edwardbondfestival.wordpress.com.

story:
Greetings this Holiday Season. Mississippi Mud Productions wishes you Happy Holidays! We're launching our end of year fund drive right here on IndieGoGo. See how you can help us now with these easy tools to use and much appreciated ways to give.


Who We Are:


We, Mississippi Mud Productions, are a developing theatre company with roots in the NYC scape, working on developing visionary American theatre with artists from around the world. American Renaissance Man of the Theatre Drama Desk 2007 winner Austin Pendleton says "Mud is a young Steppenwolf." We found our name on Thanksgiving and were officially born on Christmas Eve 2009. Like any toddler we are exploring, growing, crawling, walking, rocket to the moon-ing.


What We've Done:

At age 1: our first project was a A Streetcar Named Desire at The Cherry Pit, New York, summer 2010, with Jen and actors like Toshiji Takeshima who met at HB Studio in Austin Pendleton's advanced scene study class and decided with Austin's encouragement to follow a dream and do this play out in the city. Mud produced this work born with HB Ensemble actors and exploration time, so rooted in total love for Williams and the play and process, and offered free to the public.


At age 2: Vivien Leigh: The Last Press Conference, was produced in Long Beach Long Island for Women's History Month, with Jen Danby. Broadway's Austin Pendleton directed. Film star Vivien Leigh faces death and looks at her life. We were invited to Blue Heaven, Key West, sponsored by the generous community of Key West. Vivien came back to New York for the Long Island Fringe Festival on the Gold Coast of Long Island. Critic Mimi Torchin wrote about Jen's Vivien: "Jen Danby is such an actress. I mean a real actress. Like from the 30s, when actresses had style."


In summer 2011, we launched our pilot Mud Lab of Cat on A Hot Tin Roof by Tennessee Williams, directed by Austin Pendleton. Mud's educational wing was born this year with "gym" space for actors. With Mud Lab, Mud was able with nine actors to be in the laboratory, building ensemble, storytelling with you, Mud's friends, by opening up lab explorations. See more here www.mississippimudproductions.com/catlab.html.


In fall 2011, we produced Mr. Pendleton's Orson's Shadow on Theatre Row, called a "delicious revival" in Hot Review. See more here www.hotreview.org/articles/whenegoscollide.htm.



Mud at 3: A Sneak Peak at Our Upcoming Season:


Vivien Leigh: The Last Press Conference will make its New York City Debut with a limited run for Women's History Month and Irish Heritage on Saint Patrick's Day Weekend in a space converted from a factory in New York City's fashion district, The Alexander Technique Center for Performance and Development. Vivien will have a "new look." The 1967 wig look from her London photo shoot will now be a new 1967 look for NYC's fashion row, resourcefully refashioned with the wig that Jen sported in Mississippi Mud's Orson's Shadow.


AND Mud Lab will have its second year working on Suddenly Last Summer and getting back in the ring with more lab work on Cat on A Hot Tin Roof, both directed by Austin Pendleton, in New York's fashion district, at The Alexander Technique Center for Performance and Development run by Tom Vasiliades', or what we at Mud affectionately call "Tom's space."  We open the lab work up free to Mud friends and fans. We will share word on Facebook, Twitter, and via our website about it.



How Your Giving Helps Us:



Mud is sensitive to the challenges we face as American and world artists and audiences with the economics today. We are focusing on raw work about actor and story, with a streamlined approach making art.


$6,000 in developmental funding will help sponsor Mud Lab Tennessee Williams work for a month in the summer, space, teacher-director stipend, and photocopying. Free open work is then shared.


$1000 will help sponsor the Vivien Leigh: The Last Press Conference four performances: royalties, space, rehearsal, director stipend, programs. Tickets will be offered at artist friendly cost in an intimate space and the ticket earnings will help to cover operational costs and publicity. So what we can fundraise helps us make the art. We will offer talkbacks TBA for women's history month.


We know how valuable every dime is in these times. As an Indie theatre company, we are committed to making exciting and meaningful performances that are affordable to our audiences. We hope you will consider giving to us this season. And please check out Mud's story about who we are at www.mississippimudproductions.com, by Founder and Artistic Director Jen Danby, who, along with Mud artist Charles Black, shouts out, "Let the Mud Flow!" By the artist, for the people.


Won't you help us as you are able? Even $5 helps the Mud create. With your generosity, Mud can continue to grow and thrive in New York City.


Also stay tuned to Mud with Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and through our Mail Chimp mailing list by sending us your email address at lisa@mississippimudproductions.com


Mississippi Mud Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Mississippi Mud Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Wishing you and yours the very best this holiday season. Thank you for your support and belief in the Mud!

Cheers,

Jen, Lisa, Justine, and the Mud Team

story:
Zombies?

Es gibt sie keineswegs nur in Geschichten. Im Gegenteil! An jeder Straßenecke sieht man sie: völlig anteilnahmslos starren sie auf kleine Geräte in ihren Händen. Bekommen nichts mehr von der Welt um sie herum mit. Sind raus aus dem Leben.

Das Blöde ist: "Sie" – das sind wir.

Und wie sollen wir Kindern einen halbwegs verantwortungsvollen Umgang mit modernen Medien bebiegen, wenn wir es selber kaum gebacken kriegen? Was tun, wenn Kinder in der virtuellen Welt verloren gehen?

 

Wer ist Iso Herquist?

Ich bin Iso. Musiker, Autor, Scherzkeks und Querdenker.

Und immer gegen den Strom. Vielleicht bin ich deshalb selbständig, spiele Ukulele und (habe kein Smartphone).

Was nicht heißt, dass ich keine Ahnung von IT habe. Lange genug habe ich Datenbanken entwickelt und "Informationsarchitektur" für Websiten gemacht. Habe Skripte fürs Fernsehen geschrieben und multimediale Anwendungen entwickelt. Also eher im Gegenteil: mit IT kenne ich mich ziemlich gut aus und eigentlich weiß ich, wie man verantwortungsbewusst mit Modernen Medien umgeht.

"Eigentlich", denn auch mich erwischt es hin und wieder. Auch ich bleibe in irgendwelchen Webforen oder auf Social Media-Websites hängen. Werde eingesaugt von der digitalen Welt, von ihrem Zauber und ihren Versprechungen – und vergesse das echte Leben für eine Weile völlig.

 

Wer ist Katharina Wiedenhofer?

Katharina ist begnadete und vielfach ausgezeichnete Tänzerin. Die Chemie zwischen uns stimmt. Daher wird sie die Choreographien für die "Anti Zombie Maschine" entwerfen und die Hauptrolle bei unserer Premiere in Frankfurt spielen.

 

Was ist die Anti Zombie Maschine?

Die Anti Zombie Maschine ist ein Tanz-und-Musiktheaterstück für Kinder von 6 bis 12 Jahren, das Smartphones und virtuelle Welten zum Thema hat. Es wird eine Spiellänge von etwa 40 Minuten haben und ist geschrieben für eine Tänzerin und einen Musiker.

Allerdings geht es nicht um einen pädagogischen Ansatz. Ob SmartPhones nun "gut" oder "böse" sind – das spielt erstmal keine Rolle.

Es geht um den Mut, möglichst oft abzuschalten. Es geht um Alternativen. Es geht um: jetzt ist hier und hier ist jetzt. Den Kopf heben, die Augen öffnen – sich selbst wahrnehmen. Andere wahrnehmen. Die Welt wahrnehmen.

 

Dazu werde ich das klassische Erzähltheater mit Tanz und Musik verbinden und ein schwungvolles, witziges Tanz-und-Musik-Abenteuer für kleine und große Zuschauer schaffen. Charmant-witzig-schräge Charaktere und Mitmach-Choreografien zu zeitgenössischer Musik mit eher ungewöhnlicher Instrumentierung. Ein naives, verqueres und irgendwie auch weises modernes Märchen – ganz ohne erhobenen Zeigefinger.

Und weil man im Theater auch nur auf dem Popo hockt und glotzt gibt es zusätzlich den Anti Zombie Maschine-Workshop: die Kids können selber entweder einen der Songs mit Instrumenten spielen lernen oder die Choreographie dazu einstudieren. Für eine ganz eigene, kleine Anti Zombie Maschinen-Aufführung am Ende des Workshops.

So kann jedes Kind etwas mit nachhause nehmen: eine Geschichte, ein Lied im Ohr, einen Tanz, eine aufregende Erfahrung.

 

Ja, und jetzt?

Das Konzept steht und hat das Kulturamt der Stadt Frankfurt so weit überzeugt, dass sie mich ordentlich unterstützen. Die Story steht. Das Team steht. Die Merianschule in Frankfurt begleitet uns bei der Entwicklung – in einer AG werden wir spielerisch erkunden, wie Smartphones unser Leben verändern. Eigentlich kann es losgehen, die Premiere ist am 27. Oktober 2018.

Nur: mit der Anti Zombie Maschine habe ich mir selbst eine ganze Menge ziemlich kniffliger Aufgaben gestellt. Um sie zu entwickeln, zu probieren und letztlich in Form zu bringen brauche ich Zeit und den Austausch mit anderen. Und damit auch Geld – denn von Luft und Liebe kann niemand leben und die bisher gesammelten Fördergelder reichen nicht, um wirklich sorgfältig zu arbeiten.

 

Was passiert mit meinem Geld?

So viel steht fest: Das Stück werde ich entwickeln – komme, was da wolle. Denn ich bin fest davon überzeugt: wir brauchen eine Anti Zombie Maschine. Dringend. Aber du kannst dabei helfen: jeder Cent hilft, um die Anti Zombie Maschine ein kleines bisschen besser zu machen.

Mit deinem Geld wird das Skript entwickelt und die Dialoge entworfen, wird an den Charakteren gefeilt, werden Songtexte geschrieben, Lieder komponiert, arrangiert, einstudiert und aufgenommen, werden Choreografien entworfen, ausprobiert und einstudiert, werden Themen und Materialien für die AG der Kooperationsschule entworfen, wird dramturgische Beratung finanziert, werden Kostüme besorgt, die Bühnen gestaltet, wird Lichtdesign gemacht und (Ton-) Technik geplant, wird eine Video-Dokumentation gemacht, werden Notenhefte gesetzt und gedruckt – außerdem wird natürlich viel Büroarbeit erledigt, Fotos und Grafik gemacht, Flyer und Plakate gestaltet und gedruckt, wird Kram ins Web gestellt, Fahrtkosten und Miete und Strom und so Kram eben bezahlt.

Und sollte dann tatsächlich noch was übrig sein, dann laden wir alle Unterstützenden je nach Alter und Gusto auf einen Kaffee, ein Eis, ein paar Kekse, ein Heringsbrötchen oder ein Bier ein.

Soviel steht fest: wer uns mit mindestens 11 Euro bei IndieGogo unterstützt, kommt umsonst in die Premiere*. 27. Oktober 2018. Save the date.

 

 

*so lange Plätze frei sind. Ansonsten in eine der Folgeaufführungen.

story:
Hello, 

Thanks for visiting our indiegogo page.


We are a community of artists and cultural workers who produce an annual international performance festival in Kigali, Rwanda. The festival is called Centre x Centre and it aims to share works and ways of working around civic and aesthetic experimentation. Started in 2008 by Hope Azeda, Carole Karemera and Erik Ehn, we've hosted writing and performance workshops, hip hop, Noh theater, comedy, dance-theater, performance art and drama from Belarus, Afghanistan, Canada, US, Uganda, Mexico and Rwanda. This festival is a culmination of an eight-year-old exchange program hosted by the Interdisciplinary Genocide Studies Center and CalArts/Brown University, where students, faculty and professionals in the field travel to Rwanda/Uganda to study the histories of these two countries and ways art can participate in processes of renewal. 


With two successful festivals under our belt, we are ready to expand Centre x Centre to accommodate more artists, more audience and more innovative work. That's where you come in.


Centre x Centre

Ishyo Art Centre will host the festival from August 4 to August 6 2011. Mornings, participant artists share strategies for responding to violence through dance, performance or writing workshops. The afternoons provide space either for continuation of workshops or readings and discussion of new plays. The evenings offer concrete examples of peace-building through performance. The whole weekend is free and open to the public.


Hope Azeda, the lead producer in Rwanda, has requested $1600 to widen access to this festival in Kigali. Even though it is free, there are still barriers that limit access to the work. The funds will go towards publicizing the festival, transport for schools to attend performances, and technical support for local artists.  We need your help in meeting Hope's request.


Rwanda is engaged in remarkable acts of recovery and development and the arts, as a tool for remembering the past and imagining future, continue to be a vital part of its healing and growth. This festival puts socially engaged artists (from Rwanda and from many other countries and contexts) into conversation, sharing practices and performances that explore art as a tool for civic engagement. That it takes place in Rwanda grounds the work in modern human consequences of violence and allows more Rwandans to witness and share their expertise. Rwanda serves as our teacher in the study of peace.


By contributing, you will become a supportive member of a conversational community - please see perks for specifics on how our gratitude will manifest itself. And - in addition to material support - we could use help spreading the word. Please feel free to post this page on facebook, or email to your friends and colleagues.

The festival is called Centre x Centre and it aims to share works and ways of working around civic and aesthetic experimentation. Started in 2008 by Hope Azeda, Carole Karemera and Erik Ehn, we've hosted writing and performance workshops, hip hop, Noh theater, comedy, dance-theater, performance art and drama from Belarus, Afghanistan, Canada, US, Uganda, Mexico and Rwanda. This festival is a culmination of an eight-year-old exchange program hosted by the Interdisciplinary Genocide Studies Center and CalArts/Brown University, where students, faculty and professionals in the field travel to Rwanda/Uganda to study the histories of these two countries and ways art can participate in processes of renewal. 

With two successful festivals under our belt, we are ready to expand Centre x Centre to accommodate more artists, more audience and more innovative work. That's where you come in.


Centre x Centre 

Ishyo Art Centre will host the festival from August 4 to August 6 2011. Mornings, participant artists share strategies for responding to violence through dance, performance or writing workshops. The afternoons provide space either for continuation of workshops or readings and discussion of new plays. The evenings offer concrete examples of peace-building through performance. The whole weekend is free and open to the public. 

Hope Azeda, the lead producer in Rwanda, has requested $1600 to widen access to this festival in Kigali. Even though it is free, there are still barriers that limit access to the work. The funds will go towards publicizing the festival, transport for schools to attend performances, and technical support for local artists.  We need your help in meeting Hope's request. 

Rwanda is engaged in remarkable acts of recovery and development and the arts, as a tool
for remembering the past and imagining future, continue to be a vital part of its healing and growth. This festival puts socially engaged
artists (from Rwanda and from many other countries and contexts) into
conversation, sharing practices and performances that explore art as a
tool for civic engagement. That it takes place in Rwanda grounds the
work in modern human consequences of violence
and allows more Rwandans to witness and share their expertise. Rwanda serves as our teacher in the study of peace.

By contributing, you will become a supportive member of a conversational community - please see perks for specifics on how our gratitude will manifest itself. And - in addition to material support - we could use help spreading the word. Please feel free to post this page on facebook, or email to your friends and colleagues.

story:
VAULT is Amy Ell’s newest dance endeavor.  With her masterful cohorts, she explores multifaceted movement encompassing the entire performance space.  The results challenge convention and gravity alike, capturing a delicate sense of timelessness and freedom.  Timelessness that allows us to stop and be aware.  Freedom to expand within the natural world around us.


Vault has been invited to perform at the 2nd Annual Irish Aerial Dance Festival on June 18, 2011 and at Les Recontres de Danse Aérienne in La Baule, France on July 3-15, 2011.


In order to offset the cost, we are asking for your support.  Supply your email address and we will include you in the tales of our travels, pictures, words, and all!



Les Recontres de Danse Aérienne

http://www.lesrencontresdedanseaerienne.com/en/


2nd Annual Irish Aerial Dance Festival

http://fidgetfeet.weebly.com/irish-aerial-dance-fest.html




www.amyell.com

www.gyrotonichouston.com

https://www.facebook.com/amy.ell 

http://www.youtube.com/my_videos?feature=mhum

story:
Our Story

In the spring of 2010, Shannon Fillion, Blaze Mancillas, Matthew Michael Hurley, Ellen Joffred, and Danny Mitarotondo came together in Anne Bogart’s collaboration class to fully produce - from page to stage - a new one act play. The result of just three brief weeks of development was What The Sparrow Said, a piece that has, for all of us, been a defining and crucial catalyst in our education and growth at Columbia.

Since collaboration class the one act play has been produced at Theatre for the New City and also in a small festival in Hanoi with a whole new team entirely. This fall, Blaze Mancillas and Matthew Michael Hurley were approached by Romanian director Bogdan SÄƒrÄƒtean while producing A Midsummer Night’s Dream in Germany. Upon seeing a video of Sparrow, he eagerly offered us an opportunity to perform the play in Sibiu, Romania.  


What We Need & What You Get

Through the generosity of the Romanians, all of our accomodations and theatrical needs for this festival are paid for.  We just need to get there.  We are hoping to secure enough funding for the plane travel to Romania for the entire original team, plus our stage manager Ellen Mezzera, none of whom we could easily produce the play without. The total cost of the flights comes in at about $6,000, but all other expenses (such as food and accommodation) will be provided for by the Romanian host-company. 

We are hoping that Columbia University will step up to the plate and provide us with some funding, but it can't end there.  To show Columbia how serious we are, we are hoping to raise half the funds ourselves, a goal they will have to match.  Every dollar counts, and we are grateful for the generosity of our fans and loved ones.


Other Ways You Can Help

We are also planning a fundraiser event on March 21st, so stay tuned for that and let us know if you need more information or would like to join our mailing list! 

 

Our Thanks to the Romanians

We are so grateful to Romanian director Bogdan SÄƒrÄƒtean and our friends in Romania for their invitation to perform Sparrow in Sibiu.  The invitation included performances at both the prestigious Sibiu International Theater Festival this May and at Lucian Blaga University’s 25-hour theater festival this March 25 and 26th.  Due to our graduation schedule we are only able to travel to Romania in March for the 25-hour festival, but send our endless thanks to our friends at both festivals.

story:
Short Summary

The Fox Valley Repertory Performing Arts Academy is home to over 1,000 local youth students who are either learning the arts for the first time, building self-confidence through performance techniques, or fine tuning their stage talents.  With the growing number of classes, camps and workshops being offered to the community, it is time to create a true home for our students and parents.

Our DIY Project 

With your help, Fox Valley Rep wants to create a rehearsal room in their very own administrative building!  While performances will still take place at Pheasant Run Resort, we want students to have one main space for their classes.  This space will include:

  • Easy and accessible parking within steps of our reherasal room doors
  • A small waiting room for parents
  • Carpeted rehearsal space with mirrors, white boards, and a piano
  • Steps away from Culver's: great for grabbing a beverage, meal, or cool treat while you're waiting!

The Impact

Having a dedicated rehearsal space for our academy is important to us – it will be a place that is comfortable, consistent, and close to our administrative office and staff.  Our goal is to raise $5,000 to help cover the costs of fresh paint, carpet, mirrors, and labor.  We do not want to raise tuition or ticket prices.  But through our loyal and generous Fox Valley Rep fans and supporters, we are hoping to meet/exceed our goal in enough time to unveil our new rehearsal room by the Fall of 2013!

Every Dollar Makes a Difference

Whether you’re able to contribute or not, it is free to help us spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, email, text, or word of mouth!  Also, signing up for a summer camp is another great way to support our vision. Every single dollar or recommendation will help us make it to our goal!  

All donations are tax-deductible!

story:
The Project

Wolf is a new play, loosely based on a Hungarian folktale and written by yours truly (Aleah Black). It centers on questions of obligation, love, and humanity.

Wolf is an examination of modes of storytelling, song, dance, visual arts, and poetry to create a modern take on myth and archetypes.

It will be a lot of fun; Wolf is a collaborative exploration of the pleasure of making art, the power of community, and what it means to be a human.

It will be talking place in the middle of March, 2013 at Bard College. 

If you want to keep up with show progress and see photos and updates, like the facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/wolfaleahblack?ref=hl

The Importance

Plays are troublesome; they are site and time specific and take lots of money and effort. That is part of the reason they are important.

The kind of theater I am interested in creating you experience oncence, in real-time, and amidst a group of other people. Wolf will remind us of who we are as individuals and as a collective.

Wolf is important because it will be cheep, accessible theater. It will be theater that provokes and entertains. It will be art created for its own sake, not for monetary gain.

It will be a reminder that in a sometimes lonely, technology driven world, we are always surrounded by the communities and stories that have shaped us.

The Needs

A team of amazing artists have already signed on to create the sets, costumes, lighting design, promotional materials, music, and all the other odds-and-ends that go into making a fantastic show.

All of the wonderful people in the show (including photographers, musicians, actors, stage managers, lighting designers, etc.) have agreed to work for free. They believe in the project that much.

That said, I need to give them the materials to create high quality work. My goal is to have sets and costumes that are as much art pieces as they are functional parts of the play. This means money to buy all of the fabric and construction materials and that is just the tip of the iceberg. 

Please donate as much or as you can. Anything and everything you can give is so appreciated. This show will not be subsidized by my school nor an existing theater or playhouse.This campaign is what decides the fate of this show.

The End

If you want to watch the play progress, there will be updates and photos posted to the campaign and a Facebook page where you can keep up with the cast.

Thanks for reading, contributing, sharing, and doing whatever you can to help my play. I will be giving extra thanks, love, and gifts to the most generous donors. 

I appreciate all of you.

It's going to be a wild ride.

story:
YOU can Be the Change by supporting our Cultural Exchange!

The motto of one of our performance troupes,

IMPACT (Inspiring Mentoring, Positive Activists Called Teens) is…

“Be the Change You Want to See in the World!

We, at The Finest Performance Foundation, believe in promoting peace through education and cultural awareness.  One way we do this is through Cultural Performance Exchanges. In the summer of 2012, an entourage of 20 of us traveled to Germany cosponsored by the Rockville Sister City Corporation to visit and perform in Pinneberg, Hamburg and Berlin.

This summer, 2013, we will host 18 Exchange visiting performers coming to  Rockville, Washington DC, and New York City, USA.

Your donation helps toward expenses for our German visitors experiencing America for the first time! Contribute to a worthy cause - fostering the positive character development and leadership skills of today’s youth. DONATE NOW!

The Finest Performance Foundation is a nonprofit 501 (c)(3) tax-exempt corporation under the IRS. Your donation is 100% tax deductible.

Even the smallest donation can help. But if making a donation is not an option for you right now, you can still help by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Indiegogo has some helpful share tools!

The Finest Performance Foundation is a proud partner with the

Rockville Sister City Corporation and the

National Capital Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America

(Learning for Life Explorer Post 1711)

story:
URINETOWN - The Musical

Bird in Hand and Fraggled Productions are pleased to announce the run of URINETOWN - THE MUSICAL October 5-28th at the Lounge Theatres in Hollywood, California!

  • We are a company of Angelenos (both natives and transplants) striving to make our voices heard through the relevant and inspiring theatre community on the West Coast.
  • We are a passionate and dedicated group who create exciting pieces together using our combined perspectives, opinions, aesthetics, and talents to communicate a play's important message to the world.
  • After the success of our first Indiegogo Campaign, we now are able to shoot for round two!

In order to get the show up and running we are asking for YOUR support!

 

It's a Privilige to Pee... that's worth $5,000

Live theatre is enchanting to witness, engages the mind, and expensive to produce.

  • We need to raise $5,000 for this production!
  • This includes costumes, set pieces, sound equipment, lighting instruments, advertising, refreshments, fees to this generous site, and every other theatrical accoutrement.

For those of you that choose to support URINETOWN, we have little thank you's for each tier:

  • Any contribution - a shoutout in the program
  • $25 - poster of the show
  • $50 - poster signed by the cast
  • $100 - signed cast photo & poster
  • $250 - nods in our promo videos (name dropping at it's finest. Don't you want to be on the internets?)
  • $500 - a pair of tickets to the show & a nod in the video
  • $1,000 - Co-Producing Credit

** each tier includes those that preceed it**

Even if we do not reach our goal, we will produce the show with the money we have raised at that point in time.

 

Your contribution will make a HUGE impact in the show's realization!

In this economy the first thing to suffer are the arts. There's no money or time anymore. But there is a human interest and need for the arts, especially live theater.

There is nothing like watching another person, right in front of you, experiencing emotions that we all share. Participating in the life events of a character the audience has come to love is the reason we still go to the theater.

The young people of this world have unique perspectives to share, and they should be able to get that chance, no matter what the economy looks like.

Let us share that with you and the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! Make some noise about this to everyone you know!

  • Visit our website
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Watch us on Youtube

Be a part of making this a reality!

 

The companies of Bird in Hand, Last Exit, and Fraggled Productions thank you for your support. We'll see you at the show!!

story:
Our Story

Hello! My name is Epiphany and I am a member of Simone Sobers Dance, a NYC based contemporary dance company. We have recently been invited to present our work in Sweden at the Stockholm Fringe Festival. This will be the company's premiere of our new installation piece "Kaged"-a performance work about unleashing stories of women of color. So we are raising money to help cover travel costs and accommodations.

The Impact

This is a unique opportunity for the company as it will allow us to share our work at a prestigious international festival and create a cross-cultural dialogue about womens issues/stories through the art of dance.


What We Need & What You Get

Each member of the company is aiming to raise $1200 to cover costs of travel and accommodations. All funds that you donate will go directly towards my personal travel costs and accommodations for this trip.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word by passing on the link to others you think would be interested in supporting this dream of ours!

story:
TOGETHER WE CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE!!

 

Movement fills our human spirit as it breaths through our body and brings sensation, richeness and awareness to life. Art opens our eyes and minds and enriches our senses; we experience things never experienced before, even though they were always there in front of us. Dance artfully moves us physically and mentally and forms a vital foundation for greater self development, either as a participant or observer. Consider the bleak prospect of our world without art. Help make a difference; together we can move a little piece of the world


Atelier Favela is a small cultural center in the village of Ticuantepe
Managua, Nicaragua. It began with two artists who shared a vision: helping
people in need, while providing them with an opportunity for creativity
and selfsufficiency. Children disadvantaged by poverty are invited to the
cultural center for exploring and participating in various art forms,
including dance. Teenagers and adults from the village are provided
necessary creative tools for making crafts that they sell. Fundamental
self-esteem lifts their human spirit through experiencing self-suffciency
with the added joy of creativity. The center however is most importantly an
after school program staffed by volunteer artists who provide disadvantaged
children with constant encouragement and teach them how to
live a sustainable life and reach a viable future. These children of
Atelier Favela are my focus.

My commitment is this: with your support and success of this fundraiser, I
will take all of my dance education, experience and energies to the
children of Atelier Favela and plunge myself in their pool of youthful,
limitless potential. My desire and personal reward is the hope that my waves will
radiate through these children and move them in unison toward brighter
shores carried by inspiration,
wonderment, and encouragment.

Dance opens my eyes to the beauty and fragility of life, and it motivates
me to look and move forward, to see beyond and at the same time humbles me
with the hard work of the present that signals the journey is its own
reward. This is the message I intend to take jointly, with you, to The
Children of Atelier Favela.


PLEASE HELP ME HELP OTHERS!!!

Donated funds in support of this goal are for airfare and associted travel
expenses, food and shelter. ALL remaining funds are for direct donation to
the further benefit of Atelier Favela.

I am a full-time, self-supported student at Cornish College of the
Arts in Seattle and assure you this effort will be made in the most frugal
manner possible. All of you who donate will receive a full account of this
missionË‡s expenses.


CHECK OUT THE PERKS!!!!

Obviuosly the greastest reward in our effort is we have done something
together to empower the small, the impoverished. My Perks listed are just a
simple way to say ¨Thank You!!ã€ƒ in different doses.

 

CANT DONATE? THATS OKAY! JUST SIMPLY HELP SPREAD THE WORD, EVERY EFFORT HELPS!!!


LET'S DANCE TOGETHER!!!!!

"We should consider every day lost in which we have not danced at least
once."
-Fredich Nietsche

Sapere Aude - Have Courage To Use Your Own Reason

 

More information about the organization at http://www.atelierfavela.org

The center however is most importantly anafter school program staffed by volunteer artists who provide disadvantagedchildren with constant encouragement and teach them how tolive a sustainable life and reach a viable future. These children ofAtelier Favela are my focus.My commitment is this: with your support and success of this fundraiser, Iwill take all of my dance education, experience and energies to thechildren of Atelier Favela and plunge myself in their pool of youthful,limitless potential. My desire and personal reward is the hope that my waves willradiate through these children and move them in unison toward brightershores carried by inspiration,wonderment, and encouragment.Dance opens my eyes to the beauty and fragility of life, and it motivatesme to look and move forward, to see beyond and at the same time humbles mewith the hard work of the present that signals the journey is its ownreward. This is the message I intend to take jointly, with you, to TheChildren of Atelier Favela.PLEASE HELP ME HELP OTHERS!!!Donated funds in support of this goal are for airfare and associted travelexpenses, food and shelter. ALL remaining funds are for direct donation tothe further benefit of Atelier Favela.I am a full-time, self-supported student at Cornish College of theArts in Seattle and assure you this effort will be made in the most frugalmanner possible. All of you who donate will receive a full account of thismissionË‡s expenses.CHECK OUT THE PERKS!!!!Obviuosly the greastest reward in our effort is we have done somethingtogether to empower the small, the impoverished. My Perks listed are just asimple way to say ¨Thank You!!ã€ƒ in different doses.
 
CANT DONATE? THATS OKAY! JUST SIMPLY HELP SPREAD THE WORD, EVERY EFFORT HELPS!!!LET'S DANCE TOGETHER!!!!!"We should consider every day lost in which we have not danced at leastonce."-Fredich Nietsche


Sapere Aude - Have Courage To Use Your Own Reason
 
More information about the organization at http://www.atelierfavela.org

story:
Many Thanks to all who contributed to the 2013 campaign!  

Your contributions helped us fund a fabulous season of funny!  We had a successful run at Gotham City Improv including:

The Groovy Gang Adventures

Original Concept by Nannette Deasy

Directed by Pat Shay​


Jinkies! The Groovy Gang is up to their old tricks in IRTE's latest long-form improvisational comedy. Join your favorite band of teen sleuths and their talking alligator drummer Chompers, as they solve yet another spooky mystery.​

With Musical Guests Jessica Delfino (April 6), Summer & Eve(April 10), andMr. Big Head (April 20)


​INTERLUDES 2063
Original Concept and Directed by Alex Decaneas

Produced by Alistair Firebrand

With Special Guest Improvisers Stacy Price and Stephen Thornton


In a world where chaos is king, one traveling theater troupe remains, forever on tour.


Well met, mutants! IRTE improv returns to perform as INTERLUDES. Set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland, INTERLUDES is the last regional touring theater company taking bookings. Based on audience suggestions, this menagerie of performers will astonish with comic tales of days past - if they don’t kill each other first!

With Musical Guests ​EVan Laurence (May 4), ​Squirm and Germ (May 8), and ​Gift of Tongues (May 18)


​vIRTEgo Circus
Original Concept and Directed by Nannette Deasy (Gotham City Improv, NYC)

Directed by Pat Shay​ (Tampa Improv Festival, FL)

With Special Guest Improvisers Evie Aronson, Adam Leong and Marcia Sofley​

In the back roads of Anywhere, USA, a travelling carnival of lost souls and circus misfits will perform games and scenes based entirely on your wicked suggestions. Just be careful what you wish for.

vIRTEgo Circus! Something funny this way comes!﻿

﻿With Musical Guests Jason Soffer (June 1), Gift of Tongues (June 15) andPositive Feedback(June 29)

Space Probe

Original Concept by Robert Baumgardner

Directed by Bleep Blorp BoobleAaks VII

With Special Guest Improvisers Graceann Dorse and Stephen Thornton

The crew of the SS Buzz Aldrin flounders in deep space. Their only option...get a tow to the nearest planet from AakAak Towing. One problem, AakAak only takes payment in the local currency of Grudax.

Follow our intrepid crew as they improvise life among the aliens of a planet they know absolutely nothing about. Can they find work as foreigners to pay the towing charges? Is that alien dueling, or proposing marriage? How much can a faster than light propulsion unit cost? Come see the fun of IRTE's next fully improvised comedy, and find out what happens. Will our explorers get off, or will they get...PROBED?

﻿﻿With Musical Guests ​Charlotte Cornfield(July 6), Gift of Tongues FeaturingMatt Dallowon Accordion and Theremin (July 13) and Craig Greenberg (July 20)

​The Clique
Original Concept and Directed by Jeff O’Leary

With Special Guest Improviser Graceann Dorse

You got what it takes to hang with the cool kids? What are you: a burn-out, band geek, goth kid, jock, bookworm, skater, emo kid, cheerleader, stoner dude, preppy wannabe, choir kid, drama nerd? What’s it gonna be? Make up your mind, kid – this school is a warzone and if you don’t find a posse to back you up, you’re gonna get caught in the crossfire.

IRTE presents an evening of long-form improv  based on the high school experiences of one of our audience members. And that audience member could be you!

It's time to hang with the cool kids, with the real rulers of this school. It’s time to hang with...THE CLIQUE

﻿﻿With Musical Guests ​Carla Ulbrich(August 3), The Vigilante (August 10) and Craig Greenberg(August 17)


We also attended the following festivals:

The New Orleans Comedy Arts Festival​​
IRTE Presents: That Kick Ass Time Jump Show... Please Don't Sue Us, Scott Bakula​
January 16 & 18, 2013, 8:00pm @ La Nuit Comedy Theater
5039 Freret St, New Orleans, LA 70115
(504) 231-7011
Jan 16: Tickets: $10 pre-sale, $12 at the door.

Jan 18: $16 pre-sale, $18 at the door

All tickets include 1 free pint of beer from NOLA Brewing

Unscripted New York Improvised Theatre and Film Festival​​

​IRTE Presents: The Groovy Gang Adventures
June 2, 2013, 5:00pm @ Theatre 54, Shetler Studios (12th Floor)
244 W. 54th St., NYC
unscriptedfest@gmail.com

Tickets: $8 ​


15th Anniversary Del Close Marathon
​IRTE Presents: The Groovy Gang Adventures
June 30, 2013, 12:45am @ the Hudson Guild Theatre
441 West 26th Street, New York, NY 10001
Tickets: Weekend Wristband $30

Tampa Improv Festival​

IRTE Presents: vIRTEgo Circus

Halloween, October 31, 2013, 9:00pm @ the Silver Meteor Gallery

2213 E 6th Ave, Tampa, FL 33604

Tickets: $5


Thanks for all of your support and we look forward to seeing you at our shows in 2014!

story:
What is queerSpawn?

From Urban Dictionary:
 
1. Queerspawn: A person who has lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or queer parents or guardians.
 
Ex: Tim: "He is a queerspawn!"
Dave: "Yeah I love his moms"
 
queerSpawn is a new play by Mallery Avidon that A Collection of Shiny Objects has been working to bring to the New York stage since the summer of 2012. It tells the story of The Kid, a 14-year-old, starting high school in a small town. Everyone knows he has 2 moms, and that's just the beginning of his trouble. While dodging bullies, The Kid invents a group of imaginary friends, including sex/relationship advice columnist Dan Savage and Dr. McSteamy from tv's 'Grey's Anatomy', with whom to share his troubles. But as his reality becomes more and more hazardous, their "help" becomes less and less helpful. Staring down 4 more friendless years, what is a Kid to do? 
 
Mallery's orginal research was supported by Colage, the only national organization for people raised in LGBTQ families, where she had the opportunity to interview teens and young adult children about their experiences at home and in the world.
 
queerSpawn will be presented at HERE in New York City May 10-19, 2013 with a fantastic cast that includes David Greenspan (THE ROYAL FAMILY, CORALINE), Chris Perfetti (SONS OF THE PROPHET, Roundabout's PICNIC) and Noel Joseph Allain (MOTEL CHERRY).

Who is A Collection of Shiny Objects?

A Collection of Shiny Objects is a performance collective founded and led by Liz English, Jesse Geiger and Nathan Leigh, with a rotating group of collaborators and associate artists. A Collection of Shiny Objects creates live performance to explore the complexity of contemporary society and popular culture, especially representations of gender, sexuality, class and race. We are committed to blending performance disciplines: incorporating theater, music, dance, puppets, multimedia, and the deconstruction of the artifacts of popular culture. We are inclusive of our participating artists and audiences. We make good work and have a good time doing it.

Previous/ongoing projects include THE EXILE OF PETIE DELARGE by Jennifer Barclay (Son of Semele Theater/REDCAT NOWFest 2010), DARLING (concert presentation at Ars Nova as part of ANT Fest 2011), GOODS AND SERVICES (in development, SPACE at Ryder Farm, 2011) and THE COLLECTIONS (an informal performance salon series held at locations around Brooklyn).

 

What's the Money For?

A Collection of Shiny Objects knows how to make a lot out of a little so your small donation can get us a looong way.

That said, creating shiny new theater takes money. We have actors, designers, and other contributing artists to pay. We have rehearsal spaces to rent and sets, props and costumes to buy and make. We have programs and postcards to print so we can share our message and get folks to the show. 
 
queerSpawn has a lot to say about bullying and LGBTQ families. Your donation will help us complete our budget, invite a diverse group of artists and audiences into this conversation and make this debut New York production the best it can be.
 

GREAT PERKS!

We want YOU to join us at this dark, funny new play! Ten bucks gets you a shout-out as a Donor in the program, and for just $25-$50 you'll be our guest to the performance.
 
Able to give MORE?! We have custom, limited edition posters and t-shirts (for $100-$250 donations) to keep long after this run of queerSpawn is over and show the world you supported A Collection of Shiny Objects first.
 
Be a Shiny Objects VIP (for a donation of $500) with your very own Shiny Pass to all upcoming A Collection of Shiny Objects events (Collections, concerts, work-in-progress showings) in 2013. 
 
For the very, very special, be a Shiny Objects Hero and for just $1000 musical genius Mr. Nathan Leigh will compose, perform and record a personal theme song and tell you and everyone you know just how much you mean to us.
 

Please Spread the Word about queerSpawn!

Like us? Please share this campaign and info about the show with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, face-to-face, or any other way you can.
 
Come see the show! We'll be at HERE May 10-19, 2013.
 
Be our Friend on Facebook! Follow us on Twitter! Subscribe to our Newsletter to be a part of this and other A Collection of Shiny Objects happenings!

story:
What's this show?

Vulture-Wally is a dance piece that uses spoken word, song, and dialog to create a long-form, physicalized poem about who owns our bodies and who authors our stories. Based on an old Austrian serial novel, the dance dissects a melodramatic hero(ine) by resurrecting her body one part at a time.

We've broken the story into chapters, each one a different part of the body. We've deconstructed the language into dance and poetry and gesture. And we've cast the lead character as 4 dancers - Sweeney, Siobhan Burke, Lydia Chrisman, and Tara Willis. There's no narrative left here.

Like an album of music, Vulture-Wally goes from chapter to chapter (or song to song, or scene to scene) thematically, building on the previous emotion and creating texture in beauty and humor, rather than trying to answer big questions or resolve a fictional plot.

Where/When is the show?

May 31 - June 2 / June 4 / June 6 - 9 @ 8pm
Tickets on sale soon!

Incubator Arts Project
St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery
131 East 10th Street (at 2nd Avenue), NYC

incubatorarts.org
jilliansweeney.com

Who's involved?

Creator/Choreographer: Jillian Sweeney

Director/Sound Designer/Writer: Jeffrey Cranor

Performers: Sweeney, Siobhan Burke, Lydia Chrisman, and Tara Willis

Set Designer: Brad Kisicki

Lighting Designer: Vinny Vigilante

Costume Designer: Suzan Eraslan

Where are contributions going?

Short answer: to the artists.

Longer answer: this show costs well over $3,000 to produce. These costs are offset by ticket sales, our own contibutions (Jeffrey & Jillian's), donations from this Indiegogo campaign, and in-kind donations (like the rehearsal residencies we received in 2012 from Immediate Medium and Lower Manhattan Cultural Council). We pay all of the performers and creators as best we can, because they are trained, talented people giving a lot of time and amazing work. They deserve compensation.

We also must rent rehearsal space, buy lights and set pieces and costumes and props. Any gift you give can help us pay for these things, and should this project finish in the black, that is simply more money we can give to the artistic collaborators & crew.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Or maybe just want to do more?

  • Come to the show! Tickets on sale soon.
  • Even better: Come to the show opening weekend (Fri, May 31 - Sun, Jun 2). The earlier you see it, the more time you have to tell others about it, and the more people will come. It's only 8 shows, so every bit helps.
  • Spread the word (like the URL to this very page!) on Facebook and Twitter.

story:
Short Summary

Hey Guys and Gals

My name is Davon Magwood, I am a stand up comic. 

This June --- I'm embarking on a huge DIY grass roots stand-up comedy tour across the Country!  The shows are already booked! By the end, I'll have made  thousands laughed and gather stories from comics from all walks of life!  But only if your help gets me there.

Watch the video -- I want you to be my tour sponsor. With your support I'll be able to live my dream and get to explore the national comedy scene while I travel.

Why sponsor me? Because laughter is worth it, and I can't do it without you. This tour involves 3,000+ miles of travel to faraway cities that are in need of a good time. Being my sponsor will help cover those expenses -- gas, maintenance, food, hotels, promo, and merchandise -- so I can get to the funny part! 

I plan to post videos weekly and host live chats while on the road so you will get to see what I see as I explore this great nation! 

Please take a look, and give generously every bit helps. 

Thanks,

Davon Magwood 

What we need and why.

The goal is to raise 4,500 and that will be spent on:

  • Housing
  • Travel
  • Food
  • Merch
  • promo 
  • film  

We are going cross country in 3 months and this is what we need to be able to make that happen. 

The Impact

I was inspired years ago by the "Comedians of Comedy" and how the capture the tour from being on the road a performing on stage.

What I am doing is bring my stand up comedy to 30 plus cities and towns. But I'm also going to interview the comics from those areas I think capturing those stories wil not only help comics who are new but maybe inspire some comics are down on themselves. The goal is just to give comics who are not in LA or NYC to be able to share why they love doing it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't really help on the funds end. Please spread the word online. Twitter, Facebook, whatever new site is cool! This is a grassroots movement, anything you do is welcomed! 

 ****TOUR DATES******

JUNE

6-10 Comedy Store Main room LA Ca

6-12 M.I's Westside Comedy Theater LA Ca10pm

6-13 Rafa's Art Lounge Echo Park LA Ca

6-18 Milk Bar San Francisco Ca

6-19 Voodoo Comedy Playhouse Denver Co.

6-20 SIP bar San Francisco Ca 9pm

6-21Austin TBA

 JULY

5th July Standpipe Coffeehouse Lufkin Texas 10pm

7th-Kansas TBA

10th-Elite Bar & Grill 100 Main St. St Peters MO

11th Chemically Imbalanced Comedy Chicago 8pm

12th Louie’s Trophy House and Grill Kalamazoo MI 

13th Detroit    TBA

27th  Milwaukee WI

AUG

7th-PACA Erie Pa

9th - One And One Bar NYC

10-Club Cafe Pittsburgh Pa (2 shows)

15th- Weirton Wv TBA

16- The Grouge Shop Cleveland Oh

21- The Comedy Studio Boston Ma

22or23- Tunez and QueMorgantown Wv

28thor29th-Philadelphia Pa.

30-31th-Washinton DC

If you can't really help on the funds end. Please spread the word online. Twitter, Facebook, whatever new site is cool! This is a grassroots movement, anything you do is welcomed!

story:
The Ghost Road Company is heading to the Korczak Festival in Warsaw, Poland this October, where we have been invited to present our production of Malgorzata Sikorska-Miszczuk's "Pantofelnik's Suitcase", a new play in its first English-language production.  While in Warsaw, we have also been invited to present our latest ensemble-devised work, "The Bargain and the Butterfly".  There are 9 of us going, 6 actors, our director, producer and stage manager and we are all extremely excited to be presenting our work for the first time in Poland. We are literally short 2 round trip tickets plus baggage fees!  Please support this project!

The Shows and Their History

In the Spring of 2010, Ghost Road was asked to host an evening with three Polish artists, Marcin Liber, Malgorzata Sikorska-Miszczuk, and Woytek Staas, and also present a reading of Sikorska-Miszczuk's "Pantofelnik's Suitcase".  That following summer, while in Warsaw seeing plays and meeting with Polish artists, Ghost Road's Katharine Noon and Mark Seldis spent a day with the playwright and began a friendship which carried over into the fall of 2011, when the company was asked to present a workshop of "Pantofelnik's Suitcase" to coincide with Sikorska-Miszczuk's brief residency at USC.  Based on the response from the playwright, as well as officials from the Polish Consulate and Ministry of Culture, we were invited to bring a full production of the play to the annual Korczak Festival in Warsaw in October 2013.

In the meantime, Ghost Road completed work on our latest ensemble-devised work, "The Bargain and the Butterfly" and presented the world premiere of the piece in March and April of this year.  Having participated in a highly successful residency in Poland with lauded Polish ensemble Studium Teatralne in 2011, there was tremendous interest in having Ghost Road present our original work in Warsaw. As both plays can be performed with essentially the same actors, this became the perfect opportunity to introduce our new piece to European audiences.  We are very excited to be launching this new work in Poland, a place that has become very dear to us all.

The Korczak Festival is paying a small fee and providing lodging, with additional hospitality from the Adam Mickiewicz Institute and the Polish Consulate in Los Angeles.  With that support, plus some fundraising we have already done, we have all our expenses and 7 of our plane tickets covered.  Please help us make this dream a reality by contributing today!

What will the money go towards:

- 2 Round-Trip tickets to Warsaw

- Baggage Fees

Every cent you contribute will go towards this show.  $3,840 is the bare minimum needed to make the rest of this trip a reality, so if we can raise more it will go toward reimbursing the very expensive flights for this show as well as purchasing props and additional production equipment. 

This trip is going to be a truly life changing and unforgettable experience for all of us involved.  Your support means so much and we thank you from the bottom of our hearts. 

Sincerely,

Ghost Road Company

Katharine, Mark, Brian, Christel, Ronnie, Kim, Doug, Jen, Andrew

www.ghostroad.org

story:
For three years I have been trying to find a way to bring the show "White People" by J.T. Roger to the stage in Tampa. At last, with the support of Tampa Repertory Theater Squared, this dream is finally going to happen. 

But as is the case with all theater, there are costs. I'm launching this Indiegogo campaign to raise money to offset the rights so that I can pay my three very talented artists more than the tiny stipend they agreed to. Actors work very hard, and as this is a non-union theater, they are working for very little. 

You can help. By making a donation of $5, $10, $25 or even $50 dollars you can help us reach our goal. You donation will go a long way, no matter the amount.

Please consider helping us in our campaign, supporting live theater, and helping me bring this powerful play to the stage.

Thank you for your time and support.

Thank you for your time and support.

story:
Our Story

I am Jamie Erin Murphy and I am a Pittsburgh based dancer and choreographer.  This past May I was chosen along with 15 others to work and be mentored by NYC choreographer, Doug Varone, through his first ever DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive.  On September 12-14 Doug Varone will present the 16 emerging choreographers in the CHIN Project.  
I am very proud of this work that has been built using the devices and techniques that Doug Varone shared with me.  My dancers have been working hard and donating a ton of time, talent and dedication to this project.  Any donation will help us to finish our creation and get to NYC to present work in this once in a lifetime opportunity!

Help us to raise funds!!!

The funds we raise will go directly to paying the dancers for their time and work, costumes, music, rehearsal space, travel costs and stay in NYC.  We are striving to raise $2700 to cover all costs, but any money donated will help to make this project possible!!!


The Impact

Even though this dance work will be premiering in NYC, we still want to give back to the Pittsburgh Dance Community as well.  Helping us to fund this project will also help its cast of Pittsburgh collaborators to show our work locally at a later date in September.

I understand that traveling this work was a big on taking, however, I strongly believe that the ideas that I have been learning and working have and will continue to influence my work as an artist.  All of the choreographers for the CHIN Project have been working hard and the more of us that are able to present our works in this showcase the more likely it will be for new choreographers to get this opportunity with Doug Varone and Dancers in the future!!!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you are not able to help finacially there are other ways you can continue to support our project...

    • Sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, your blog, and through emailing your friends and family.
    • By spreading the word.  
    • Offering any other assistance. Donations of any kind are always helpful in the creation process!
    ***On September 12-14, 2014, Doug Varone and Dancers presents the work of 16 hand-selected emerging choreographers in the CHIN Project, the culminating event of the DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive (CHIN). DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive is a mentoring program of Doug Varone and Dancers, made possible with generous funding support from the New York Community Trust.  The program is supported, in part, by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, in partnership with the City Council.  The CHIN Project is presented in partnership with the 92nd Street Y.

story:
What is High-Five for Bang-Galore? 

Bang-Galore is an evening of original scenes, monologues, and one-acts by playwright Ken Ferrigni (Occupation, Mangella, angel/buddy). They are funny and crass and none of these plays have ever been performed in New York.

  • We love Ken and his work- we want everyone to see it. 
  • We love a lot of amazing actors who don't have enough quality work to do.
  • We love all of you and want to give you a truly engaging, original show that is, first and foremost, a really fun time. 

That's how Bang-Galore was born. We've selected the pieces, gathered a stellar cast, and put down a deposit at the lovely, local Chain Theater in Queens, New York. The show runs for 3 nights starting on October 30, 2014. 

This is where you come in. We don't care about making money. All we care about is gathering enough to pay for the space and production elements to make this an awesome night of theater and merriment. We want to put on a great show and we want you to come and enjoy it. And we want you to do that in a space that feels like a beautiful theater and not at all like a Port Authority men's room. 

So we're asking for $5. That's it. Crowd-funded theater for the people. Rather than lean on anyone for a big donation, we want to use this "High-Five" campaign to get our collective community engaged and contribute a little bit to make this happen. Can we get 680 people to give a little to make some art in 30 days? That's up to you. Please give us your latte money, share with your friends, and (most importantly) join us Halloween weekend for a Bang-Galorious time! 

What We Need & What You Get

It's pretty simple. 

What we need: 

  • $2200 is going to the rental of the Chain Theater for the week of the performance. It covers tech. So we can get fancy. 
  • $200 goes to general liability and accident insurance. Because we're grown-ups now and we need that. Feel free to slip at the theater and sue us. 
  • $620 goes to pay all of our actors. Because that is the minimum amount we must pay according to the Equity Showcase code. We split the door profits. If there are any. See? This is for YOU!
  • $380 goes to production costs- Props and costumes, set transport, lighting gels, programs, and paying our board op. 
And that's $3400. I know, It's shocking how little that actually goes. But it buys a whole SHOW! And it pales in comparison to...

What you get:
  • This is also simple. If you live in or near NYC, give us $5 and we'll take it off your ticket.
  • Most importantly, you get to come to Bang-Galore. 
What if we get MORE?!
Let's not get carried away. First of all, if we don't make our goal, you will still get to see Bang-Galore. Never fear. But the money will be coming from the pockets of us poor starving artists who will end up prostituting ourselves in hideous temp jobs for lecherous hedge fund executives (probably).

If we DO happen to make more than what we're asking, there's no telling what we might do. We might do something crazy like pay our board op and our actors more money. We might do something more expected, like hire an elephant to carry the marquee or give everyone in the audience a Vitamix. We might even extend this craziness a whole extra week to share the Bang-Galory with more people. It's up to you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute. We understand. Sometimes you're feeling like today just might be the day for that $5 scratch-off. Sometimes Duane Reade is having a sale on family-size bags of Skittles. Sometimes you drop your coffee on the sidewalk, sploosh it over your outfit, and have to buy a NEW coffee. 

Let's get real. $5 is not much. So if you can find it in your hearts to send it our way and make this happen, we would be truly grateful. That being said, we can use your FREE help whether you decide to donate or not. This High-Five Campaign is truly crowd-funding, so please share with your friends!

  • Send an email to your friends and family, make a post on Facebook or Twitter, and link to our page or video. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools- they're so easy! 

And that's all there is to it. Please join us. In a totally non-cult-like way. 

Questions, Comments, Suggestions? 

Please e-mail: BangGaloreNYC@gmail.com

story:
So what is FFT?

We’re a new theater company in Chicago, whose big-picture goal is two-fold:

1) To create a home for UChicago alumni artists within the greater Chicago arts community
2) To contextualize performance for the current moment within “the life of the mind,” a UChicago tagline which implies a rigorous academic approach to the work.

All the while, we aim to make work which people want to see, especially our peers, the crowd who less and less goes to see live performance.

Why give us money? And what are we spending it on?

Right now we are raising our start-up operating costs. Sure, when you think of money a theater company might need, you think of space rental and design budgets and yes, we will, eventually have to pay for those things. However, there are a lot of expenses we have to face first including:

-Monthly membership fees for our umbrella non-profit status: $20/month
-Application fee for our own 501c3 status: $300
-Application fee to incorporate within the state of IL: $77.75
-Buying our domain name: $8.17
-Monthly domain hosting fee: $40/month
-Printing announcement materials: $36.87
-Space rental for our launch party: $400

and this month we have to:
-Reserve the space for our first full length run: $1200
-Buy the rights for that show: $1950
-Other expenses for the launch party: $250
-Application fee for our own 501c3 status: $300

And then later this year we’ll have to:
Pay the rest of the space rental: at least $2400
Buy rental insurance: $500
Pay banking fees
Design two shows...
Pay space rental on our festival show
And so many more things....and we’re not even paying our artists yet as much as we really want to...

So, as you can see, $2000 is a tiny fraction of what we need to make it through this year but it is the bare minimum we need for now.

If you can spare even $5 it would mean the world to us but if you can help us go above and beyond our goal please do! The more fundraising we can get out of the way up front, the more we can focus on the art later in the year! And the more people support us NOW, the more eligible we become for grants in the future.

 

Thanks for supporting us!

story:
In Man of La Mancha, a talented cast of twelve actors will tell the Tony Award-winning story of Miguel de Cervantes, an aging failure as a playwright and poet, who has been thrown into a dungeon, in Seville, to await trial by the Spanish Inquisition for an offense against the Church.  There, he is dragged before a mock trial of his fellow prisoners, who plan to confiscate his few possessions - including his uncompleted manuscript of a novel, Don Quixote.

Transporting you to a gritty, dungy Spanish prison, our design and artisitic team is led by Artistic Director John Allen Biles, Director Ted Watts, and Scenic and Lighting Designer Dan Kendgia.  The set will be an exposed, engaging experience, utilizing the most creative stage and lighting techniques.  Led by the musical direction of Tim Marquette, a live orchestra of acoustic guitarists will recreate the most integral parts of Mitch Leigh's classic score.

 

Who is The Company of Pittsburgh?


We are an innovative theater company, whose primary goal is to fill a void in Pittsburgh's live, professional musical theater.  We utilize only the most essential peices of each musical in our productions.  This approach includes using multi-media techniques to suggest location, a well-built set and scaling down the orchestra to just a handful of live musicians. 


Dedicating ourselves to local artists, we celebrate their talent with the greater Pittsburgh community. 

 

Why is our campaign important?


If you are a fan of theater, and want to support first-class Pittsburgh talent in professional, affordable musical theater productions, we ask that you consider supporting us with your donation.  The costs of producing such unique, outstanding productions depend on your support. 

For each donation we receive, we not only offer incredible perks, but also limited high-end items.

WE GREATLY APPRECIATE ANY AND ALL SUPPORT!

 

How does your donation help?

 

Your donation will fill a void in our production budget for Man of La Mancha, giving us the necessary financial support needed for us to fulfill our ongoing mission to become a sustainable company for musical theater in Pittsburgh. 

 

Other ways you can help:


Connect with us on Facebook social media: www.facebook.com/TheCompanyOfPittsburgh


Follow and support us on Twitter:

https://twitter.com/TheCompanyOfPgh

story:
Hello,

 

My name is Ian O'Brien. I am a professional actor and playwright from the Halton (Ontario) region and a founding member of The Failed Magician's League; A Creative Collective of young and talented minds from the Halton region and beyond. This summer, tFML is taking my show, "Placid Ends At Mothballed Beginnings" from Georgetown, across Canada, to the wonderful city of Nanaimo, B.C., as part of the Fringetastic! Theatre Festival from August 16th to the 26th.
We need your help to make this endeavour a resounding success. 

Not one soul in the cast, crew, or design team is over twenty three. This production is truly a youth creation, and one that seeks to change forever how you and yours view abstract theatre. 

Placid Ends, as it has come to be known, is my first play, written when I was seventeen years old. Three pairs of people and their god inhabit an area of space as close to nowhere as possible. They suffer and mourn in chilling isolation, in the end wholly aware that the world is not but a cycle of detriment and loss, played out to the tune of the divine. The show has been praised for its bold choice of aesthetic, and topic matter: The creeping sensation that our actions and struggles have no meaning or bearing on the outcome of the world.
It's a comedy!

We are asking the people of the internet for a thousand dollars to help us get this show out west. It has been such an incredible honour for us and our town to represent all of Eastern Canada at this festival, and we would be proud to count you as a supporter. 

All funding will go towards accomodation costs for the minors on our roster. We have three members under 18, and we want to make sure they get a guaranteed place to sleep for the entire run of the show, and a healthy three meals a day. After their needs are taken care of, any remaining funds would go towards accomodations for those members over 18.

When we make it out there, we promise to put on a show so wonderfully different than anything that's been seen in Canadian theatre for quite some time. A change is in the air. The young artists of Canada have a drive and a new determination. Who knows? Perhaps with your help this show can acheive some small level of success for the budding youngsters who will drive that new dream forward. 

Of course, donations do not go without their perks. We have devised some super epic "Placid Ends" themed rewards for all you generous donors out there. Such items include hand written letters, documentary videos, props, pictures, and those super generous donors out there will have the option of a dedicated song sent by email OR a dinner theatre evening brought to your door by The Failed Magician's League.

 

We hope that you choose to support our endeavour, and remember, the only way to save Theatre is to pave the way for those that come next.

 

 For more information please check the following websites and emails.

Thank you for taking an interest in our show. Perhaps we'll see you in Nanaimo.

 

The Failed Magician's League:

http://failedmagiciansleague.ca/

dontcutmeinhalf@gmail.com

http://www.facebook.com/groups/257371967670811/

 

Fringetastic!

http://www.facebook.com/fringetastic

http://fringetastic.com/

I am a professional actor and playwright from the Halton (Ontario) region and a founding member of The Failed Magician's League; A Creative Collective of young and talented minds from the Halton region and beyond. This summer, tFML is taking my show, "Placid Ends At Mothballed Beginnings" from Georgetown, across Canada, to the wonderful city of Nanaimo, B.C., as part of the Fringetastic!
